grade_9_10.name: Introduction to Biology & Scientific Method
grade_9_10.short_description: Foundation in scientific inquiry, experimental design, and biological investigation techniques. Students learn to formulate hypotheses, design experiments, collect and analyze data, and communicate scientific findings.

sub_topics.name: Nature of Science
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding scientific principles, theories, laws, and the process of scientific investigation.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Life
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and explain the fundamental properties that distinguish living organisms from non-living matter.
example_tasks: List and describe all eight characteristics of life (organization, metabolism, homeostasis, growth, reproduction, response to stimuli, adaptation, and evolution) with specific examples of each.
Analyze whether a virus should be considered alive by evaluating it against each of the eight characteristics of life and justify your conclusion.
Design a table comparing a living organism (such as a bacterium), a non-living object (such as a rock), and a borderline case (such as a virus or prion) across all characteristics of life.

sub_topics.name: Scientific Theories and Laws
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish between scientific theories, laws, and hypotheses and understand their roles in science.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between a scientific theory and a scientific law using the Cell Theory and the Law of Conservation of Mass as examples.
Evaluate why the Theory of Evolution is considered a scientific theory rather than a hypothesis, providing at least three pieces of supporting evidence.
Create a concept map showing the relationship between observations, hypotheses, experiments, theories, and laws in the scientific process.

sub_topics.name: Branches of Biology
sub_topics.short_description: Explore major subdisciplines of biology and their interconnections.
example_tasks: Match each biological discipline (ecology, genetics, microbiology, anatomy, physiology, taxonomy, evolution, molecular biology) with its primary focus and provide one example of a question each discipline addresses.
Research a current biological discovery in the news and identify which branches of biology contributed to that discovery.
Explain how different branches of biology work together to address a complex issue such as antibiotic resistance or climate change effects on coral reefs.

sub_topics.name: Scientific Method & Experimental Design
sub_topics.short_description: Learn to apply the scientific method and design controlled experiments with proper variables and controls.

sub_topics.name: Steps of the Scientific Method
sub_topics.short_description: Master the sequential steps of scientific investigation from observation to conclusion.
example_tasks: Given an observation (e.g., 'Plants near the window grow taller than plants in the corner'), write a testable hypothesis and describe how you would test it.
Analyze a provided experimental scenario and identify which step of the scientific method is being performed at each stage (observation, question, hypothesis, experiment, analysis, conclusion).
Design a complete scientific investigation to answer the question: 'Does the color of light affect plant growth?' Include all steps from hypothesis to expected results.

sub_topics.name: Variables and Controls
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and distinguish between independent, dependent, and controlled variables in experiments.
example_tasks: For an experiment testing whether temperature affects enzyme activity, identify the independent variable, dependent variable, and at least three controlled variables that must be kept constant.
Critique a flawed experimental design that lacks proper controls and explain what controls should be added to make it a valid experiment.

Design an experiment to test whether fertilizer affects tomato plant height, clearly labeling your control group, experimental group, independent variable, dependent variable, and controlled variables.

sub_topics.name: Data Collection and Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Collect quantitative and qualitative data and use appropriate methods to analyze results.
example_tasks: Given a data table showing bacterial growth at different temperatures, create an appropriate graph (line graph) with properly labeled axes, title, and units.
Calculate the mean, median, and range for a set of experimental measurements and explain which measure of central tendency best represents the data.
Analyze experimental data to determine whether results support or refute the hypothesis, citing specific evidence from the data and addressing potential sources of error.

sub_topics.name: Drawing Conclusions and Communicating Results
sub_topics.short_description: Interpret experimental results and effectively communicate scientific findings.
example_tasks: Write a conclusion paragraph for an experiment that includes whether the hypothesis was supported, what the data showed, possible sources of error, and suggestions for further investigation.
Peer review a classmate's experimental write-up and provide constructive feedback on their experimental design, data analysis, and conclusions.
Create a scientific poster or presentation that communicates an experiment's purpose, methods, results, and conclusions using appropriate scientific conventions.

sub_topics.name: Laboratory Skills & Safety
sub_topics.short_description: Develop proper laboratory techniques, equipment use, and safety protocols essential for biological investigations.

sub_topics.name: Laboratory Safety Procedures
sub_topics.short_description: Understand and apply safety rules, emergency procedures, and proper handling of biological materials.
example_tasks: Identify at least ten laboratory safety rules and explain the scientific or safety rationale behind each rule.
Analyze several laboratory scenarios and identify safety violations, explaining what should have been done differently in each case.
Create a safety poster illustrating proper procedures for one laboratory hazard (chemical spills, broken glass, fire, or biological contamination) including prevention and response steps.

sub_topics.name: Microscope Use and Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Master the proper use of compound light microscopes and preparation of wet mount slides.
example_tasks: Label all parts of a compound light microscope and explain the function of each component (eyepiece, objective lenses, stage, diaphragm, light source, coarse and fine adjustment).
Calculate total magnification for different objective lens combinations and determine the field of view diameter at each magnification level.
Prepare a wet mount slide of an onion cell, focus it properly under low, medium, and high power, and create a detailed biological drawing with proper labeling and magnification noted.

sub_topics.name: Measurement and Scientific Units
sub_topics.short_description: Use metric system measurements and convert between units commonly used in biology.
example_tasks: Convert between metric units: 2500 micrometers to millimeters, 0.045 liters to milliliters, and 3.2 kilograms to grams.
Measure the length of microscopic organisms or cells using a microscope's field of view and calculate actual size in micrometers.
Design a data table using appropriate metric units to record measurements for an experiment involving mass, volume, length, temperature, and time.

sub_topics.name: Laboratory Equipment and Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Properly use common laboratory equipment including pipettes, balances, thermometers, and glassware.
example_tasks: Demonstrate proper technique for using a graduated cylinder to measure 47 mL of water, explaining how to read the meniscus and avoid parallax error.
Use a triple beam balance or electronic balance to accurately measure 5.5 grams of a substance, explaining the proper procedure and precision of the instrument.
Compare the accuracy and appropriate uses of different measuring tools (beaker, graduated cylinder, pipette) for measuring volumes, and explain when each should be used.

sub_topics.name: Data Analysis & Scientific Communication
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze biological data using mathematical and statistical methods, and communicate findings using scientific conventions and formats.

sub_topics.name: Graphing and Data Interpretation
sub_topics.short_description: Create and interpret various types of graphs used to display biological data.
example_tasks: Given data on population growth over time, determine the most appropriate graph type (line, bar, pie, or scatter plot) and create the graph with proper title, labeled axes, scale, and units.
Interpret a graph showing enzyme activity versus pH and answer questions about optimal conditions, range of activity, and how the enzyme performs at different pH levels.
Analyze a graph with error bars showing experimental results and explain what the error bars represent and whether differences between groups are likely significant.

sub_topics.name: Mathematical Calculations in Biology
sub_topics.short_description: Perform calculations relevant to biological concepts including percentages, rates, ratios, and probability.
example_tasks: Calculate percentage change in a population: If a bacterial colony grows from 1,000 cells to 8,000 cells, what is the percentage increase?
Determine the rate of photosynthesis: If a plant produces 45 mL of oxygen in 15 minutes, what is the rate of oxygen production per minute?
Calculate surface area to volume ratio for cells of different sizes and explain how this ratio affects cell size limitations and efficiency.

sub_topics.name: Scientific Writing and Documentation
sub_topics.short_description: Write clear, objective laboratory reports and scientific explanations using appropriate terminology and format.
example_tasks: Write a formal laboratory report including the following sections: title, purpose, hypothesis, materials, procedure, results (with data table and graph), and conclusion.
Revise a paragraph written in casual language into formal scientific writing, eliminating personal pronouns, using passive voice where appropriate, and incorporating precise scientific terminology.
Create a properly formatted bibliography citing at least three scientific sources (journal article, textbook, and website) using a standard citation format.

sub_topics.name: Evaluating Scientific Information
sub_topics.short_description: Critically evaluate scientific claims, identify reliable sources, and distinguish between correlation and causation.
example_tasks: Evaluate the credibility of three different sources about a biological topic (peer-reviewed journal, news article, blog post) using criteria such as author credentials, publication date, evidence provided, and bias.

Analyze a claim that 'drinking green tea causes weight loss' by distinguishing between correlation and causation, and identifying what additional evidence would be needed to support a causal relationship.
Identify logical fallacies and unsupported claims in a pseudoscientific article and explain what makes it unscientific (lack of controls, anecdotal evidence, cherry-picking data, etc.).

grade_9_10.name: Biochemistry & Biological Molecules
grade_9_10.short_description: Study of organic compounds, macromolecules, and chemical processes essential to life. Students explore the structure and function of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids, and understand their roles in living organisms.

sub_topics.name: Atoms, Molecules, and Chemical Bonds
sub_topics.short_description: Understand atomic structure, formation of molecules, and types of chemical bonds important in biology.

sub_topics.name: Elements and Atoms in Living Things
sub_topics.short_description: Identify elements essential for life and understand atomic structure including protons, neutrons, and electrons.
example_tasks: List the six most abundant elements in living organisms (C, H, O, N, P, S) and explain why carbon is uniquely suited as the backbone of biological molecules.
Draw a simple atomic diagram for carbon showing its 6 protons, 6 neutrons, and 6 electrons arranged in appropriate energy levels.
Explain how the number of valence electrons in carbon (4) allows it to form four covalent bonds and create diverse molecular structures.

sub_topics.name: Chemical Bonds
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish between covalent, ionic, and hydrogen bonds and their importance in biological molecules.
example_tasks: Compare and contrast covalent and ionic bonds, providing one biological example of each (e.g., bonds within glucose vs. sodium chloride dissociation).
Explain why hydrogen bonds, though individually weak, are crucial for the structure and function of water, DNA, and proteins.
Draw a water molecule showing polar covalent bonds within the molecule and hydrogen bonds between adjacent water molecules, labeling partial charges (δ+ and δ-).

sub_topics.name: Properties of Water
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze water's unique properties and explain how they support life processes.
example_tasks: Explain how water's polarity leads to its properties as a universal solvent, and give three examples of biological substances that dissolve in water.
Describe how hydrogen bonding explains water's high specific heat capacity and why this property is important for maintaining stable body temperature in organisms.
Analyze how cohesion, adhesion, and surface tension in water enable capillary action in plants and explain why this is essential for water transport from roots to leaves.

sub_topics.name: Acids, Bases, and pH
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the pH scale, properties of acids and bases, and the importance of pH regulation in organisms.
example_tasks: Interpret the pH scale from 0-14, identifying which values are acidic, neutral, and basic, and place common biological fluids (stomach acid pH 2, blood pH 7.4, pancreatic juice pH 8) on the scale.
Explain what happens to the concentration of hydrogen ions (H+) when pH decreases from 7 to 5, and why this change affects enzyme function.
Describe the role of buffers in maintaining pH homeostasis in blood, and explain what could happen if blood pH drops below 7.35 (acidosis).

sub_topics.name: Carbon Compounds and Macromolecules
sub_topics.short_description: Explore the four major groups of biological macromolecules and understand their structure, function, and synthesis.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Organic Chemistry
sub_topics.short_description: Understand organic molecules, functional groups, and how monomers join to form polymers.
example_tasks: Define organic compounds and explain why carbon's bonding properties make it ideal for forming the diverse molecules found in living things.
Identify common functional groups (hydroxyl, carboxyl, amino, phosphate, carbonyl) in molecular diagrams and describe how each affects the molecule's properties.
Explain dehydration synthesis (condensation) and hydrolysis reactions, drawing a simple diagram showing how two monomers join together and how a polymer breaks apart.

sub_topics.name: Carbohydrates: Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze the structure and biological roles of monosaccharides, disaccharides, and polysaccharides.
example_tasks: Compare the structure and function of three monosaccharides: glucose (immediate energy), fructose (fruit sugar), and deoxyribose (DNA component).
Explain how two glucose molecules bond through dehydration synthesis to form maltose (a disaccharide), and identify the glycosidic linkage formed.

Compare the structure and function of starch (plant energy storage), glycogen (animal energy storage), and cellulose (plant structural support), explaining how differences in bonding affect their properties.

sub_topics.name: Lipids: Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the diverse structures of lipids including fats, phospholipids, and steroids, and their biological roles.
example_tasks: Draw a triglyceride molecule showing glycerol bonded to three fatty acid chains, and explain the difference between saturated fats (all single bonds) and unsaturated fats (contain double bonds).
Describe the structure of a phospholipid with its hydrophilic (phosphate) head and hydrophobic (fatty acid) tails, and explain how this amphipathic structure enables formation of cell membranes.
Compare the functions of different lipid types: triglycerides (energy storage), phospholipids (membrane structure), and steroids like cholesterol (membrane fluidity and hormone precursor).

sub_topics.name: Proteins: Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Understand amino acid structure, peptide bond formation, protein levels of organization, and diverse protein functions.
example_tasks: Draw the general structure of an amino acid showing the central carbon, amino group, carboxyl group, hydrogen atom, and variable R group, then explain how different R groups create 20 different amino acids.
Describe the four levels of protein structure (primary, secondary, tertiary, quaternary) with specific examples, and explain how structure determines function.

Explain protein denaturation by describing what happens to a protein's structure when exposed to heat, extreme pH, or chemical agents, and why this destroys protein function (use enzyme denaturation as an example).

sub_topics.name: Nucleic Acids: Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Explore the structure of DNA and RNA nucleotides and understand their roles in heredity and protein synthesis.
example_tasks: Draw and label a nucleotide showing its three components: five-carbon sugar (ribose or deoxyribose), phosphate group, and nitrogenous base.
Compare the structure of DNA and RNA, creating a table that shows differences in sugar type, bases present (DNA: A, T, C, G vs RNA: A, U, C, G), number of strands, and primary function.
Explain how nucleotides bond together through phosphodiester bonds to form the sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA, and how complementary base pairing (A-T and C-G) holds the two strands together.

sub_topics.name: Enzymes and Biochemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Investigate how enzymes catalyze biochemical reactions and factors that affect enzyme activity.

sub_topics.name: Enzyme Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Understand enzymes as biological catalysts with specific active sites that facilitate chemical reactions.
example_tasks: Define enzyme, substrate, active site, and product, then explain the induced fit model of enzyme action using a diagram showing substrate binding and product release.
Explain how enzymes lower activation energy to speed up reactions without being consumed, using an energy diagram to show activation energy with and without an enzyme.
Describe why enzymes are specific for certain substrates, relating the complementary shape between active site and substrate to the lock-and-key or induced fit model.

sub_topics.name: Factors Affecting Enzyme Activity
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze how temperature, pH, substrate concentration, and inhibitors affect enzyme function.
example_tasks: Interpret a graph showing enzyme activity versus temperature, identifying the optimal temperature, explaining why activity increases initially, and why it drops sharply after the optimum due to denaturation.
Explain why pepsin (a stomach enzyme) works best at pH 2 while trypsin (an intestinal enzyme) works best at pH 8, relating optimal pH to the environment where each enzyme functions.
Design an experiment to test the effect of substrate concentration on enzyme activity, predicting how reaction rate changes as substrate concentration increases until saturation is reached.

sub_topics.name: Enzyme Regulation and Inhibition
sub_topics.short_description: Understand competitive and noncompetitive inhibition and how cells regulate enzyme activity.
example_tasks: Compare competitive inhibition (inhibitor competes for active site) and noncompetitive inhibition (inhibitor binds elsewhere, changing active site shape), drawing diagrams of each.
Explain feedback inhibition using an example metabolic pathway where the end product inhibits the first enzyme in the pathway, preventing overproduction.
Analyze why many drugs and poisons work by inhibiting specific enzymes, providing one example (such as aspirin inhibiting COX enzymes or cyanide inhibiting cellular respiration enzymes).

sub_topics.name: Chemical Reactions and Energy in Living Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Examine energy transformations, ATP structure and function, and the role of chemical reactions in metabolism.

sub_topics.name: ATP: The Energy Currency
sub_topics.short_description: Understand ATP structure, how it stores and releases energy, and the ATP-ADP cycle.
example_tasks: Draw the structure of ATP (adenosine triphosphate) showing adenine, ribose, and three phosphate groups, then indicate where energy is stored in the high-energy bonds between phosphate groups.
Explain the ATP-ADP cycle: how ATP hydrolysis releases energy for cellular work and how ADP is recharged to ATP through phosphorylation using energy from food molecules.
Describe three types of cellular work powered by ATP: mechanical work (muscle contraction), transport work (active transport across membranes), and chemical work (synthesizing macromolecules).

sub_topics.name: Laws of Energy and Metabolism
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the first and second laws of thermodynamics to biological systems and understand metabolic pathways.
example_tasks: Explain the first law of thermodynamics (energy cannot be created or destroyed) using a food chain as an example showing energy transfer from sun to producers to consumers.
Describe the second law of thermodynamics (entropy increases) and explain why organisms must continually acquire energy to maintain their organized structure and perform life functions.
Distinguish between anabolic pathways (building molecules, requires energy input) and catabolic pathways (breaking down molecules, releases energy), providing two examples of each.

sub_topics.name: Coupled Reactions in Cells
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how cells couple exergonic reactions with endergonic reactions using ATP.
example_tasks: Explain how ATP hydrolysis (exergonic, releases energy) is coupled with glucose phosphorylation (endergonic, requires energy) in the first step of cellular respiration.
Describe why cells use ATP as an intermediate energy carrier rather than directly using energy from glucose for all cellular work.
Analyze a metabolic pathway diagram showing how the energy released from breaking down one molecule is captured in ATP and then used to build another molecule.

grade_9_10.name: Cell Structure & Function
grade_9_10.short_description: Exploration of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, organelles, and cellular organization. Students examine cell theory, compare cell types, and understand how organelle structure relates to function in maintaining life processes.

sub_topics.name: Cell Theory and History of Cell Biology
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the development of cell theory and contributions of key scientists to cell biology.

sub_topics.name: Development of Cell Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Learn the three principles of cell theory and the historical discoveries that led to its formulation.
example_tasks: State the three tenets of cell theory: (1) all living things are composed of cells, (2) cells are the basic unit of life, (3) all cells come from pre-existing cells.

Describe the contributions of Robert Hooke (first observed cork cells, 1665), Anton van Leeuwenhoek (observed living microorganisms), Matthias Schleiden (plants made of cells), Theodor Schwann (animals made of cells), and Rudolf Virchow (cells from cells) to cell theory.
Explain how improvements in microscope technology enabled scientists to discover cells and develop cell theory, and discuss what modern microscopes reveal that early microscopes could not.

sub_topics.name: Microscopy Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Compare different types of microscopes and their applications in studying cells.
example_tasks: Compare light microscopes and electron microscopes, including their magnification limits, resolution, whether they can view living specimens, and typical applications.
Explain the difference between transmission electron microscopy (TEM) which shows internal structures and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) which shows 3D surface details.
Calculate the size of a cell: if a cell appears 40mm long under 400x magnification, what is its actual size in micrometers? (40mm ÷ 400 = 0.1mm = 100 micrometers)

sub_topics.name: Prokaryotic Cells
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the structure and characteristics of prokaryotic cells including bacteria and archaea.

sub_topics.name: Prokaryotic Cell Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and describe the components of prokaryotic cells and their functions.
example_tasks: Draw and label a typical bacterial cell including: cell wall, plasma membrane, cytoplasm, nucleoid region (circular DNA), ribosomes, flagella, pili, and capsule.

Describe the function of each prokaryotic cell structure: cell wall (protection, shape), plasma membrane (controls entry/exit), nucleoid (contains genetic material), ribosomes (protein synthesis), flagella (movement), pili (attachment, conjugation).
Explain why prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organelles and how this affects their organization and function compared to eukaryotic cells.

sub_topics.name: Bacterial Characteristics and Diversity
sub_topics.short_description: Understand bacterial shapes, reproduction, and ecological roles.
example_tasks: Identify and sketch the three main bacterial shapes: cocci (spherical), bacilli (rod-shaped), and spirilla (spiral), and provide one example organism for each.
Explain binary fission as the method of bacterial reproduction, describing how one cell divides into two identical daughter cells and why this leads to rapid population growth.
Describe beneficial roles of bacteria in ecosystems and human life, such as nitrogen fixation in soil, decomposition of organic matter, and production of foods like yogurt and cheese.

sub_topics.name: Eukaryotic Cells
sub_topics.short_description: Explore the complex structure of eukaryotic cells found in plants, animals, fungi, and protists.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Eukaryotic Cells
sub_topics.short_description: Identify key features that distinguish eukaryotic cells from prokaryotic cells.
example_tasks: List five major differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells including presence of nucleus, membrane-bound organelles, size, DNA organization, and ribosomes.
Create a Venn diagram comparing prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, showing unique features and shared characteristics (both have DNA, ribosomes, plasma membrane, cytoplasm).
Explain the evolutionary significance of the nucleus and how compartmentalization in eukaryotic cells allows for more complex regulation and specialization.

sub_topics.name: Animal Cell Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and describe the organelles present in animal cells and their specific functions.
example_tasks: Draw and label a typical animal cell including: nucleus, nuclear envelope, nucleolus, ribosomes, rough and smooth endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, mitochondria, lysosomes, centrioles, plasma membrane, and cytoplasm.

Create a table matching each organelle to its function: nucleus (genetic control center), mitochondria (ATP production), ribosomes (protein synthesis), ER (protein and lipid synthesis/transport), Golgi (modification and packaging), lysosomes (digestion), centrioles (cell division).

Explain the endomembrane system by tracing the path of a protein from synthesis at the ribosome, through the ER, to the Golgi for modification, and finally to secretion via vesicle fusion with the plasma membrane.

sub_topics.name: Plant Cell Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Identify unique features of plant cells and compare plant and animal cell structures.
example_tasks: Draw a plant cell and label structures unique to plants: cell wall, chloroplasts, large central vacuole, and plasmodesmata, in addition to structures shared with animal cells.

Explain the function of plant-specific structures: cell wall (rigid support and protection), chloroplasts (photosynthesis), central vacuole (water storage, turgor pressure, waste storage), plasmodesmata (cell-cell communication).
Create a comparison table showing which organelles are found in plant cells only, animal cells only, or both types of cells, and explain the functional significance of the differences.

sub_topics.name: Organelles and Their Detailed Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the structure and function of each organelle and understand how they work together to maintain cell function.

sub_topics.name: Nucleus: Genetic Control Center
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the structure of the nucleus and its role in storing genetic information and controlling cell activities.
example_tasks: Describe the structure of the nucleus including: nuclear envelope (double membrane with pores), nucleoplasm, chromatin (DNA + proteins), and nucleolus (ribosome assembly site).
Explain how the nucleus controls cell activities by containing DNA that codes for proteins, and how mRNA carries genetic instructions through nuclear pores to ribosomes in the cytoplasm.
Describe the function of nuclear pores in regulating the transport of molecules between nucleus and cytoplasm, and explain what types of molecules enter and exit the nucleus.

sub_topics.name: Ribosomes: Protein Synthesis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand ribosome structure and their role in translating mRNA into proteins.
example_tasks: Describe ribosome structure (made of rRNA and proteins, composed of large and small subunits) and locations (free in cytoplasm or attached to rough ER).
Explain the difference between free ribosomes (produce proteins for use in cytoplasm) and bound ribosomes (produce proteins for secretion, insertion into membranes, or specific organelles).
Trace the process of protein synthesis: mRNA binds to ribosome, tRNA brings amino acids, ribosome links amino acids via peptide bonds, protein chain grows until stop codon is reached.

sub_topics.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish between rough and smooth ER and understand their roles in protein and lipid synthesis.
example_tasks: Compare rough ER (studded with ribosomes, synthesizes and processes proteins) and smooth ER (no ribosomes, synthesizes lipids, detoxifies drugs and poisons, stores calcium ions).
Explain how rough ER modifies proteins by folding them properly and adding carbohydrate chains (glycosylation), then packages them in vesicles for transport to Golgi.

Describe specialized functions of smooth ER in different cell types: extensive in liver cells (detoxification), muscle cells (calcium storage for contraction), and hormone-producing cells (lipid/steroid synthesis).

sub_topics.name: Golgi Apparatus
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how the Golgi modifies, sorts, and packages proteins and lipids for distribution.
example_tasks: Describe Golgi structure as a stack of flattened membrane sacs (cisternae) with a cis face (receiving side near ER) and trans face (shipping side toward plasma membrane).
Explain the Golgi's role in modifying proteins by adding or removing carbohydrates, phosphates, or lipids to finalize protein structure and function.

Trace a protein's journey: synthesized at ribosome → processed in rough ER → transported in vesicle to Golgi cis face → modified as it moves through Golgi stack → packaged in vesicle at trans face → delivered to final destination (lysosome, membrane, or secretion).

sub_topics.name: Mitochondria: Energy Production
sub_topics.short_description: Examine mitochondrial structure and understand cellular respiration and ATP production.
example_tasks: Draw and label mitochondrial structure: outer membrane, inner membrane (with cristae folds), intermembrane space, and matrix (contains enzymes, DNA, ribosomes).

Explain how mitochondria convert chemical energy in glucose to ATP through cellular respiration, identifying where different stages occur: glycolysis (cytoplasm), Krebs cycle (matrix), electron transport chain (inner membrane).

Describe evidence for the endosymbiotic theory of mitochondrial origin: mitochondria have their own circular DNA, reproduce independently via binary fission, have double membranes, and have ribosomes similar to bacteria.

sub_topics.name: Chloroplasts: Photosynthesis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand chloroplast structure and the process of converting light energy to chemical energy.
example_tasks: Draw and label chloroplast structure: outer membrane, inner membrane, thylakoids (stacked as grana), thylakoid space, stroma (fluid-filled interior), and chlorophyll (green pigment).

Explain how chloroplasts carry out photosynthesis: light reactions occur in thylakoid membranes (producing ATP and NADPH), and Calvin cycle occurs in stroma (using ATP and NADPH to synthesize glucose).

Compare chloroplasts and mitochondria in structure and function, noting their complementary roles: chloroplasts convert light energy to chemical energy (glucose), mitochondria convert chemical energy (glucose) to usable cellular energy (ATP).

sub_topics.name: Lysosomes: Cellular Digestion
sub_topics.short_description: Understand lysosome function in breaking down waste materials and cellular debris.
example_tasks: Describe lysosome structure (membrane-bound vesicles containing hydrolytic enzymes) and explain why the acidic pH inside lysosomes is necessary for enzyme function.
Explain the role of lysosomes in: digesting food particles brought in by phagocytosis, breaking down worn-out organelles (autophagy), and defending against bacteria.
Describe what happens in lysosomal storage diseases (such as Tay-Sachs disease) where defective lysosomal enzymes cannot break down certain lipids, leading to harmful accumulation.

sub_topics.name: Vacuoles: Storage and Support
sub_topics.short_description: Compare vacuoles in plant and animal cells and understand their roles.
example_tasks: Contrast the central vacuole in plant cells (large, stores water, nutrients, and wastes, maintains turgor pressure) with smaller vacuoles in animal cells (temporary storage, waste removal).
Explain how the central vacuole maintains turgor pressure: when full of water, it pushes against the cell wall, keeping the plant rigid and upright; when water is lost, the plant wilts.
Describe contractile vacuoles in freshwater protists and their function in pumping out excess water that enters the cell by osmosis to prevent bursting.

sub_topics.name: Cytoskeleton: Cellular Structure and Movement
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the components of the cytoskeleton and their roles in cell shape, support, and movement.
example_tasks: Identify the three types of cytoskeletal fibers: microfilaments (actin, thinnest, muscle contraction and cell movement), intermediate filaments (structural support), and microtubules (tubulin, thickest, cell shape and organelle movement).
Explain how microtubules function as tracks for motor proteins (kinesins and dyneins) to transport vesicles and organelles throughout the cell.

Describe the role of the cytoskeleton in cell division: microtubules form the spindle apparatus that separates chromosomes, and microfilaments form the contractile ring that pinches the cell in two during cytokinesis.

sub_topics.name: Centrioles and Cell Division
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the structure and function of centrioles in animal cell division.
example_tasks: Describe centriole structure: two cylindrical structures made of nine triplets of microtubules arranged in a circle, positioned perpendicular to each other.
Explain the role of centrioles during cell division: they migrate to opposite poles of the cell and organize the spindle fibers that pull chromosomes apart during mitosis and meiosis.
Identify that centrioles are found in animal cells and some protists but are generally absent in plant cells and fungi, which use other mechanisms to organize their spindle apparatus.

sub_topics.name: Specialized Cells and Levels of Cellular Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Examine cell specialization and how cells organize into tissues, organs, and organ systems.

sub_topics.name: Cell Specialization and Differentiation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how cells become specialized for specific functions through differentiation.
example_tasks: Define cell differentiation as the process by which cells become specialized in structure and function, and explain that all cells in an organism contain the same DNA but express different genes.

Compare three specialized cell types and relate their structure to function: red blood cells (no nucleus, biconcave shape for oxygen transport), neurons (long axons for electrical signal transmission), muscle cells (many mitochondria, contractile proteins for movement).
Explain why cell specialization is advantageous for multicellular organisms, allowing division of labor where different cells perform different functions more efficiently.

sub_topics.name: Levels of Organization in Multicellular Organisms
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the hierarchy from cells to tissues to organs to organ systems to organism.
example_tasks: List and define the five levels of organization in order: cells (basic unit), tissues (group of similar cells), organs (tissues working together), organ systems (organs working together), organism (complete living thing).
Provide an example showing all levels: cardiac muscle cells → cardiac muscle tissue → heart (organ) → cardiovascular system → human organism.
Explain how organization at each level enables increasingly complex functions that would not be possible at lower levels of organization.

sub_topics.name: Types of Animal Tissues
sub_topics.short_description: Identify the four main types of animal tissues and their functions.
example_tasks: Describe the four main animal tissue types: epithelial (covers body surfaces, lines organs), connective (supports and binds structures), muscle (movement), and nervous (transmits signals).
Match tissue types to specific examples: epithelial (skin epidermis, intestinal lining), connective (bone, blood, adipose), muscle (cardiac, smooth, skeletal), nervous (brain, spinal cord, nerves).
Explain how the structure of epithelial tissue (tightly packed cells with little extracellular space) suits its function as a protective barrier and selective barrier for absorption.

sub_topics.name: Plant Tissues and Organs
sub_topics.short_description: Identify major plant tissues and organs and understand their functions.
example_tasks: Describe three main plant tissue types: dermal tissue (protective outer covering), vascular tissue (xylem for water transport, phloem for sugar transport), and ground tissue (photosynthesis, storage, support).
Identify the main plant organs (roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruits) and describe one main function of each.
Explain how the structure of xylem cells (dead cells with thick, lignified walls and hollow centers) relates to their function in transporting water and providing structural support.

grade_9_10.name: Cell Transport & Homeostasis
grade_9_10.short_description: Mechanisms of molecular movement across membranes and cellular equilibrium. Students explore membrane structure, passive and active transport processes, and how cells maintain stable internal conditions despite external changes.

sub_topics.name: Cell Membrane Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the fluid mosaic model of membrane structure and the roles of phospholipids, proteins, and other components.

sub_topics.name: Phospholipid Bilayer
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how phospholipids arrange into a bilayer and create selective permeability.
example_tasks: Draw a phospholipid bilayer showing the hydrophilic phosphate heads facing outward toward aqueous environments and hydrophobic fatty acid tails facing inward, away from water.
Explain why the phospholipid bilayer forms spontaneously in aqueous environments due to the amphipathic nature of phospholipids (having both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions).

Describe selective permeability: small nonpolar molecules (O₂, CO₂) and small uncharged polar molecules (H₂O) can pass through easily, while large polar molecules and ions cannot pass through the hydrophobic core and require proteins.

sub_topics.name: Membrane Proteins and Their Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Identify types of membrane proteins and understand their diverse roles in transport, recognition, and signaling.
example_tasks: Distinguish between integral proteins (embedded in membrane, often spanning both layers) and peripheral proteins (loosely attached to membrane surface), providing examples of each.

Describe six major functions of membrane proteins: transport (channels and carriers), enzymatic activity, signal transduction (receptors), cell-cell recognition (glycoproteins), intercellular joining (adhesion proteins), and attachment to cytoskeleton.

Explain how channel proteins and carrier proteins both transport substances but differ: channels form pores for specific ions to pass through, while carriers bind to molecules and change shape to move them across.

sub_topics.name: Fluid Mosaic Model
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the dynamic nature of the cell membrane with proteins floating in the phospholipid bilayer.
example_tasks: Explain why the membrane is described as 'fluid': phospholipids and proteins can move laterally within their layer, giving the membrane flexibility and allowing it to self-repair.
Explain why the membrane is described as a 'mosaic': it contains a variety of proteins, cholesterol, and carbohydrates scattered throughout like tiles in a mosaic pattern.

Describe the role of cholesterol in animal cell membranes: at body temperature, cholesterol restrains phospholipid movement (reduces fluidity); at cool temperatures, it prevents tight packing (maintains fluidity).

sub_topics.name: Carbohydrates in the Cell Membrane
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the role of glycoproteins and glycolipids in cell recognition and identification.
example_tasks: Define glycoproteins (proteins with attached carbohydrate chains) and glycolipids (lipids with attached carbohydrate chains), noting that they are found on the external surface of the membrane.
Explain how carbohydrate markers function in cell-cell recognition, such as identifying self vs. foreign cells in the immune response, or enabling sperm to recognize an egg cell.
Describe how blood type is determined by different carbohydrate markers on red blood cells: Type A has A antigens, Type B has B antigens, Type AB has both, Type O has neither.

sub_topics.name: Passive Transport Mechanisms
sub_topics.short_description: Examine transport processes that do not require cellular energy, including diffusion, osmosis, and facilitated diffusion.

sub_topics.name: Simple Diffusion
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the movement of molecules from high to low concentration without energy or protein assistance.
example_tasks: Define diffusion as the net movement of particles from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration until equilibrium is reached, driven by random molecular motion.
Explain why diffusion is considered passive transport: it does not require cellular energy (ATP) because molecules move down their concentration gradient.

Predict the direction of diffusion in various scenarios: if oxygen concentration is high in the lungs and low in the blood, oxygen will diffuse from lungs into blood; if CO₂ is high in tissues and low in blood, CO₂ diffuses from tissues into blood.

sub_topics.name: Factors Affecting Rate of Diffusion
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze how temperature, concentration gradient, and molecular size affect diffusion rate.
example_tasks: Explain how increasing temperature increases diffusion rate because molecules move faster with more kinetic energy.
Describe how a steeper concentration gradient (larger difference between high and low concentration) increases the rate of diffusion.
Explain why smaller molecules diffuse faster than larger molecules, and why this affects which substances can cross the membrane by simple diffusion (O₂ and CO₂ vs. glucose and proteins).

sub_topics.name: Osmosis: Diffusion of Water
sub_topics.short_description: Understand water movement across selectively permeable membranes from areas of low to high solute concentration.
example_tasks: Define osmosis as the diffusion of water across a selectively permeable membrane from an area of lower solute concentration (higher water concentration) to an area of higher solute concentration (lower water concentration).

Predict the direction of osmosis: if a cell with 10% solute is placed in a solution with 5% solute, water will move from the solution (hypotonic) into the cell because water moves toward higher solute concentration.
Explain why osmosis is important for cells: it regulates water balance, maintains cell volume and shape, and can cause cells to swell or shrink depending on the surrounding solution.

sub_topics.name: Tonicity and Effects on Cells
sub_topics.short_description: Compare isotonic, hypotonic, and hypertonic solutions and predict their effects on cells.
example_tasks: Define three types of solutions relative to a cell: isotonic (equal solute concentration, no net water movement), hypotonic (lower solute concentration, water enters cell), hypertonic (higher solute concentration, water leaves cell).
Predict what happens to an animal cell (no cell wall) in each solution: isotonic (stays the same), hypotonic (swells and may burst/lyse), hypertonic (shrinks/crenates).

Predict what happens to a plant cell (has cell wall) in each solution: isotonic (flaccid, no turgor pressure), hypotonic (turgid, firm from turgor pressure), hypertonic (plasmolyzed, membrane pulls away from cell wall).

sub_topics.name: Facilitated Diffusion
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how transport proteins help large or charged molecules cross the membrane down their concentration gradient.
example_tasks: Define facilitated diffusion as passive transport using channel or carrier proteins to help substances cross the membrane down their concentration gradient without using ATP.

Compare channel proteins (provide a hydrophilic tunnel for specific ions or water to pass through) and carrier proteins (bind to molecule, change shape, release molecule on other side) as two types of facilitated diffusion.

Explain why glucose requires facilitated diffusion to enter cells: glucose is a large polar molecule that cannot pass through the hydrophobic phospholipid bilayer, so it needs carrier proteins (GLUT transporters) to cross the membrane.

sub_topics.name: Aquaporins: Water Channel Proteins
sub_topics.short_description: Understand specialized channel proteins that facilitate rapid water transport across membranes.
example_tasks: Describe aquaporins as channel proteins that form pores specifically for water molecules, greatly increasing the rate of osmosis in cells that need rapid water transport.
Explain where aquaporins are especially important: kidney cells (water reabsorption), red blood cells (rapid water exchange), and plant root cells (water uptake from soil).

Compare water movement with and without aquaporins: some water can pass through the phospholipid bilayer, but aquaporins allow much faster water transport (up to 3 billion molecules per second per channel).

sub_topics.name: Active Transport Mechanisms
sub_topics.short_description: Explore transport processes that require cellular energy to move substances against their concentration gradient.

sub_topics.name: Active Transport and Protein Pumps
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how cells use ATP to move molecules from low to high concentration via protein pumps.
example_tasks: Define active transport as the movement of substances across a membrane against their concentration gradient (from low to high concentration), requiring energy from ATP and carrier proteins called pumps.

Explain why active transport is necessary: it allows cells to maintain concentration gradients different from their surroundings, accumulate nutrients even when they're rare outside the cell, and remove wastes even when they're concentrated inside.

Compare passive transport and active transport using a table showing: direction of movement (down gradient vs. up gradient), energy requirement (no ATP vs. requires ATP), and protein involvement (sometimes vs. always).

sub_topics.name: Sodium-Potassium Pump
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the most important active transport protein in animal cells and its role in maintaining electrochemical gradients.
example_tasks: Describe the sodium-potassium pump cycle: (1) 3 Na⁺ ions from cytoplasm bind to pump, (2) ATP phosphorylates pump causing shape change, (3) Na⁺ released outside cell, (4) 2 K⁺ from outside bind to pump, (5) phosphate released, pump returns to original shape, (6) K⁺ released into cytoplasm.

Explain why the sodium-potassium pump is essential for nerve and muscle cells: it maintains high K⁺ inside and high Na⁺ outside, creating an electrochemical gradient necessary for nerve impulse transmission and muscle contraction.
Calculate the energy cost: if one ATP is hydrolyzed per pump cycle, and a cell runs thousands of pump cycles per second, explain why this pump can consume 25-30% of a cell's total ATP production.

sub_topics.name: Other Types of Active Transport
sub_topics.short_description: Explore additional active transport mechanisms including calcium pumps, proton pumps, and cotransport.
example_tasks: Describe calcium pumps that actively transport Ca²⁺ out of the cytoplasm (into ER/SR or out of cell), maintaining low cytoplasmic calcium concentration important for cell signaling and muscle relaxation.
Explain proton pumps that transport H⁺ ions to create pH gradients, such as in stomach cells (creating acidic stomach environment) and in plant cells (acidifying cell walls for growth).

Define cotransport (secondary active transport): using the concentration gradient of one substance (established by active transport) to drive transport of another substance against its gradient, such as glucose-sodium cotransport in intestinal cells.

sub_topics.name: Bulk Transport: Endocytosis and Exocytosis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how cells transport large molecules, particles, or bulk quantities of substances using vesicles.

sub_topics.name: Endocytosis: Bringing Materials Into the Cell
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how cells engulf external materials by forming vesicles from the plasma membrane.
example_tasks: Define endocytosis as the process of taking materials into the cell by forming vesicles from the plasma membrane, requiring energy from ATP.

Distinguish between three types of endocytosis: phagocytosis ('cell eating,' engulfing large particles like bacteria), pinocytosis ('cell drinking,' taking in droplets of extracellular fluid), and receptor-mediated endocytosis (specific uptake triggered by ligand binding to receptors).

Describe receptor-mediated endocytosis using cholesterol uptake as an example: LDL cholesterol binds to specific receptors, receptor-ligand complexes cluster in coated pits, membrane invaginates forming coated vesicle, vesicle fuses with lysosome where cholesterol is released.

sub_topics.name: Exocytosis: Secreting Materials From the Cell
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how cells package and export proteins and other molecules using secretory vesicles.
example_tasks: Define exocytosis as the process of releasing materials from the cell by fusion of secretory vesicles with the plasma membrane, requiring energy from ATP.

Describe the process: substances are packaged in vesicles by the Golgi apparatus, vesicles move to the plasma membrane along microtubules, vesicle membrane fuses with plasma membrane, contents are released outside the cell.

Provide examples of exocytosis: secretion of digestive enzymes from pancreatic cells, release of neurotransmitters from nerve cells, secretion of hormones from endocrine glands, and release of mucus from goblet cells.

sub_topics.name: Bulk Transport in Immune Function
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how white blood cells use phagocytosis to destroy pathogens.
example_tasks: Describe how macrophages and neutrophils use phagocytosis to engulf bacteria and viruses: they extend pseudopods around the pathogen, enclose it in a phagosome (vesicle), fuse the phagosome with a lysosome, and digest the pathogen with lysosomal enzymes.
Explain how phagocytosis is part of the immune response and provides protection against infection.

Compare phagocytosis of pathogens to receptor-mediated endocytosis of nutrients, noting that phagocytosis typically involves much larger particles and may be triggered by recognition of foreign surface markers.

sub_topics.name: Homeostasis and Cellular Regulation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how cells and organisms maintain stable internal conditions through feedback mechanisms and regulation of transport.

sub_topics.name: Concept of Homeostasis
sub_topics.short_description: Define homeostasis and understand its importance for survival of cells and organisms.
example_tasks: Define homeostasis as the maintenance of stable internal conditions despite changes in the external environment, involving the regulation of variables such as temperature, pH, water balance, and ion concentrations.

Explain why homeostasis is essential: enzymes and cellular processes function optimally only within narrow ranges of temperature, pH, and salt concentration; deviations can denature proteins and disrupt metabolism.

Provide examples of homeostasis at different levels: cellular (maintaining cytoplasmic ion concentrations), tissue (maintaining extracellular fluid composition), and organismal (maintaining body temperature and blood glucose levels).

sub_topics.name: Negative and Positive Feedback
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish between negative feedback (maintaining stability) and positive feedback (amplifying changes).
example_tasks: Define negative feedback as a response that counteracts the initial stimulus, returning a variable to its set point, and explain that most homeostatic mechanisms use negative feedback (example: body temperature regulation).

Describe a negative feedback loop for temperature regulation: when body temperature rises above 37°C, thermoreceptors detect change, hypothalamus triggers sweating and vasodilation, body temperature decreases back to set point, response stops.

Define positive feedback as a response that amplifies the initial stimulus, moving the variable farther from its set point, and provide an example: during childbirth, uterine contractions stimulate oxytocin release, which causes stronger contractions, amplifying until birth occurs.

sub_topics.name: Osmoregulation in Cells and Organisms
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how cells and organisms regulate water and solute balance.
example_tasks: Explain osmoregulation in freshwater protists: water constantly enters by osmosis (environment is hypotonic), contractile vacuoles collect and pump out excess water to prevent cell bursting.

Describe osmoregulation in plant cells: cell wall prevents bursting in hypotonic environments, allowing cells to become turgid which provides structural support; in hypertonic environments, plasmolysis occurs as water leaves the cell.

Compare osmoregulation challenges for freshwater fish (water enters, must excrete dilute urine) versus saltwater fish (water leaves, must drink seawater and actively excrete excess salts through gills).

sub_topics.name: Ion Regulation and Electrochemical Gradients
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how cells maintain specific ion concentrations and electrical potentials across membranes.
example_tasks: Explain how cells maintain different ion concentrations inside and outside: sodium-potassium pumps actively transport ions, creating gradients (high K⁺ and low Na⁺ inside, opposite outside).

Describe the resting membrane potential in nerve cells (approximately -70 mV, inside negative relative to outside) and explain how it results from unequal ion distribution and selective membrane permeability.

Explain why maintaining ion gradients is important: they provide potential energy for cotransport, generate electrical signals in nerve and muscle cells, and drive ATP synthesis in mitochondria and chloroplasts.

grade_9_10.name: Cellular Energy & Metabolism
grade_9_10.short_description: Photosynthesis, cellular respiration, and ATP production pathways. Students explore how cells capture, convert, and use energy to power life processes through complementary metabolic pathways.

sub_topics.name: Overview of Cellular Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the relationship between photosynthesis and cellular respiration and the flow of energy through living systems.

sub_topics.name: Autotrophs and Heterotrophs
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish between organisms that produce their own food and those that consume other organisms.
example_tasks: Define autotrophs (producers) as organisms that make their own food from inorganic substances using light energy (photosynthesis) or chemical energy (chemosynthesis), and provide examples: plants, algae, cyanobacteria.

Define heterotrophs (consumers) as organisms that obtain energy by consuming other organisms, and classify types: herbivores (plant eaters), carnivores (meat eaters), omnivores (both), decomposers (break down dead matter).

Explain the relationship between autotrophs and heterotrophs in ecosystems: autotrophs capture energy from the sun and convert it to chemical energy in organic molecules, which heterotrophs then consume to obtain energy.

sub_topics.name: Photosynthesis and Cellular Respiration as Complementary Processes
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how photosynthesis and cellular respiration are opposite reactions that cycle matter and energy.
example_tasks: Write the overall equations showing how photosynthesis and cellular respiration are reverse processes: Photosynthesis: 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + light energy → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂; Cellular Respiration: C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ → 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + ATP.
Explain how these processes cycle carbon and oxygen: photosynthesis removes CO₂ from atmosphere and releases O₂; cellular respiration consumes O₂ and releases CO₂, maintaining atmospheric balance.

Describe how energy flows through these processes: solar energy is captured and stored in chemical bonds (glucose) during photosynthesis; that stored energy is released and converted to ATP during cellular respiration.

sub_topics.name: Oxidation-Reduction (Redox) Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand electron transfer reactions that drive energy metabolism in cells.
example_tasks: Define oxidation as the loss of electrons (or hydrogen) and reduction as the gain of electrons (or hydrogen), using the mnemonic 'OIL RIG' (Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain).

Explain how cellular respiration involves oxidation of glucose (glucose loses electrons) and reduction of oxygen (oxygen gains electrons), with energy released as electrons move to lower energy states.

Describe the role of electron carriers NAD⁺ and FAD in metabolism: they accept electrons (becoming NADH and FADH₂) during glucose breakdown and deliver them to the electron transport chain for ATP production.

sub_topics.name: Photosynthesis
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how plants and other autotrophs convert light energy into chemical energy stored in glucose.

sub_topics.name: Overview and Importance of Photosynthesis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand photosynthesis as the foundation of most food chains and the source of atmospheric oxygen.
example_tasks: Write and explain the overall equation for photosynthesis: 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + light energy → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂, identifying reactants (inputs) and products (outputs).

Explain why photosynthesis is essential for life on Earth: it produces oxygen for aerobic respiration, creates organic molecules that form the base of food chains, and removes CO₂ from the atmosphere.
Describe where photosynthesis occurs: in chloroplasts of plant cells and algae, specifically in thylakoid membranes (light reactions) and stroma (Calvin cycle).

sub_topics.name: Light-Dependent Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how light energy is captured and converted to chemical energy (ATP and NADPH) in thylakoid membranes.
example_tasks: Describe the location and overall purpose of light reactions: occur in thylakoid membranes, use light energy to split water molecules, produce ATP and NADPH, and release O₂ as a byproduct.

Explain the role of chlorophyll and other pigments: chlorophyll absorbs light energy (primarily red and blue wavelengths, reflects green), becomes excited, and transfers energy to electrons which enter the electron transport chain.

Trace the path of electrons in light reactions: light excites electrons in Photosystem II, electrons move through electron transport chain (producing ATP by chemiosmosis), light excites electrons again in Photosystem I, electrons ultimately reduce NADP⁺ to NADPH.

sub_topics.name: Photolysis and Oxygen Production
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how water molecules are split to provide electrons and produce oxygen gas.
example_tasks: Define photolysis as the light-dependent splitting of water molecules: 2H₂O → 4H⁺ + 4e⁻ + O₂, occurring in Photosystem II.
Explain why photolysis is necessary: it replaces the electrons that chlorophyll loses when excited by light, allowing the light reactions to continue.

Describe the fate of products from photolysis: electrons replace those lost from chlorophyll, H⁺ ions contribute to the proton gradient used to make ATP, and O₂ is released as a waste product (which we breathe).

sub_topics.name: Chemiosmosis and ATP Synthesis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how the proton gradient across thylakoid membrane drives ATP production.
example_tasks: Explain how chemiosmosis works in chloroplasts: as electrons move through the electron transport chain, H⁺ ions are pumped from stroma into thylakoid space, creating a concentration gradient.

Describe how ATP synthase uses the proton gradient: H⁺ ions flow back through ATP synthase channels from thylakoid space to stroma (down their gradient), and the energy released drives phosphorylation of ADP to ATP.

Compare chemiosmosis in chloroplasts and mitochondria: both use proton gradients and ATP synthase, but in chloroplasts H⁺ concentration is higher in thylakoid space, while in mitochondria H⁺ is higher in intermembrane space.

sub_topics.name: Calvin Cycle (Light-Independent Reactions)
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how CO₂ is fixed and reduced to form glucose using ATP and NADPH from light reactions.
example_tasks: Describe the location and overall purpose of the Calvin cycle: occurs in the stroma of chloroplasts, uses CO₂, ATP, and NADPH to synthesize glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆).

Outline the three main stages of the Calvin cycle: (1) Carbon fixation - CO₂ combines with RuBP (5-carbon) via enzyme RuBisCO to form 3-carbon molecules; (2) Reduction - ATP and NADPH reduce the 3-carbon molecules to G3P (glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate); (3) Regeneration - most G3P regenerates RuBP using ATP, while some G3P exits to form glucose.

Explain the cycle's requirements: for every 6 CO₂ molecules fixed, 18 ATP and 12 NADPH are consumed to produce 1 glucose molecule (C₆H₁₂O₆), showing the connection to light reactions that produce these energy carriers.

sub_topics.name: Factors Affecting Rate of Photosynthesis
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze how environmental variables influence photosynthetic rate.
example_tasks: Explain how light intensity affects photosynthesis: as light increases, photosynthetic rate increases until a saturation point where other factors become limiting.
Describe how CO₂ concentration affects photosynthesis: increasing CO₂ increases rate until saturation; typical atmospheric CO₂ (0.04%) is often limiting for plants.

Analyze how temperature affects photosynthesis: rate increases with temperature (faster enzyme activity) until optimal temperature is reached, then decreases sharply due to enzyme denaturation (usually 35-40°C for most plants).

sub_topics.name: Cellular Respiration
sub_topics.short_description: Explore how cells break down glucose to produce ATP through glycolysis, Krebs cycle, and electron transport chain.

sub_topics.name: Overview of Cellular Respiration
sub_topics.short_description: Understand cellular respiration as the process of extracting energy from glucose to produce ATP.
example_tasks: Write and explain the overall equation for cellular respiration: C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ → 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + ATP (approximately 36-38 ATP), identifying which molecule is oxidized (glucose) and which is reduced (oxygen).
Explain why cellular respiration is necessary: breaking down glucose releases energy stored in its chemical bonds, which cells capture in ATP for use in cellular work.

List the three main stages of aerobic cellular respiration and where each occurs: (1) Glycolysis (cytoplasm), (2) Krebs cycle/Citric acid cycle (mitochondrial matrix), (3) Electron transport chain and chemiosmosis (inner mitochondrial membrane).

sub_topics.name: Glycolysis
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the first stage of cellular respiration where glucose is split into pyruvate molecules.
example_tasks: Describe the inputs and outputs of glycolysis: 1 glucose (6-carbon) + 2 ATP (for activation) + 2 NAD⁺ → 2 pyruvate (3-carbon each) + 4 ATP (net gain of 2 ATP) + 2 NADH.
Explain that glycolysis occurs in the cytoplasm and does not require oxygen (anaerobic process), so it occurs in both aerobic and anaerobic respiration.

Outline the process: glucose is phosphorylated (using 2 ATP), splits into two 3-carbon molecules, these are oxidized (producing 2 NADH), and phosphorylated again (producing 4 ATP by substrate-level phosphorylation), resulting in 2 pyruvate molecules.

sub_topics.name: Krebs Cycle (Citric Acid Cycle)
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how pyruvate is completely oxidized to CO₂ while producing electron carriers and some ATP.
example_tasks: Describe the preparatory step before Krebs cycle: pyruvate (3-carbon) from glycolysis enters mitochondria, is oxidized to acetyl (2-carbon), producing CO₂ and NADH, then acetyl combines with Coenzyme A forming acetyl-CoA.

Outline the Krebs cycle: acetyl-CoA (2-carbon) combines with oxaloacetate (4-carbon) forming citrate (6-carbon), which is gradually oxidized through a series of reactions, releasing 2 CO₂, generating 3 NADH, 1 FADH₂, and 1 ATP per turn.

Calculate total output from one glucose molecule: since 2 pyruvate enter from glycolysis, the Krebs cycle turns twice, producing 6 NADH, 2 FADH₂, 2 ATP, and 4 CO₂ (all carbon from glucose is now released as CO₂).

sub_topics.name: Electron Transport Chain
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how electrons from NADH and FADH₂ pass through protein complexes, establishing a proton gradient.
example_tasks: Describe the structure and location: electron transport chain consists of protein complexes embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane (cristae), positioned between matrix and intermembrane space.

Explain the process: NADH and FADH₂ donate electrons to the chain, electrons pass through a series of carriers (losing energy at each step), energy is used to pump H⁺ from matrix to intermembrane space, electrons finally combine with O₂ and H⁺ to form H₂O.

Explain why oxygen is called the 'final electron acceptor': oxygen is the last molecule to receive electrons at the end of the chain; without oxygen, electrons back up, the chain stops, and ATP production halts (this is why we need to breathe oxygen).

sub_topics.name: Oxidative Phosphorylation and ATP Synthesis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how chemiosmosis uses the proton gradient to drive massive ATP production.
example_tasks: Explain chemiosmosis in mitochondria: H⁺ ions pumped into intermembrane space create a concentration gradient, H⁺ flows back through ATP synthase (down gradient) into the matrix, and the energy released drives ATP synthesis from ADP + Pi.

Calculate approximate ATP yield: electron transport and chemiosmosis produce about 26-28 ATP (from NADH and FADH₂), glycolysis produces 2 ATP, Krebs cycle produces 2 ATP, for a total of approximately 30-32 ATP per glucose (some sources say up to 36-38 depending on efficiency).
Explain why this stage produces the most ATP: the potential energy in the proton gradient (created by oxidation of many NADH and FADH₂ molecules) is efficiently converted to ATP through chemiosmosis.

sub_topics.name: Anaerobic Respiration and Fermentation
sub_topics.short_description: Examine alternative pathways that allow glycolysis to continue without oxygen by regenerating NAD⁺.
example_tasks: Explain why fermentation is necessary in absence of oxygen: glycolysis produces NADH but requires NAD⁺ to continue; without oxygen, electron transport chain cannot regenerate NAD⁺, so fermentation regenerates NAD⁺ from NADH, allowing glycolysis to continue producing ATP.
Compare lactic acid fermentation (in muscle cells during intense exercise): pyruvate + NADH → lactate + NAD⁺, producing no additional ATP but regenerating NAD⁺ for continued glycolysis.

Compare alcoholic fermentation (in yeast and some bacteria): pyruvate → CO₂ + acetaldehyde; then acetaldehyde + NADH → ethanol + NAD⁺, used in baking (CO₂ makes bread rise) and brewing (ethanol production).

sub_topics.name: Comparing and Connecting Metabolic Pathways
sub_topics.short_description: Synthesize understanding of how photosynthesis and cellular respiration complement each other and connect to broader biological concepts.

sub_topics.name: Energy Transformations in Living Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Trace energy flow from sun through photosynthesis to cellular respiration.
example_tasks: Create a diagram showing energy flow: solar energy → captured by chlorophyll → converted to chemical energy in glucose bonds (photosynthesis) → released and captured as ATP (cellular respiration) → used for cellular work → some lost as heat at each step.

Explain how photosynthesis and respiration illustrate the laws of thermodynamics: first law (energy conserved, transformed from light to chemical to usable cellular energy), second law (energy conversions not 100% efficient, some energy lost as heat, increasing entropy).

Describe the complementary nature: photosynthesis is endergonic (requires energy input), builds complex molecules (anabolic), and reduces CO₂; respiration is exergonic (releases energy), breaks down molecules (catabolic), and oxidizes glucose.

sub_topics.name: Carbon and Oxygen Cycles
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how photosynthesis and respiration drive global cycling of carbon and oxygen.
example_tasks: Trace the path of carbon atoms: CO₂ in atmosphere → fixed into glucose during photosynthesis → stored in plant tissues → consumed by heterotrophs → released as CO₂ during cellular respiration → returns to atmosphere.

Trace the path of oxygen atoms: H₂O split during photosynthesis → O₂ released to atmosphere → consumed during cellular respiration (combines with electrons and H⁺) → forms H₂O → potentially used again in photosynthesis.

Explain how disrupting this balance affects Earth's systems: excess CO₂ from burning fossil fuels (ancient photosynthesis products) faster than photosynthesis can remove it leads to increased atmospheric CO₂ and climate change; deforestation reduces photosynthetic organisms, further imbalancing the cycle.

sub_topics.name: Evolutionary Perspective on Metabolism
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the evolutionary development of photosynthesis and respiration and their impact on Earth.
example_tasks: Explain that early Earth's atmosphere lacked oxygen and early organisms performed anaerobic metabolism (fermentation), which produces only 2 ATP per glucose.
Describe how evolution of photosynthesis in cyanobacteria (about 2.5 billion years ago) gradually added O₂ to the atmosphere, changing Earth's chemistry and making aerobic respiration possible.

Explain the evolutionary advantage of aerobic respiration: yields about 30-32 ATP per glucose (versus 2 ATP from fermentation), allowing organisms to be more active and complex; this drove the evolution of diverse, complex multicellular life.

sub_topics.name: Alternative Energy Pathways
sub_topics.short_description: Explore how cells can metabolize other molecules besides glucose for energy.
example_tasks: Explain how proteins can be used for energy: proteins are broken down into amino acids, amino groups removed (deamination), remaining carbon skeletons converted to intermediates that enter glycolysis or Krebs cycle at various points.

Explain how lipids (fats) can be used for energy: triglycerides broken down to glycerol and fatty acids; glycerol enters glycolysis; fatty acids broken down through beta-oxidation into acetyl-CoA units that enter Krebs cycle (fats yield more ATP per gram than carbohydrates).

Describe metabolic flexibility: cells can use carbohydrates, fats, or proteins for energy depending on availability; during starvation, body preferentially breaks down fats, then proteins; brain normally requires glucose but can adapt to use ketone bodies from fat metabolism.

grade_9_10.name: Cell Division & Cell Cycle
grade_9_10.short_description: Mitosis, meiosis, and regulation of cell reproduction. Students explore how cells replicate their DNA, divide to produce new cells for growth and repair, and create gametes for sexual reproduction.

sub_topics.name: The Cell Cycle
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the stages cells go through from formation to division, including interphase and mitotic phase.

sub_topics.name: Interphase: Cell Growth and DNA Replication
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the three phases of interphase where cells grow, carry out normal functions, and replicate DNA.
example_tasks: Describe the three sub-phases of interphase: G1 (gap 1: cell growth, normal metabolism, protein synthesis), S (synthesis: DNA replication, chromosomes duplicated), and G2 (gap 2: continued growth, preparation for division, organelle duplication).

Explain why DNA replication occurs during S phase: each daughter cell needs a complete copy of genetic information, so before division, the cell must duplicate all chromosomes (DNA goes from 46 to 92 chromatids in human cells).

Describe what happens to chromosome number during S phase: the number of chromosomes stays the same (46 in humans) but each chromosome now consists of two identical sister chromatids joined at the centromere.

sub_topics.name: Cell Cycle Regulation and Checkpoints
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how the cell cycle is controlled by checkpoints to ensure accurate division.
example_tasks: Identify three major checkpoints: G1 checkpoint (cell large enough? nutrients available? DNA damaged?), G2 checkpoint (DNA replicated correctly? cell ready for mitosis?), M checkpoint (chromosomes attached to spindle properly?).

Explain what happens if a cell fails a checkpoint: the cycle is halted, allowing time for repairs; if damage cannot be repaired, the cell may undergo apoptosis (programmed cell death) to prevent passing on mutations.

Describe the role of cyclins and CDKs (cyclin-dependent kinases): cyclins are proteins whose levels rise and fall during the cell cycle; when cyclins bind to CDKs, they activate them to phosphorylate target proteins that drive the cell through checkpoints.

sub_topics.name: Cancer and Loss of Cell Cycle Control
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how mutations in cell cycle control genes can lead to uncontrolled cell division.
example_tasks: Define cancer as a disease caused by uncontrolled cell division resulting from mutations in genes that regulate the cell cycle, leading to formation of tumors (masses of abnormal cells).

Distinguish between proto-oncogenes (normal genes that promote cell division; when mutated become oncogenes that cause excessive division) and tumor suppressor genes (genes that slow division or promote apoptosis; when mutated lose protective function, examples: p53, RB).

Explain how cancer typically requires multiple mutations: one mutation is usually not enough; cells must accumulate several mutations affecting both oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes before becoming cancerous, which is why cancer risk increases with age.

sub_topics.name: Mitosis: Cell Division for Growth and Repair
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the process of nuclear division that produces two identical daughter cells.

sub_topics.name: Purpose and Importance of Mitosis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand why organisms need mitosis for growth, repair, and asexual reproduction.
example_tasks: List three main purposes of mitosis: (1) growth (increasing number of cells in multicellular organisms), (2) repair and replacement (replacing damaged or dead cells), (3) asexual reproduction (producing genetically identical offspring in some organisms).
Explain why daughter cells must be genetically identical to parent cell: body (somatic) cells need the same genetic instructions to maintain proper structure and function of tissues and organs.
Provide examples of mitosis in humans: skin cells dividing to replace dead surface cells, blood cell production in bone marrow, healing of cuts and wounds, growth during childhood and adolescence.

sub_topics.name: Phases of Mitosis
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and describe the events occurring in each phase: prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase.
example_tasks: Describe prophase: chromatin condenses into visible chromosomes (each consisting of two sister chromatids joined at centromere), nuclear envelope breaks down, centrioles move to opposite poles, spindle fibers begin forming.

Describe metaphase: chromosomes align at the cell's equator (metaphase plate), spindle fibers from both poles attach to the centromere of each chromosome at kinetochores, cell checks that all chromosomes are properly attached before proceeding.

Describe anaphase and telophase: anaphase - sister chromatids separate and move to opposite poles pulled by spindle fibers, cell elongates; telophase - chromosomes decondense back to chromatin, nuclear envelopes reform around each set of chromosomes, spindle disassembles.

sub_topics.name: Cytokinesis: Division of Cytoplasm
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how the cytoplasm divides to create two separate daughter cells.
example_tasks: Describe cytokinesis in animal cells: a cleavage furrow forms (indentation around cell's equator), contractile ring of actin microfilaments pinches cell membrane inward, cell splits into two daughter cells.

Describe cytokinesis in plant cells: cell plate forms at the equator from vesicles containing cell wall materials, plate grows outward to meet existing cell wall, resulting in two cells each with its own cell wall.
