Explain why plant and animal cells divide differently: plant cells have rigid cell walls that cannot be pinched inward, so they must build a new wall (cell plate) between the two daughter cells.

sub_topics.name: Chromosome Numbers Through Mitosis
sub_topics.short_description: Track how chromosome number remains constant through mitotic division.
example_tasks: Define diploid (2n) as having two sets of chromosomes (one from each parent), and identify that human somatic cells are diploid with 46 chromosomes (23 pairs).

Trace chromosome number through mitosis in humans: parent cell has 46 chromosomes → after S phase has 46 chromosomes (each consisting of 2 sister chromatids = 92 chromatids total) → after mitosis each daughter cell has 46 chromosomes (single chromatids).
Explain why mitosis is called 'equational division': the chromosome number stays the same (2n → 2n), producing daughter cells genetically identical to parent cell.

sub_topics.name: Meiosis: Cell Division for Sexual Reproduction
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the specialized division process that produces gametes with half the chromosome number.

sub_topics.name: Purpose and Importance of Meiosis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand why sexually reproducing organisms need meiosis to produce gametes.
example_tasks: Explain the main purpose of meiosis: to produce gametes (sex cells: sperm and eggs) with half the chromosome number (haploid, n) so that when fertilization occurs, the diploid number (2n) is restored in offspring.

Explain what would happen without meiosis: if diploid cells (46 chromosomes in humans) fused during fertilization, offspring would have double the chromosomes (92), and this would double with each generation, which is not viable.
Describe where meiosis occurs: in specialized organs called gonads (testes in males produce sperm, ovaries in females produce eggs).

sub_topics.name: Overview of Meiosis: Two Divisions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that meiosis consists of two consecutive divisions producing four haploid cells.
example_tasks: Outline the two divisions: Meiosis I (reductional division: homologous chromosomes separate, diploid → haploid) and Meiosis II (equational division: sister chromatids separate, similar to mitosis).
Compare the outcome: one diploid parent cell (2n) produces four haploid daughter cells (n), each genetically unique (versus mitosis which produces two identical diploid cells).

Explain how meiosis reduces chromosome number by half: humans start with 46 chromosomes (23 pairs) → after meiosis I have 23 chromosomes (still doubled as sister chromatids) → after meiosis II have 23 single chromosomes (haploid gametes).

sub_topics.name: Meiosis I: Separation of Homologous Chromosomes
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the stages of the first meiotic division where homologous pairs separate.
example_tasks: Describe Prophase I (longest phase): homologous chromosomes pair up (synapsis) forming tetrads (bivalents), crossing over occurs between nonsister chromatids exchanging genetic material, nuclear envelope breaks down, spindle forms.
Describe Metaphase I: tetrads (pairs of homologous chromosomes) line up at the equator, spindle fibers attach to centromeres, orientation of each pair is random (independent assortment).

Describe Anaphase I and Telophase I: homologous chromosomes (not sister chromatids) separate and move to opposite poles, each pole receives one chromosome from each homologous pair (now haploid), nuclear envelopes may reform, cytokinesis produces two haploid cells (each chromosome still consists of two sister chromatids).

sub_topics.name: Meiosis II: Separation of Sister Chromatids
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the second meiotic division that resembles mitosis.
example_tasks: Explain that Meiosis II is similar to mitosis but starts with haploid cells: no S phase occurs between Meiosis I and II (DNA not replicated again).

Describe the phases: Prophase II (chromosomes condense, spindle forms), Metaphase II (chromosomes line up at equator), Anaphase II (sister chromatids separate and move to opposite poles), Telophase II (nuclear envelopes reform, cytokinesis occurs).
State the final result: four haploid daughter cells, each with single-chromatid chromosomes, each genetically unique due to crossing over and independent assortment.

sub_topics.name: Crossing Over and Genetic Recombination
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how exchange of DNA segments between homologous chromosomes increases genetic diversity.
example_tasks: Define crossing over: during Prophase I, nonsister chromatids of homologous chromosomes exchange equivalent segments of DNA at points called chiasmata, creating new combinations of alleles.
Explain the significance: crossing over produces recombinant chromosomes that have a mix of alleles from both parents, increasing genetic variation in gametes and ultimately in offspring.

Describe how crossing over differs from independent assortment: crossing over shuffles alleles within chromosomes, while independent assortment shuffles whole chromosomes; both contribute to genetic diversity but through different mechanisms.

sub_topics.name: Independent Assortment
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how random orientation of chromosome pairs during Meiosis I creates genetic variation.
example_tasks: Explain independent assortment: during Metaphase I, each pair of homologous chromosomes lines up randomly (maternal or paternal chromosome can face either pole), and they separate independently of other pairs.

Calculate the number of possible gamete combinations from independent assortment alone: with n pairs of chromosomes, there are 2ⁿ possible combinations; in humans with 23 pairs, 2²³ = 8,388,608 possible different gametes from one individual.

Explain why independent assortment is important: it produces tremendous genetic diversity in gametes, meaning each gamete from a parent is genetically unique (except identical twins), and when combined with another unique gamete during fertilization, each offspring is genetically distinct.

sub_topics.name: Comparing Mitosis and Meiosis
sub_topics.short_description: Synthesize understanding of similarities and differences between mitotic and meiotic division.

sub_topics.name: Key Similarities and Differences
sub_topics.short_description: Create comprehensive comparisons between the two types of cell division.
example_tasks: Create a comparison table with columns for mitosis and meiosis comparing: purpose (growth/repair vs. gamete production), number of divisions (one vs. two), number of daughter cells (two vs. four), genetic relationship to parent (identical vs. unique), chromosome number in daughters (diploid vs. haploid).

Compare key events: both undergo DNA replication in S phase before division, both use spindle fibers to move chromosomes, but meiosis has synapsis and crossing over in Prophase I (mitosis does not), and meiosis separates homologs in first division (mitosis separates sister chromatids in only division).

Explain functional differences: mitosis maintains genetic consistency in body tissues (all cells have same instructions), while meiosis generates genetic diversity necessary for evolution and adaptation (every individual is unique).

sub_topics.name: Errors in Cell Division: Nondisjunction
sub_topics.short_description: Understand what happens when chromosomes fail to separate properly during division.
example_tasks: Define nondisjunction as the failure of homologous chromosomes (Meiosis I) or sister chromatids (Meiosis II or mitosis) to separate properly, resulting in gametes or cells with abnormal chromosome numbers.

Describe consequences of nondisjunction in gametes: one gamete receives extra chromosome (n+1) and one receives one fewer (n-1); if these fertilize a normal gamete, offspring has trisomy (2n+1, three copies of a chromosome) or monosomy (2n-1, one copy).

Provide examples of chromosomal disorders: Down syndrome (trisomy 21, three copies of chromosome 21), Turner syndrome (monosomy X, only one X chromosome in females), Klinefelter syndrome (XXY, extra X in males); explain that most autosomal monosomies and many trisomies are lethal.

sub_topics.name: Gametogenesis: Formation of Sperm and Eggs
sub_topics.short_description: Compare spermatogenesis and oogenesis, the processes that produce male and female gametes.
example_tasks: Compare spermatogenesis (in testes): one diploid spermatogonium undergoes meiosis producing four equal-sized functional haploid sperm cells, process continues throughout adult male life.

Compare oogenesis (in ovaries): one diploid oogonium undergoes meiosis producing one large functional ovum (egg) and two or three small polar bodies that degenerate, unequal division preserves cytoplasm and nutrients for the egg, begins before birth but completes only if fertilization occurs.

Explain the functional reasons for differences: sperm are small and motile (need many to maximize fertilization chance), eggs are large with nutrients to support early embryo (only one needed per fertilization event), reflecting different reproductive strategies.

grade_9_10.name: Molecular Genetics
grade_9_10.short_description: DNA structure, replication, transcription, and translation. Students explore how genetic information is stored in DNA, replicated for cell division, and expressed through protein synthesis.

sub_topics.name: DNA Structure and Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the double helix structure of DNA and how genetic information is encoded.

sub_topics.name: DNA Nucleotides and Base Pairing
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the building blocks of DNA and Chargaff's rules for complementary base pairing.
example_tasks: Describe the structure of a DNA nucleotide: consists of deoxyribose sugar (5-carbon), phosphate group, and one of four nitrogenous bases (adenine, thymine, guanine, or cytosine).

Explain Chargaff's rules and complementary base pairing: adenine (A) always pairs with thymine (T) via two hydrogen bonds, guanine (G) always pairs with cytosine (C) via three hydrogen bonds, so the amount of A equals T and the amount of G equals C in double-stranded DNA.
Given one DNA strand sequence (5'-ATCGGTA-3'), determine the complementary strand using base pairing rules (3'-TAGCCAT-5'), noting that strands run antiparallel (opposite directions).

sub_topics.name: The Double Helix Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Understand Watson and Crick's model of DNA as a twisted ladder with complementary strands.
example_tasks: Describe the double helix: two polynucleotide strands twisted around each other, sugar-phosphate backbones form the outside (sides of ladder), base pairs form the rungs (held together by hydrogen bonds), strands are antiparallel (one runs 5' to 3', other runs 3' to 5').

Explain how base pairing contributes to DNA stability: multiple hydrogen bonds along the molecule create a stable structure, while still allowing strands to separate for replication and transcription; GC pairs (3 H-bonds) are more stable than AT pairs (2 H-bonds).

Credit key scientists: James Watson and Francis Crick (proposed double helix model, 1953), Rosalind Franklin (X-ray crystallography showing helical structure), Maurice Wilkins (DNA structure work), Erwin Chargaff (base pairing rules).

sub_topics.name: Chromosome Structure and Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how DNA is packaged with proteins to form chromosomes.
example_tasks: Describe DNA packaging levels: DNA double helix → wraps around histone proteins forming nucleosomes (beads on a string) → nucleosomes coil into chromatin fiber → chromatin condenses further during cell division forming visible chromosomes.

Explain why DNA packaging is necessary: human cells contain about 2 meters of DNA that must fit into a nucleus about 10 micrometers in diameter; packaging condenses DNA by thousands-fold while still allowing access for replication and transcription.

Define key terms: chromatin (DNA-protein complex in non-dividing cells), histones (proteins that DNA wraps around), nucleosome (DNA wrapped around 8 histone proteins), chromosome (highly condensed chromatin visible during cell division).

sub_topics.name: DNA Replication
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how DNA copies itself to pass genetic information to daughter cells.

sub_topics.name: Semiconservative Replication Model
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that each new DNA molecule contains one original strand and one new strand.
example_tasks: Define semiconservative replication: when DNA replicates, the two strands separate and each serves as a template for a new complementary strand, so each new DNA molecule consists of one original (conserved) strand and one newly synthesized strand.

Explain the Meselson-Stahl experiment that proved semiconservative replication: used heavy and light nitrogen isotopes to track original vs. new DNA strands through generations, showing that after one replication, DNA was hybrid (one heavy, one light strand).

Explain why semiconservative replication is important: preserving one original strand in each molecule ensures accurate copying and provides a template to correct errors, maintaining genetic information fidelity across cell generations.

sub_topics.name: The Replication Process
sub_topics.short_description: Trace the steps and enzymes involved in DNA replication.
example_tasks: Describe the initiation of replication: enzyme helicase unwinds and separates the double helix at origins of replication, breaking hydrogen bonds between base pairs, creating a replication fork with two template strands.

Explain the role of key enzymes: helicase (unwinds DNA), DNA polymerase (adds nucleotides to growing strand, proofreads), primase (synthesizes RNA primer to start replication), ligase (joins Okazaki fragments on lagging strand).

Compare leading and lagging strand synthesis: leading strand is synthesized continuously in the 5' to 3' direction toward the replication fork; lagging strand is synthesized discontinuously in short Okazaki fragments (also 5' to 3' but away from fork) because DNA polymerase can only add nucleotides in one direction.

sub_topics.name: Accuracy and Proofreading in Replication
sub_topics.short_description: Understand mechanisms that ensure high fidelity of DNA replication.
example_tasks: Explain DNA polymerase proofreading: as it adds nucleotides, DNA polymerase checks each base pair; if an incorrect nucleotide is added, the enzyme removes it and replaces it with the correct one, reducing error rate to about 1 in 1 billion bases.
Describe mismatch repair: specialized proteins scan newly replicated DNA for errors missed by proofreading, remove incorrect nucleotides, and replace them with correct ones.

Explain why accurate replication is critical: errors (mutations) in DNA can lead to altered proteins, cellular dysfunction, cancer, or genetic disorders if they occur in gametes; proofreading and repair mechanisms maintain genetic stability across generations.

sub_topics.name: Gene Expression: Overview
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the central dogma of molecular biology: DNA → RNA → Protein.

sub_topics.name: The Central Dogma of Molecular Biology
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the flow of genetic information from DNA to RNA to protein.
example_tasks: State the central dogma: genetic information flows from DNA → RNA (transcription) → protein (translation), with DNA serving as permanent storage, RNA as temporary message, and proteins as functional products.

Explain the role of each molecule: DNA stores the genetic code in genes, mRNA carries the code from nucleus to ribosomes, tRNA brings amino acids to ribosomes, ribosomes read mRNA and assemble proteins.
Define key terms: gene (section of DNA that codes for a protein or RNA), transcription (DNA → RNA), translation (RNA → protein), codon (3-nucleotide sequence in mRNA that codes for an amino acid).

sub_topics.name: The Genetic Code
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how nucleotide sequences specify amino acid sequences in proteins.
example_tasks: Describe properties of the genetic code: triplet code (each codon is 3 nucleotides), redundant/degenerate (most amino acids coded by multiple codons), universal (same code used by nearly all organisms), non-overlapping (codons read in sequence without sharing nucleotides).

Use the codon table to translate mRNA sequences: given mRNA sequence 5'-AUGGCUUAA-3', identify codons (AUG-GCU-UAA), translate to amino acids using codon table (Met-Ala-Stop), noting that AUG is start codon and UAA is stop codon.
Explain start and stop codons: AUG codes for methionine and signals where translation begins; UAA, UAG, and UGA are stop codons that signal where translation ends (don't code for amino acids).

sub_topics.name: Transcription: DNA to RNA
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how genetic information is copied from DNA to messenger RNA.

sub_topics.name: The Transcription Process
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the three stages of transcription: initiation, elongation, and termination.
example_tasks: Describe initiation: RNA polymerase binds to the promoter region of DNA (before the gene), unwinds a small section of the double helix, and begins synthesis at the start site.

Describe elongation: RNA polymerase moves along the DNA template strand (3' to 5' direction), adding complementary RNA nucleotides (A pairs with U instead of T, C pairs with G) to growing mRNA strand in 5' to 3' direction.
Describe termination: when RNA polymerase reaches a termination sequence, it releases the completed mRNA strand and detaches from DNA; DNA rewinds into double helix.

sub_topics.name: Types of RNA
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish between mRNA, tRNA, and rRNA and their roles in gene expression.
example_tasks: Compare messenger RNA (mRNA): carries genetic information from DNA to ribosomes, contains codons that specify amino acid sequence, short-lived.
Compare transfer RNA (tRNA): brings amino acids to ribosomes during translation, has anticodon that pairs with mRNA codon and carries corresponding amino acid, cloverleaf shape.
Compare ribosomal RNA (rRNA): combines with proteins to form ribosomes, catalyzes peptide bond formation between amino acids, most abundant type of RNA in cells.

sub_topics.name: RNA Processing in Eukaryotes
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how pre-mRNA is modified to become mature mRNA in eukaryotic cells.
example_tasks: Describe the three RNA processing steps in eukaryotes: (1) 5' cap added (modified guanine nucleotide protects mRNA and helps ribosomes attach), (2) 3' poly-A tail added (string of adenine nucleotides increases stability), (3) splicing removes introns.

Explain introns and exons: genes contain introns (intervening sequences that don't code for protein) and exons (expressed sequences that do code); splicing removes introns and joins exons together to form mature mRNA.

Explain why RNA processing doesn't occur in prokaryotes: prokaryotic genes lack introns, and transcription and translation occur simultaneously in the cytoplasm (no nucleus), so mRNA doesn't need processing.

sub_topics.name: Translation: RNA to Protein
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how ribosomes synthesize proteins using the information in mRNA.

sub_topics.name: The Translation Process
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the three stages of translation: initiation, elongation, and termination.
example_tasks: Describe initiation: small ribosomal subunit binds to mRNA at the 5' cap, moves to AUG start codon, initiator tRNA (carrying methionine) binds to start codon, large ribosomal subunit attaches forming complete ribosome with A (aminoacyl), P (peptidyl), and E (exit) sites.

Describe elongation: tRNA with complementary anticodon enters A site bringing its amino acid, ribosome catalyzes peptide bond between amino acids in A and P sites, ribosome translocates (moves) one codon, moving tRNA from A to P to E sites, process repeats, growing polypeptide chain.

Describe termination: when stop codon (UAA, UAG, or UGA) enters A site, release factor protein binds instead of tRNA, causes ribosome to release polypeptide chain, ribosomal subunits dissociate from mRNA.

sub_topics.name: tRNA Structure and Anticodons
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how tRNA molecules match amino acids with mRNA codons.
example_tasks: Describe tRNA structure: cloverleaf-shaped molecule with an anticodon region (3 nucleotides that complement an mRNA codon) on one end and an amino acid attachment site on the opposite end.

Explain how tRNA functions: each tRNA is specific for one amino acid (charged by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase enzyme), anticodon pairs with complementary mRNA codon, ensures correct amino acid is added to growing protein.
Practice anticodon-codon pairing: if mRNA codon is 5'-UAC-3', the tRNA anticodon is 3'-AUG-5' (antiparallel and complementary), and tRNA carries the amino acid tyrosine (Tyr).

sub_topics.name: From Polypeptide to Functional Protein
sub_topics.short_description: Understand post-translational modifications and protein folding.
example_tasks: Explain that the initial product is a polypeptide chain (linear sequence of amino acids) that must fold into a specific 3D shape to become a functional protein, guided by the amino acid sequence and assisted by chaperone proteins.

Describe post-translational modifications that may occur: removal of methionine, addition of chemical groups (phosphate, carbohydrate, lipid), cleavage into smaller active forms (like insulin), or combination with other subunits.

Explain how protein structure determines function: the sequence of amino acids (primary structure) determines how the protein folds (secondary, tertiary, quaternary structure), and the final 3D shape determines what the protein can do (enzyme catalysis, transport, structure, etc.).

sub_topics.name: Mutations: Changes in DNA Sequence
sub_topics.short_description: Examine types of mutations, their causes, and potential effects on proteins and organisms.

sub_topics.name: Types of Gene Mutations
sub_topics.short_description: Classify mutations by their effects on DNA sequence.
example_tasks: Define point mutations (single nucleotide changes) and distinguish three subtypes: silent (no amino acid change due to redundancy of genetic code), missense (different amino acid), nonsense (creates stop codon, truncated protein).

Define frameshift mutations: insertion or deletion of nucleotides (not in multiples of 3) that shifts the reading frame, changing all downstream amino acids; usually more damaging than point mutations.

Provide examples: sickle cell disease (missense mutation, glutamic acid → valine in hemoglobin), cystic fibrosis (deletion of 3 nucleotides, loss of phenylalanine in CFTR protein), some cancers (nonsense mutations inactivating tumor suppressor genes).

sub_topics.name: Causes of Mutations
sub_topics.short_description: Identify factors that can cause DNA mutations.
example_tasks: Distinguish between spontaneous mutations (occur naturally due to errors in DNA replication or spontaneous DNA damage, despite proofreading) and induced mutations (caused by environmental factors called mutagens).

List types of mutagens: physical (UV radiation, X-rays, radioactive decay), chemical (tobacco smoke, certain pesticides, some industrial chemicals), and biological (certain viruses insert DNA into host chromosomes).

Explain why mutations in gametes are more significant than somatic mutations: mutations in body cells affect only that individual and aren't passed on, but mutations in sex cells (gametes) are inherited by offspring and affect all cells in next generation.

sub_topics.name: Effects of Mutations on Organisms
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that mutations can be harmful, beneficial, or neutral.
example_tasks: Explain harmful mutations: most mutations that change proteins are harmful because proteins already work well; examples include genetic disorders (sickle cell, cystic fibrosis, hemophilia) and cancer (mutations in cell cycle control genes).

Explain beneficial mutations: rare but important for evolution; examples include mutations conferring antibiotic resistance in bacteria, lactose tolerance in some human populations, or adaptations to high altitude.

Explain neutral mutations: many mutations have no effect on fitness because they occur in non-coding DNA, are silent (don't change amino acid), or change amino acid in a way that doesn't affect protein function; these contribute to genetic variation without immediate selective advantage or disadvantage.

grade_9_10.name: Classical Genetics & Heredity
grade_9_10.short_description: Mendelian inheritance, pedigrees, and probability in genetics. Students explore patterns of inheritance, solve genetics problems, and understand how traits are passed from parents to offspring.

sub_topics.name: Mendel's Experiments and Laws
sub_topics.short_description: Understand Gregor Mendel's pea plant experiments and the fundamental principles of inheritance.

sub_topics.name: Mendel's Experimental Approach
sub_topics.short_description: Examine why Mendel's methodical experiments led to breakthrough discoveries in genetics.
example_tasks: Explain why Mendel chose pea plants for his experiments: short generation time, produce many offspring, easy to cross-pollinate or self-pollinate, have distinct traits with two clear variations (tall/short, green/yellow, etc.).

Describe Mendel's experimental method: he studied one trait at a time, used large sample sizes, counted and analyzed offspring ratios mathematically, and performed controlled crosses through several generations.

Define key terms: P generation (parental, true-breeding), F1 generation (first filial, offspring of P cross), F2 generation (second filial, offspring of F1 self-cross), dominant trait (appears in F1), recessive trait (hidden in F1, reappears in F2).

sub_topics.name: Law of Segregation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that allele pairs separate during gamete formation so each gamete receives one allele.
example_tasks: State the Law of Segregation: each individual has two alleles for each gene, these alleles separate during meiosis, and each gamete receives only one allele for each gene.

Explain Mendel's evidence: when he crossed tall (TT) and short (tt) pea plants, all F1 were tall (Tt); when F1 self-crossed, F2 showed 3:1 ratio (3 tall : 1 short), indicating that the recessive allele was present but hidden in F1 and reappeared in F2.

Use a Punnett square to demonstrate segregation: cross Tt × Tt, showing how alleles separate into gametes (T and t from each parent), then combine to produce offspring genotypes TT (25%), Tt (50%), tt (25%), resulting in 3:1 phenotypic ratio.

sub_topics.name: Law of Independent Assortment
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that genes for different traits segregate independently during gamete formation.
example_tasks: State the Law of Independent Assortment: alleles for different genes segregate independently of one another during gamete formation (applies to genes on different chromosomes or far apart on same chromosome).

Explain Mendel's dihybrid cross evidence: crossing pea plants differing in two traits (seed shape and color: RRYY × rryy) produced F1 all RrYy, then F2 showed 9:3:3:1 ratio (9 round yellow : 3 round green : 3 wrinkled yellow : 1 wrinkled green).
Use a dihybrid Punnett square: cross RrYy × RrYy, showing 16 possible offspring combinations, demonstrating that shape and color assort independently, each following its own 3:1 ratio.

sub_topics.name: Genetic Terminology and Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Master the vocabulary and fundamental concepts used in genetics problems and analysis.

sub_topics.name: Alleles, Genotype, and Phenotype
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish between different forms of genes and their expression.
example_tasks: Define key terms: allele (alternative form of a gene), genotype (genetic makeup, the alleles present), phenotype (observable characteristics, physical expression of genotype), dominant allele (expressed when present), recessive allele (expressed only in homozygous state).
Explain notation: dominant alleles represented by uppercase letters (T for tall), recessive by lowercase (t for short); genotype written with both alleles (TT, Tt, or tt).
Distinguish homozygous (two identical alleles: TT or tt) from heterozygous (two different alleles: Tt), and explain that heterozygotes show the dominant phenotype but carry the recessive allele.

sub_topics.name: Monohybrid Crosses
sub_topics.short_description: Solve genetics problems involving a single trait using Punnett squares.
example_tasks: Set up and complete a Punnett square for a monohybrid cross: Tt × Tt, determine gametes (T and t from each parent), fill in 4 boxes, calculate genotypic ratio (1 TT : 2 Tt : 1 tt) and phenotypic ratio (3 tall : 1 short).

Solve a test cross problem: if a tall plant could be TT or Tt, cross it with a short plant (tt); if any offspring are short, the tall parent must be Tt; if all offspring are tall, parent is probably TT.
Calculate probability: in a Tt × Tt cross, what's the probability of getting a short plant? (25% or 1/4, since only tt genotype produces short phenotype).

sub_topics.name: Dihybrid Crosses
sub_topics.short_description: Solve genetics problems involving two traits simultaneously.
example_tasks: Determine possible gametes for dihybrid individuals: for RrYy parent, use FOIL method or branching diagram to find four gamete types (RY, Ry, rY, ry) each with 25% probability.
Set up 4×4 Punnett square for dihybrid cross RrYy × RrYy, fill in 16 boxes, identify the 9:3:3:1 phenotypic ratio characteristic of independent assortment.
Use multiplication rule as shortcut: probability of round AND yellow offspring (R_Y_) = probability of round (3/4) × probability of yellow (3/4) = 9/16, matching Punnett square results.

sub_topics.name: Probability Rules in Genetics
sub_topics.short_description: Apply mathematical probability to predict inheritance outcomes.
example_tasks: Use the multiplication rule (AND): to find probability of independent events both occurring, multiply their individual probabilities; example: probability of getting TTyy from Tt × Yy cross = 1/4 (TT) × 1/4 (yy) = 1/16.
Use the addition rule (OR): to find probability of alternative events, add their individual probabilities; example: probability of getting Tt OR tt from Tt × Tt = 1/2 + 1/4 = 3/4.
Solve complex problems: In a cross AaBbCc × AaBbCc, what is the probability of offspring with genotype AABbcc? Calculate each trait separately: AA (1/4) × Bb (1/2) × cc (1/4) = 1/32.

sub_topics.name: Extensions of Mendelian Genetics
sub_topics.short_description: Explore inheritance patterns that are more complex than simple dominance.

sub_topics.name: Incomplete Dominance
sub_topics.short_description: Understand inheritance where heterozygotes show an intermediate phenotype.
example_tasks: Define incomplete dominance: neither allele is completely dominant, so heterozygotes display a phenotype intermediate between the two homozygotes; often use different notation (C^R for red, C^W for white instead of R and r).
Provide examples: snapdragon flower color (red × white → pink), human hair texture (straight × curly → wavy), some cattle coat colors.

Predict offspring: cross two pink snapdragons (C^R C^W × C^R C^W), producing 1 red (C^R C^R) : 2 pink (C^R C^W) : 1 white (C^W C^W), showing 1:2:1 ratio for both genotype AND phenotype (different from 3:1 in simple dominance).

sub_topics.name: Codominance
sub_topics.short_description: Understand inheritance where both alleles are fully expressed in heterozygotes.
example_tasks: Define codominance: both alleles are equally dominant and both are fully expressed in heterozygotes, producing a phenotype with both traits visible simultaneously (not blended).

Explain human ABO blood types as codominance example: I^A and I^B alleles are codominant (both expressed in type AB blood), while both are dominant over i (type O); possible genotypes I^A I^A or I^A i (type A), I^B I^B or I^B i (type B), I^A I^B (type AB), ii (type O).

Solve blood type problems: if a man with type AB blood (I^A I^B) has children with a woman with type O blood (ii), what blood types are possible in offspring? All children will receive either I^A or I^B from father and i from mother, so 50% type A (I^A i) and 50% type B (I^B i), no type AB or O.

sub_topics.name: Multiple Alleles
sub_topics.short_description: Understand traits controlled by genes with more than two allelic forms.
example_tasks: Explain that while individuals have only two alleles for a gene, the gene may have multiple allelic forms in the population; example: ABO blood type has three alleles (I^A, I^B, i) in human population.
Describe rabbit coat color controlled by four alleles: C (full color) > c^ch (chinchilla) > c^h (Himalayan) > c (albino), arranged in dominance hierarchy, each rabbit has two of these alleles.
Calculate possible offspring: cross a Himalayan rabbit (c^h c) with a chinchilla rabbit (c^ch c^h), offspring will be 50% chinchilla (c^ch c^h) and 50% Himalayan (c^h c).

sub_topics.name: Polygenic Inheritance
sub_topics.short_description: Understand traits influenced by multiple genes with additive effects.
example_tasks: Define polygenic inheritance: traits controlled by two or more genes, with alleles having small additive effects, producing continuous variation (range of phenotypes) rather than discrete categories.
Provide examples of polygenic traits in humans: height, skin color, eye color, intelligence, many susceptibilities to diseases; these traits show bell curve distribution in populations.

Explain skin color inheritance (simplified): if three genes (AaBbCc) each contribute, individuals with more dominant alleles have darker skin; cross AaBbCc × AaBbCc produces offspring ranging from very light (aabbcc) to very dark (AABBCC) with most showing intermediate shades.

sub_topics.name: Epistasis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand when one gene affects the expression of another gene.
example_tasks: Define epistasis: one gene (epistatic gene) masks or modifies the expression of another gene (hypostatic gene) at a different locus, producing non-traditional ratios.

Explain Labrador retriever coat color: gene E (pigment deposition) is epistatic to gene B (color type); genotypes with ee always produce yellow dogs regardless of B genotype, while E_ allows B to be expressed (B_ produces black, bb produces brown), giving 9:3:4 ratio instead of 9:3:3:1.
Predict offspring: cross two dogs with genotype BbEe, determine phenotypic ratio: 9/16 black (B_E_), 3/16 brown (bbE_), 4/16 yellow (either B_ee or bbee).

sub_topics.name: Pleiotropy
sub_topics.short_description: Understand when a single gene affects multiple phenotypic traits.
example_tasks: Define pleiotropy: one gene influences multiple, seemingly unrelated phenotypic traits; mutation in one gene can have cascading effects throughout the organism.

Provide example of sickle cell disease: single mutation in hemoglobin gene causes multiple effects including misshapen red blood cells, anemia, pain episodes, organ damage, increased malaria resistance (heterozygotes), demonstrating how one gene affects many body systems.

Explain phenylketonuria (PKU): mutation in gene for enzyme that breaks down phenylalanine leads to multiple problems including intellectual disability, light skin and hair pigmentation, and musty odor if untreated, all from one genetic defect.

sub_topics.name: Sex-Linked Inheritance
sub_topics.short_description: Understand inheritance patterns of genes located on sex chromosomes.

sub_topics.name: Sex Determination and Sex Chromosomes
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how sex is determined by chromosomes in humans and other organisms.
example_tasks: Explain the XY system in humans: females have two X chromosomes (XX), males have one X and one Y (XY); eggs always carry X, sperm carry either X or Y, so father determines offspring sex.
Use Punnett square to show 50:50 sex ratio: cross XX (female) × XY (male) produces 50% XX (female) and 50% XY (male) offspring.

Describe other sex determination systems: ZW system in birds (males ZZ, females ZW), temperature-dependent in some reptiles, haplodiploidy in bees (males from unfertilized eggs are haploid, females from fertilized eggs are diploid).

sub_topics.name: X-Linked Traits
sub_topics.short_description: Understand inheritance patterns of genes located on the X chromosome.
example_tasks: Explain why X-linked recessive traits are more common in males: males have only one X chromosome, so a single recessive allele produces the trait (hemizygous); females need two recessive alleles to show the trait, but one recessive allele makes them carriers.

Use notation for X-linked traits: X^H (dominant allele), X^h (recessive allele), Y (no corresponding allele); possible genotypes: X^H X^H (normal female), X^H X^h (carrier female), X^h X^h (affected female), X^H Y (normal male), X^h Y (affected male).

Solve X-linked problems: cross a carrier female (X^H X^h) with a normal male (X^H Y); offspring will be 25% normal female, 25% carrier female, 25% normal male, 25% affected male, showing characteristic pattern where affected males can have unaffected parents.

sub_topics.name: Examples of X-Linked Disorders
sub_topics.short_description: Examine specific human traits and disorders that show X-linked inheritance.
example_tasks: Describe hemophilia A: X-linked recessive disorder causing blood clotting problems due to lack of clotting factor VIII; affected individuals mostly males, female carriers usually unaffected, transmitted through carrier mothers to sons.
Describe red-green color blindness: X-linked recessive trait affecting ability to distinguish red and green colors, common in males (about 8%) but rare in females (about 0.5%).
Describe Duchenne muscular dystrophy: X-linked recessive disorder causing progressive muscle degeneration, affecting mostly males, symptoms appear in early childhood, no cure currently available.

sub_topics.name: Y-Linked Traits
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the few traits passed directly from father to all sons.
example_tasks: Explain Y-linked (holandric) inheritance: genes on Y chromosome passed from father to all sons and only sons, never to daughters; very few genes on Y chromosome (mostly related to male sex determination and sperm production).
Describe SRY gene: sex-determining region on Y chromosome that triggers male development; presence of functional SRY leads to male phenotype, absence leads to female development.

Provide examples of Y-linked traits: male-pattern hair growth, some cases of male infertility, ear hair growth (in some populations); these show distinctive pattern where all males in patrilineal line are affected if trait is present.

sub_topics.name: Pedigree Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Learn to construct and interpret family trees showing inheritance patterns across generations.

sub_topics.name: Pedigree Symbols and Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Master the standard symbols and conventions used in pedigree charts.
example_tasks: Identify pedigree symbols: squares (males), circles (females), horizontal lines (mating), vertical lines (offspring), filled symbols (affected by trait), half-filled (carriers for recessive traits), diagonal line through symbol (deceased).

Understand pedigree structure: Roman numerals label generations (I, II, III), Arabic numerals label individuals within each generation (1, 2, 3), generations read from top (oldest) to bottom (youngest).
Practice reading relationships: identify parents, siblings, offspring, aunts/uncles, cousins, generations; determine who is affected by the trait being traced.

sub_topics.name: Autosomal Dominant Pedigrees
sub_topics.short_description: Recognize patterns characteristic of dominant traits on autosomes.
example_tasks: Identify autosomal dominant patterns: trait appears in every generation, affected individuals have at least one affected parent, roughly equal numbers of affected males and females, two unaffected parents cannot have affected children.
Determine genotypes in a dominant pedigree: affected individuals are either AA or Aa (usually Aa since most genetic disorders are rare), unaffected individuals are aa.

Provide examples: Huntington's disease, achondroplasia (dwarfism), polydactyly (extra fingers/toes); explain why some dominant disorders persist despite selection against them (late onset like Huntington's, or mild effects).

sub_topics.name: Autosomal Recessive Pedigrees
sub_topics.short_description: Recognize patterns characteristic of recessive traits on autosomes.
example_tasks: Identify autosomal recessive patterns: trait often skips generations, affected individuals can have two unaffected parents (both carriers), roughly equal numbers of affected males and females, more common in consanguineous marriages (related parents).
Determine genotypes: affected individuals are aa, unaffected individuals with affected children must be Aa (carriers), unaffected individuals with no family history could be AA or Aa.
Provide examples: cystic fibrosis, sickle cell disease, Tay-Sachs disease, albinism; explain carrier screening in populations where certain recessive disorders are more common.

sub_topics.name: X-Linked Recessive Pedigrees
sub_topics.short_description: Recognize patterns characteristic of X-linked recessive traits.
example_tasks: Identify X-linked recessive patterns: much more common in males than females, affected males often have unaffected parents (mother is carrier), affected males have carrier daughters (if they reproduce), trait passes from carrier mother to affected sons, no male-to-male transmission.
Determine genotypes: affected males are X^h Y, affected females are X^h X^h (rare), carrier females are X^H X^h, normal individuals are X^H X^H or X^H Y.

Analyze a pedigree: if a woman has an affected father and normal mother, what is the woman's genotype? She must be X^H X^h (carrier) because she received X^h from affected father and X^H from normal mother; predict the probability her sons will be affected (50%).

sub_topics.name: Constructing and Using Pedigrees
sub_topics.short_description: Practice creating pedigrees from family history information and using them to predict inheritance.
example_tasks: Construct a pedigree from a scenario: given a family history description (e.g., 'A couple has three children: two unaffected daughters and one affected son with hemophilia; the wife's father had hemophilia'), draw the pedigree using proper symbols and identify carrier females.

Use pedigree for genetic counseling: determine probability that specific individuals will have affected children; example: if a woman's brother has cystic fibrosis (recessive) and her parents are unaffected, what's the probability she is a carrier? (2/3, since she's unaffected but could be Aa).

Analyze complex pedigrees: determine most likely mode of inheritance (autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, X-linked recessive, Y-linked) by examining patterns across multiple generations and comparing to characteristic patterns.

sub_topics.name: Human Genetic Disorders
sub_topics.short_description: Explore specific genetic conditions, their causes, symptoms, and societal implications.

sub_topics.name: Chromosomal Disorders
sub_topics.short_description: Understand disorders caused by changes in chromosome number or structure.
example_tasks: Describe Down syndrome (trisomy 21): extra copy of chromosome 21, characteristic facial features, intellectual disability, increased heart defect risk, most common viable autosomal trisomy, risk increases with maternal age.

Compare other trisomies: trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome, severe developmental problems, usually lethal in infancy), trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome, severe defects, usually lethal); explain why most autosomal trisomies are lethal.

Describe sex chromosome aneuploidies: Turner syndrome (X0, female with one X chromosome), Klinefelter syndrome (XXY, male with extra X), XXX syndrome, XYY syndrome; note these are generally less severe than autosomal aneuploidies because of X-inactivation.

sub_topics.name: Single-Gene Disorders
sub_topics.short_description: Examine disorders caused by mutations in individual genes.
example_tasks: Compare sickle cell disease (recessive): mutation in beta-globin gene, misshapen red blood cells, pain crises, heterozygotes have sickle cell trait (mild) and malaria resistance, most common in African descent populations.

Compare Huntington's disease (dominant): progressive nervous system degeneration, late onset (typically 30-50 years), caused by CAG repeat expansion, illustrates why some dominant lethal alleles persist in population.

Compare cystic fibrosis (recessive): defective chloride ion channel, thick mucus in lungs and digestive tract, most common lethal genetic disease in Caucasian populations, improved treatments increasing life expectancy.

sub_topics.name: Genetic Testing and Counseling
sub_topics.short_description: Understand modern applications of genetics in medicine and family planning.
example_tasks: Describe types of genetic testing: carrier screening (identify heterozygotes for recessive disorders), prenatal testing (amniocentesis, chorionic villus sampling), newborn screening (PKU, other treatable conditions), predictive testing (BRCA genes for cancer risk).

Explain roles of genetic counselors: assess family history and risk, explain inheritance patterns and probabilities, discuss testing options and implications, provide support for decision-making, address ethical concerns.

Discuss ethical considerations: privacy of genetic information, potential for discrimination, reproductive decisions, psychological impact of test results, questions about testing minors for adult-onset conditions.

grade_9_10.name: Evolution & Natural Selection
grade_9_10.short_description: Mechanisms of evolution, adaptation, and evidence for evolutionary change. Students examine how populations change over time through natural selection and other evolutionary forces.

sub_topics.name: History of Evolutionary Thought
sub_topics.short_description: Trace the development of evolutionary theory from early ideas to Darwin's contributions.

sub_topics.name: Pre-Darwin Ideas About Species
sub_topics.short_description: Understand early concepts about species change and Earth's history.
example_tasks: Describe Lamarck's theory of inheritance of acquired characteristics: organisms could pass traits acquired during their lifetime to offspring (e.g., giraffe stretching neck to reach leaves passes longer neck to offspring); explain why this mechanism is incorrect but the idea of species change was important.

Explain contributions of geologists Hutton and Lyell: proposed Earth is very old and shaped by slow, gradual processes (uniformitarianism) rather than catastrophes; influenced Darwin by suggesting Earth was old enough for gradual evolution.

Describe the dominant view before Darwin: fixity of species (species unchanging since creation), young Earth (thousands not millions of years old), and each species specially created for its environment.

sub_topics.name: Darwin's Voyage and Observations
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the observations from HMS Beagle that led Darwin to develop his theory.
example_tasks: Describe key observations from Galápagos Islands: finches on different islands had different beak shapes suited to available food, tortoises from different islands had different shell shapes, islands close together had similar but distinct species.

Explain fossil observations: Darwin found fossils of extinct animals (like giant ground sloths) that resembled but were larger than living species in same region, suggesting descent with modification.

Describe biogeographical patterns: similar environments on different continents had very different species, but species were more similar within a continent even in different environments, suggesting common ancestry within regions rather than independent creation for each environment.

sub_topics.name: Darwin's Theory of Evolution by Natural Selection
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the key components of Darwin's revolutionary theory.
example_tasks: State Darwin's main ideas: (1) species change over time, (2) all species descended from common ancestors, (3) gradual accumulation of changes, (4) mechanism is natural selection ('survival of the fittest').

Explain what influenced Darwin's thinking: Malthus's essay on population (competition for limited resources), artificial selection by breeders (showing species can change), Lyell's geology (old Earth, gradual change).

Describe why Darwin delayed publication: collected evidence for 20+ years, feared religious and scientific controversy, finally published 'On the Origin of Species' (1859) when Wallace independently developed similar ideas.

sub_topics.name: Natural Selection as a Mechanism
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the process by which natural selection drives evolutionary change.

sub_topics.name: Key Principles of Natural Selection
sub_topics.short_description: Identify the essential conditions required for natural selection to occur.
example_tasks: List the four key observations and conclusions: (1) Overproduction - organisms produce more offspring than can survive, (2) Variation - individuals show differences in traits, (3) Heredity - traits are passed to offspring, (4) Differential survival/reproduction - individuals with advantageous traits survive and reproduce more, passing those traits to next generation.

Explain 'survival of the fittest': 'fitness' means reproductive success (number of offspring that survive to reproduce), not strength or speed; individuals with traits that increase survival and reproduction in current environment have higher fitness.

Clarify common misconceptions: evolution is not goal-directed or purposeful, organisms don't evolve during their lifetime (populations evolve over generations), 'need' doesn't create mutations, natural selection works on existing variation.

sub_topics.name: Types of Natural Selection
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish between directional, stabilizing, and disruptive selection.
example_tasks: Describe directional selection: one extreme phenotype is favored, shifts population average in one direction; example: antibiotic resistance in bacteria (resistance alleles increase), peppered moths during industrial revolution (dark moths favored in polluted areas).

Describe stabilizing selection: intermediate phenotype is favored, reduces variation and maintains status quo; example: human birth weight (very small and very large babies have lower survival), selection against extreme phenotypes in stable environments.

Describe disruptive selection: both extreme phenotypes are favored over intermediate, increases variation and can lead to speciation; example: African seed-cracker finches where birds with very large or very small beaks are more successful than intermediate-sized beaks.

sub_topics.name: Adaptations
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how natural selection produces adaptations suited to specific environments.
example_tasks: Define adaptation: inherited characteristic that increases an organism's fitness (survival and reproduction) in a particular environment; results from natural selection acting over many generations.

Provide examples of adaptations: structural (cactus spines for water conservation, arctic fox white fur for camouflage), behavioral (bird migration, hibernation), physiological (snake venom for prey capture, bacteria antibiotic resistance).

Explain that adaptations are relative: traits beneficial in one environment may be harmful in another (thick fur good in arctic, bad in desert); what counts as adaptation depends on current environment and can change.

sub_topics.name: Evidence for Evolution
sub_topics.short_description: Examine multiple independent lines of evidence supporting evolutionary theory.

sub_topics.name: Fossil Evidence
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how the fossil record documents evolutionary change over time.
example_tasks: Explain how fossils form: organisms buried in sediment, hard parts (bones, shells) preserved through mineralization, sediment hardens into rock layers (strata), oldest fossils in deepest layers (law of superposition).

Describe what the fossil record shows: progression from simple to complex organisms, appearance of new groups over time, extinctions of many species, transitional forms showing intermediate characteristics between groups.

Provide examples of transitional fossils: Archaeopteryx (reptile-bird transition with both feathers and teeth), Tiktaalik (fish-tetrapod transition with fins and neck), whale fossils showing transition from land mammals to aquatic (Ambulocetus, Dorudon).

sub_topics.name: Comparative Anatomy
sub_topics.short_description: Examine structural similarities that reveal evolutionary relationships.
example_tasks: Define and identify homologous structures: anatomical features with same basic structure and embryonic origin but different functions due to different evolutionary pressures; example: forelimbs of humans, cats, whales, bats have same bones arranged differently (evidence of common ancestry).

Define analogous structures: features that serve similar functions and look similar but have different evolutionary origins (result of convergent evolution); example: wings of birds and insects both used for flight but evolved independently, have different structures.

Explain vestigial structures: reduced or functionless structures that were functional in ancestors, evidence of evolutionary change; examples: human appendix (reduced cecum), whale pelvic bones (remnants of walking ancestors), snake leg bones (remnants of lizard ancestors).

sub_topics.name: Embryological Evidence
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how similarities in early development reveal common ancestry.
example_tasks: Describe embryological similarities: vertebrate embryos (fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, mammals) all show similar early stages including gill pouches, tail, and similar body organization, suggesting common ancestry.

Explain that developmental pathways are conserved: closely related organisms show similarities for longer in development, more distantly related organisms diverge earlier; humans and chimps nearly identical through most development, humans and fish diverge early.

Relate to homologous structures: structures that are homologous in adults develop from same embryonic tissues, supporting common ancestry (e.g., all vertebrate limbs develop from same embryonic limb buds).

sub_topics.name: Molecular and Biochemical Evidence
sub_topics.short_description: Examine DNA and protein similarities that provide the strongest evidence for evolution.
example_tasks: Explain molecular homologies: all organisms use DNA with same genetic code, same 20 amino acids, same ATP for energy, suggesting all life descended from common ancestor; more closely related organisms have more similar DNA sequences.

Describe DNA sequence comparisons: humans and chimpanzees share ~98-99% DNA sequence similarity, humans and gorillas ~98%, humans and mice ~85%, humans and fruit flies ~60%, decreasing similarity correlates with evolutionary distance.

Explain molecular clocks: mutations accumulate at relatively constant rates, so number of DNA differences can estimate time since species diverged; consistent with fossil record dating; allows estimation of divergence times even without fossils.

sub_topics.name: Biogeographical Evidence
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how geographic distribution of species supports evolution.
example_tasks: Explain island biogeography: islands have species similar to nearest mainland but with unique adaptations, not species similar to other islands with similar environments; suggests colonization from mainland followed by evolution (example: Galápagos finches related to South American finches, not to similar birds on African islands).

Describe continental patterns: continents that were once connected (e.g., South America and Africa) have related species, while continents that were never connected (e.g., Australia) have very different species despite similar environments (marsupials in Australia vs. placentals elsewhere).

Explain why biogeography supports evolution: distribution makes sense if species descended and dispersed from common ancestors, would not make sense if each species independently created for its current environment.

sub_topics.name: Directly Observed Evolution
sub_topics.short_description: Examine evolution occurring in real time in laboratories and nature.
example_tasks: Describe antibiotic resistance in bacteria: bacteria evolve resistance to antibiotics through natural selection in years or decades; random mutations provide variation, antibiotics create strong selective pressure, resistant bacteria survive and reproduce.

Explain pesticide resistance in insects: mosquitoes evolved DDT resistance, many insects resistant to multiple pesticides, demonstrates rapid evolution in response to human-created selective pressures.

Provide other examples: HIV evolving resistance to drugs, influenza virus changing requiring new vaccines annually, Darwin's finches (beak size changes observed over decades in response to drought), color changes in peppered moths tracked during industrial pollution and cleanup.

sub_topics.name: Population Genetics and Microevolution
sub_topics.short_description: Understand evolution at the population level through changes in allele frequencies.

sub_topics.name: Populations and Gene Pools
sub_topics.short_description: Define the units and measures of evolutionary change.
example_tasks: Define population: group of individuals of the same species living in the same area and interbreeding; population is the unit of evolution (individuals don't evolve, but populations do over generations).
Define gene pool: all alleles present in a population; evolution is change in allele frequencies in the gene pool over time (microevolution).

Calculate allele frequencies: in a population of 100 individuals (200 alleles for a gene), if 60 individuals are AA, 30 are Aa, and 10 are aa, frequency of A allele = (60×2 + 30)/200 = 0.75, frequency of a = 0.25.

sub_topics.name: Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the null hypothesis for evolutionary change describing non-evolving populations.
example_tasks: State Hardy-Weinberg conditions for non-evolution: (1) no mutations, (2) random mating, (3) no gene flow (migration), (4) very large population size (no genetic drift), (5) no natural selection; if all conditions met, allele frequencies remain constant.

Use Hardy-Weinberg equations: p + q = 1 (allele frequencies) and p² + 2pq + q² = 1 (genotype frequencies), where p = dominant allele frequency, q = recessive allele frequency, p² = homozygous dominant, 2pq = heterozygous, q² = homozygous recessive.

Solve Hardy-Weinberg problems: if 16% of population shows recessive phenotype (q²), calculate q = 0.4, p = 0.6, heterozygote frequency = 2pq = 0.48 (48% are carriers); conversely, if conditions are violated, population is evolving.

sub_topics.name: Mechanisms Causing Microevolution
sub_topics.short_description: Identify factors that cause allele frequencies to change, violating Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.
example_tasks: Explain mutation as source of variation: random changes in DNA create new alleles, usually rare, most are harmful or neutral, occasionally beneficial; necessary for evolution but alone causes slow change in allele frequencies.

Explain gene flow (migration): movement of individuals or gametes between populations transfers alleles, tends to reduce differences between populations, can introduce new alleles or change frequencies of existing ones.

Explain genetic drift: random changes in allele frequencies due to chance events, stronger effect in small populations; examples include bottleneck effect (population drastically reduced by disaster) and founder effect (new population started by few individuals).

sub_topics.name: Sexual Selection
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how mate choice and competition for mates drive evolution of certain traits.
example_tasks: Define sexual selection: type of natural selection where traits affecting mating success are favored even if they reduce survival; explains evolution of elaborate traits that seem disadvantageous for survival (peacock tail, elk antlers).

Distinguish intrasexual selection (competition between same sex, usually males, for access to mates): male-male competition leads to evolution of larger size, weapons (antlers, horns), aggressive behavior.

Distinguish intersexual selection (mate choice, usually females choosing males): female preferences drive evolution of male ornaments (bright colors, elaborate displays, songs); examples: peacock tail, bird of paradise plumage, firefly light patterns.

sub_topics.name: Speciation and Macroevolution
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how new species form and large-scale evolutionary patterns.

sub_topics.name: Species Concepts and Definitions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand different ways to define species.
example_tasks: Define biological species concept: group of populations that can interbreed and produce fertile offspring in nature, and are reproductively isolated from other groups; most commonly used but has limitations.

Identify limitations of biological species concept: doesn't apply to asexual organisms, extinct species (can't test breeding), or populations that are geographically separated (don't have opportunity to interbreed but might be able to).

Describe alternative species concepts: morphological (distinguished by structural features), ecological (defined by ecological niche), phylogenetic (smallest group sharing common ancestor); each useful in different contexts.

sub_topics.name: Reproductive Isolation Mechanisms
sub_topics.short_description: Identify barriers that prevent different species from producing viable, fertile offspring.
example_tasks: List prezygotic barriers (prevent fertilization): habitat isolation (species in different areas), temporal isolation (breed at different times), behavioral isolation (different courtship behaviors), mechanical isolation (reproductive structures incompatible), gametic isolation (sperm can't fertilize egg).

List postzygotic barriers (occur after fertilization): reduced hybrid viability (hybrid embryos don't develop properly), reduced hybrid fertility (hybrid offspring sterile, like mule), hybrid breakdown (F1 hybrids fertile but F2 have problems).

Provide examples: horses and donkeys mate but produce sterile mule (postzygotic), eastern and western meadowlarks overlap in range but don't mate due to different songs (behavioral), species of sea urchins release gametes into water but sperm and egg won't fuse between species (gametic).

sub_topics.name: Allopatric Speciation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand speciation that occurs when populations are geographically separated.
example_tasks: Define allopatric speciation: evolution of new species when populations are geographically isolated (separated by physical barrier), preventing gene flow; populations accumulate different mutations and experience different selection pressures, eventually becoming reproductively incompatible.

Describe the process: single population divided by barrier (mountain range, river, ocean) → isolated populations experience different environments → natural selection and genetic drift cause populations to diverge → if reunited later, populations can no longer interbreed (new species).

Provide examples: Darwin's finches on different Galápagos islands, squirrels on opposite sides of Grand Canyon (Kaibab vs. Abert's squirrels), many species formed when continents separated or islands became isolated.

sub_topics.name: Sympatric Speciation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand speciation that occurs without geographic separation.
example_tasks: Define sympatric speciation: evolution of new species within the same geographic area, without physical barriers separating populations; less common than allopatric speciation but occurs through various mechanisms.

Explain polyploidy in plants: error in meiosis produces gametes with extra chromosome sets; if diploid gametes fuse, offspring is tetraploid and reproductively isolated from diploid parents; instant speciation, common in plant evolution (wheat, cotton).

Describe other mechanisms: sexual selection (cichlid fish in same lake diverge based on female color preferences), habitat differentiation (apple maggot flies evolved from hawthorn flies when apples introduced to North America, flies on different fruits isolated by timing).

sub_topics.name: Patterns and Rates of Evolution
sub_topics.short_description: Examine large-scale evolutionary patterns observed in the fossil record.
example_tasks: Compare gradualism (Darwin's view): species evolve slowly and steadily through small changes accumulating over long periods, transitional forms should be abundant in fossil record.

Compare punctuated equilibrium (Eldredge and Gould): species remain relatively unchanged (stasis) for long periods, then undergo rapid change during speciation events (thousands of years, rapid geologically), explains relative scarcity of transitional forms.

Describe adaptive radiation: rapid diversification of a single ancestral species into many species occupying different ecological niches; examples: Darwin's finches, Hawaiian honeycreepers, mammals after dinosaur extinction, often occurs when new environment becomes available.

grade_9_10.name: Classification & Biodiversity
grade_9_10.short_description: Taxonomic systems, phylogenetics, and diversity of life. Students explore how organisms are classified, named, and organized based on evolutionary relationships.

sub_topics.name: The Need for Classification
sub_topics.short_description: Understand why organizing Earth's biodiversity is essential for biological study.

sub_topics.name: Earth's Biodiversity
sub_topics.short_description: Appreciate the vast diversity of life forms on Earth.
example_tasks: Describe the scope of biodiversity: estimated 8-10 million species on Earth (only about 2 million named and described), found in every environment from deep ocean trenches to mountain peaks, from polar regions to tropical rainforests.

Explain the importance of classification: organizing diversity allows scientists to communicate about organisms, identify patterns, study relationships, manage conservation, discover new species, and understand evolutionary history.
Define taxonomy: the science of naming, describing, and classifying organisms into hierarchical groups based on shared characteristics and evolutionary relationships.

sub_topics.name: Early Classification Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understand historical approaches to organizing living things.
example_tasks: Describe Aristotle's classification: divided organisms into plants and animals, then by habitat (land, water, air) and physical features; simple but not based on evolutionary relationships.

Explain Linnaeus's contributions (1700s): developed binomial nomenclature (two-part naming system), organized species into hierarchical categories, laid foundation for modern taxonomy, though his system predated understanding of evolution.

Contrast historical vs. modern classification: early systems based on observable similarities (morphology), modern systems aim to reflect evolutionary relationships (phylogeny) using multiple lines of evidence including DNA.

sub_topics.name: Linnaean Classification System
sub_topics.short_description: Master the hierarchical system of taxonomic categories and naming conventions.

sub_topics.name: Taxonomic Hierarchy
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the nested levels of classification from domain to species.
example_tasks: List taxonomic categories from most to least inclusive: Domain → Kingdom → Phylum → Class → Order → Family → Genus → Species (mnemonic: Dear King Philip Came Over For Good Soup).

Explain hierarchical organization: each level is nested within the level above it; organisms grouped at lower levels (species) are more closely related than those grouped at higher levels (kingdoms); moving up hierarchy, groups become more inclusive but less similar.
Practice classification: humans are classified as Domain: Eukarya, Kingdom: Animalia, Phylum: Chordata, Class: Mammalia, Order: Primates, Family: Hominidae, Genus: Homo, Species: sapiens.

sub_topics.name: Binomial Nomenclature
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the two-part scientific naming system for species.
example_tasks: Explain binomial nomenclature rules: scientific name consists of genus (capitalized) and species epithet (lowercase), both italicized or underlined, genus name can be abbreviated after first use (e.g., Homo sapiens, then H. sapiens).

Describe advantages of scientific names: universal (same name worldwide regardless of language), specific (each species has unique name), stable (doesn't change when organism moves or is reclassified at higher levels), informative (shows relationships).

Practice writing scientific names correctly: domestic dog is Canis familiaris (or Canis lupus familiaris), modern human is Homo sapiens, common house cat is Felis catus; identify and correct errors like writing genus in lowercase or forgetting to italicize.

sub_topics.name: Dichotomous Keys
sub_topics.short_description: Use and create identification tools based on paired choices.
example_tasks: Define dichotomous key: step-by-step identification tool using paired statements (usually yes/no or either/or choices) about observable characteristics, leading user to correct identification.
Use a dichotomous key: given a key for identifying trees or insects, follow paired choices based on characteristics (leaf shape, number of legs, presence of wings) to identify an unknown organism.

Create a simple dichotomous key: for a set of familiar organisms (classroom pets, local trees, types of fruit), develop paired statements that separate them based on observable differences until each organism can be uniquely identified.

sub_topics.name: Modern Classification: Three Domains
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the current system recognizing three domains of life based on molecular and cellular evidence.

sub_topics.name: The Three Domains
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya based on fundamental differences.
example_tasks: Compare key features of three domains: Bacteria (prokaryotic, peptidoglycan cell walls, membrane lipids with ester linkages), Archaea (prokaryotic, no peptidoglycan, membrane lipids with ether linkages, live in extreme environments), Eukarya (eukaryotic, membrane-bound nucleus and organelles).

Explain molecular evidence for three domains: ribosomal RNA (rRNA) sequences show Archaea are more closely related to Eukarya than to Bacteria despite all being prokaryotic; revolutionized classification in 1970s-90s (Carl Woese).
Describe the tree of life: three domains diverged from common ancestor (LUCA - Last Universal Common Ancestor); Domain Bacteria and Domain Archaea split first, then Archaea and Eukarya diverged.

sub_topics.name: Six Kingdoms Within Three Domains
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how kingdoms fit within the domain system.
example_tasks: List six kingdoms: Domain Bacteria (Kingdom Eubacteria), Domain Archaea (Kingdom Archaebacteria), Domain Eukarya (Kingdoms Protista, Fungi, Plantae, Animalia).
Describe Kingdom Eubacteria: true bacteria, diverse metabolic capabilities, includes many pathogens and beneficial species, most familiar bacteria (E. coli, Streptococcus, cyanobacteria).

Describe Kingdom Archaebacteria: ancient bacteria, often live in extreme environments (hot springs, salt lakes, deep ocean vents, highly acidic/basic conditions), methanogens, halophiles, thermophiles.

sub_topics.name: Kingdom Protista
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the diverse and paraphyletic kingdom of eukaryotic microorganisms.
example_tasks: Describe Kingdom Protista: eukaryotic, mostly unicellular (some multicellular), extremely diverse group (not monophyletic), includes protozoa (animal-like), algae (plant-like), and slime molds (fungus-like).
Provide examples: amoeba (protozoan with pseudopods), paramecium (ciliated protozoan), euglena (has chloroplasts and flagellum), algae (kelp, diatoms, dinoflagellates), plasmodium (causes malaria).

Explain why Protista is problematic: not a natural evolutionary group (paraphyletic), organisms grouped together because they don't fit other kingdoms; modern molecular evidence suggests protists should be split into multiple kingdoms.

sub_topics.name: Kingdom Fungi
sub_topics.short_description: Examine characteristics of fungi and their ecological roles.
example_tasks: Describe Kingdom Fungi characteristics: eukaryotic, mostly multicellular (yeasts unicellular), heterotrophic (absorptive nutrition - secrete enzymes to digest food externally), cell walls made of chitin, reproduce via spores.
Describe fungal structure: body composed of thread-like hyphae forming mycelium network, fruiting bodies (mushrooms) are reproductive structures, most mass is underground mycelium.

Explain ecological roles: decomposers (break down dead organic matter, recycle nutrients), form mycorrhizal associations with plant roots (enhance nutrient uptake), some are pathogens (athlete's foot, crop diseases), some used in food production (yeast for bread/beer, mushrooms).

sub_topics.name: Kingdom Plantae
sub_topics.short_description: Understand characteristics that define plants and their evolutionary adaptations to land.
example_tasks: Describe Kingdom Plantae characteristics: eukaryotic, multicellular, autotrophic (photosynthetic with chloroplasts containing chlorophyll a and b), cell walls made of cellulose, alternation of generations life cycle.

Describe adaptations for life on land: cuticle (waxy coating prevents water loss), stomata (pores for gas exchange), vascular tissue (xylem and phloem for transport in larger plants), roots (anchor and absorb water), seeds (protect embryo).

List major plant groups with increasing complexity: bryophytes (mosses, no vascular tissue), seedless vascular plants (ferns), gymnosperms (conifers, naked seeds), angiosperms (flowering plants, seeds in fruit).

sub_topics.name: Kingdom Animalia
sub_topics.short_description: Examine characteristics of animals and major phyla.
example_tasks: Describe Kingdom Animalia characteristics: eukaryotic, multicellular, heterotrophic (ingestive nutrition - eat food then digest internally), lack cell walls, most have specialized tissues and organs, most can move, reproduce sexually.

List major animal phyla with distinguishing features: Porifera (sponges), Cnidaria (jellyfish, hydra), Platyhelminthes (flatworms), Nematoda (roundworms), Annelida (segmented worms), Mollusca (snails, clams, octopus), Arthropoda (insects, spiders, crustaceans), Echinodermata (sea stars, sea urchins), Chordata (vertebrates and relatives).

Describe key evolutionary innovations in animals: tissues (cnidarians), bilateral symmetry (flatworms), body cavity/coelom (annelids and higher), segmentation (annelids, arthropods, chordates), exoskeleton (arthropods), endoskeleton (echinoderms, chordates), vertebral column (vertebrates).

sub_topics.name: Phylogeny and Cladistics
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how evolutionary relationships are determined and represented.

sub_topics.name: Reading Phylogenetic Trees
sub_topics.short_description: Interpret diagrams showing evolutionary relationships among organisms.
example_tasks: Identify parts of phylogenetic tree: tips/leaves represent groups (species or higher taxa), branches represent lineages through time, nodes represent common ancestors, branch points show where lineages split (speciation events), root represents most ancient common ancestor.

Determine relationships: organisms sharing more recent common ancestor (node closer to tips) are more closely related than those sharing older common ancestor; sister groups share a node that no other group shares.

Understand what trees show and don't show: trees show patterns of descent (who is related to whom), not necessarily time scale or amount of change; longer branches don't necessarily mean more evolution unless specifically scaled.

sub_topics.name: Shared Derived Characteristics
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how evolutionary innovations are used to construct phylogenies.
example_tasks: Define shared derived characteristics (synapomorphies): traits that evolved in a common ancestor and are shared by its descendants but not by more distantly related groups; used to identify clades (monophyletic groups).

Distinguish from ancestral characteristics: ancestral traits are inherited from distant ancestors and shared by many groups (not useful for determining close relationships); example: vertebral column is derived characteristic of vertebrates but ancestral trait within mammals.

Practice using characteristics: if analyzing vertebrates, features like jaws (derived for gnathostomes), four limbs (derived for tetrapods), amniotic egg (derived for amniotes), hair (derived for mammals) define nested clades reflecting evolutionary history.

sub_topics.name: Constructing and Analyzing Cladograms
sub_topics.short_description: Build phylogenetic hypotheses based on shared characteristics.
example_tasks: Construct a simple cladogram: given a table of characteristics for several organisms, identify shared derived traits, arrange organisms so those sharing more traits are grouped together, mark on branches where each new trait evolved.
Interpret cladogram: identify which groups are most closely related (share most recent common ancestor), which traits are synapomorphies for which clades, what traits the common ancestor likely had.

Understand that cladograms are hypotheses: different characteristics or methods may produce different trees; scientists use multiple lines of evidence (morphology, DNA sequences, fossils) to determine most likely phylogeny; trees revised as new evidence discovered.

sub_topics.name: Molecular Phylogenetics
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how DNA and protein sequences reveal evolutionary relationships.
example_tasks: Explain molecular approach: compare DNA or protein sequences among organisms; more similar sequences indicate more recent common ancestor; differences accumulate through mutations over time.

Describe advantages of molecular data: objective and quantitative, can compare all organisms (even very different looking ones), can use many genes for robust phylogeny, can estimate divergence times with molecular clock.

Provide examples of molecular insights: DNA evidence shows whales are closely related to hippos (not other marine mammals), fungi are more closely related to animals than plants, birds are dinosaurs (descendants of theropods).

grade_9_10.name: Ecology & Ecosystems
grade_9_10.short_description: Biotic and abiotic factors, energy flow, and biogeochemical cycles. Students explore how organisms interact with each other and their environment, and how energy and matter cycle through ecosystems.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Ecology
