Describe CAP-cAMP mechanism: when glucose low, cAMP levels rise, cAMP binds CAP (catabolite activator protein), CAP-cAMP complex binds near lac promoter, enhances RNA polymerase binding, increases transcription.

Explain dual control of lac operon: requires both conditions (1) lactose present (removes repressor - negative control) AND (2) glucose absent (CAP-cAMP activates transcription - positive control); achieves fine-tuned regulation responding to nutrient availability.

sub_topics.name: Gene Regulation in Eukaryotes
sub_topics.short_description: Examine multiple levels of gene control in eukaryotic cells.

sub_topics.name: Chromatin Structure and Accessibility
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how DNA packaging affects gene expression.
example_tasks: Explain chromatin remodeling: DNA wrapped around histones; tight packing (heterochromatin) prevents transcription, loose packing (euchromatin) allows access; chromatin remodeling complexes can loosen or tighten DNA-histone association, controlling which genes are accessible.

Describe histone modifications: acetylation (adding acetyl groups to histones loosens chromatin, promotes transcription), methylation (can activate or repress depending on location), phosphorylation; modifications create 'histone code' that affects gene expression.

Explain DNA methylation: adding methyl groups to cytosine bases (especially in CpG islands near promoters) generally silences genes; stable and heritable through cell divisions; involved in long-term gene silencing, X-chromosome inactivation, genomic imprinting; abnormal methylation patterns in cancer.

sub_topics.name: Transcriptional Control
sub_topics.short_description: Understand regulation of RNA polymerase II activity.
example_tasks: Describe transcription factors: proteins that bind DNA and regulate transcription; general transcription factors (required for all genes, bind TATA box and recruit RNA polymerase), specific transcription factors (regulate particular genes, bind enhancers or silencers).

Explain enhancers and silencers: DNA sequences that increase (enhancers) or decrease (silencers) transcription; can be far from promoter (thousands of base pairs away), work in either orientation, function through DNA looping brings specific transcription factors near promoter.

Describe combinatorial control: typical eukaryotic gene regulated by multiple transcription factors binding multiple control elements; different combinations of factors in different cell types produce tissue-specific gene expression; allows precise control from same genome.

sub_topics.name: Post-Transcriptional Control
sub_topics.short_description: Understand regulation after transcription but before translation.
example_tasks: Explain alternative RNA splicing: different combinations of exons included or excluded from final mRNA; single gene produces multiple protein variants (isoforms); greatly increases protein diversity without increasing gene number; tissue-specific splicing produces proteins adapted to cell type.

Describe mRNA stability: how long mRNA lasts before degradation affects protein production; sequences in 5' and 3' UTRs (untranslated regions) affect stability; regulatory proteins and small RNAs can enhance or reduce mRNA lifetime.

Explain RNA interference (RNAi): small RNA molecules (microRNAs, siRNAs) complementary to mRNA sequences bind target mRNA, block translation or trigger degradation; naturally regulates gene expression; used as research tool and potential therapy.

sub_topics.name: Translational and Post-Translational Control
sub_topics.short_description: Understand regulation of protein synthesis and modification.
example_tasks: Describe translational control: regulatory proteins bind mRNA 5' UTR affecting ribosome binding and translation initiation; allows rapid response (mRNA present but protein not made until needed); example: ferritin (iron storage protein) translation regulated by iron availability.

Explain post-translational modifications: chemical changes to proteins after synthesis including phosphorylation (adding phosphate groups activates/deactivates proteins), cleavage (insulin activated by cutting), addition of carbohydrates or lipids, ubiquitination (marks for degradation).

Describe protein activation and degradation: proteins activated by removal of inhibitory sequences (proteolytic cleavage), inactivated by breakdown; proteasomes degrade proteins tagged with ubiquitin; allows rapid changes in protein activity and removal of damaged proteins.

sub_topics.name: Development and Differentiation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how gene regulation controls development and produces specialized cells.

sub_topics.name: Differential Gene Expression
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how cells with identical DNA become different.
example_tasks: Explain the principle: all cells in organism have same DNA (except gametes and some immune cells), different cell types express different genes, pattern of gene expression determines cell structure and function; liver cells express liver genes, neurons express neuron genes.

Describe determination and differentiation: determination (cell commits to particular developmental fate, not yet specialized), differentiation (cell becomes structurally and functionally specialized); determined cells respond differently to signals than undetermined cells.

Provide examples: during development, cells receive signals (morphogens) based on position, activate specific transcription factors, transcription factors turn on tissue-specific genes, cells differentiate into various types (muscle, nerve, skin, etc.); process is largely irreversible in most organisms.

sub_topics.name: Homeotic Genes and Body Plan
sub_topics.short_description: Examine master control genes that determine basic body structure.
example_tasks: Define homeotic genes: master regulatory genes that determine identity of body segments during development; mutations cause homeotic transformations (body part in wrong location, like leg where antenna should be in Drosophila).

Describe Hox genes: family of homeotic genes containing homeobox (180 base pair sequence encoding DNA-binding domain); found in all animals; controls anterior-posterior axis; gene order on chromosome matches body position (colinearity); demonstrates ancient evolutionary conservation.

Explain significance: small changes in timing or location of Hox gene expression can produce major evolutionary changes in body form; helps explain diversity of animal body plans; shows all animals share common genetic toolkit.

sub_topics.name: Pattern Formation and Morphogenesis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how organized structures emerge during development.
example_tasks: Explain positional information: cells determine their location in embryo by concentration gradients of signaling molecules (morphogens); morphogen concentration indicates position, activates position-appropriate genes; example: bicoid protein gradient in Drosophila embryo specifies anterior structures.

Describe induction: cells influence development of adjacent cells through chemical signals; responding cells must be competent (able to respond); example: optic vesicle induces overlying ectoderm to form lens.

Explain apoptosis in development: programmed cell death sculpts structures by removing cells; examples: separation of fingers and toes (removal of webbing), hollowing of organs, removal of tadpole tail during metamorphosis; controlled by specific genes.

sub_topics.name: Cancer Genetics
sub_topics.short_description: Examine genetic basis of cancer and how normal cell cycle control is disrupted.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Cancer Cells
sub_topics.short_description: Understand properties that distinguish cancer cells from normal cells.
example_tasks: List hallmarks of cancer: uncontrolled cell division (ignore stop signals), evade apoptosis (don't die when should), unlimited replicative potential (ignore Hayflick limit), sustained angiogenesis (promote blood vessel growth), tissue invasion and metastasis (spread to other parts of body), altered metabolism.

Explain loss of contact inhibition: normal cells stop dividing when touch neighbors, cancer cells continue dividing and pile up; normal cells anchor to extracellular matrix, cancer cells lose anchorage dependence.

Describe metastasis: cancer cells break away from primary tumor, enter bloodstream or lymphatic system, exit at distant site, establish secondary tumor; most cancer deaths result from metastatic tumors not primary tumor.

sub_topics.name: Oncogenes and Tumor Suppressor Genes
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the two classes of genes involved in cancer development.
example_tasks: Explain proto-oncogenes and oncogenes: proto-oncogenes are normal genes promoting cell division (growth factors, receptors, signal transduction proteins, transcription factors); mutations that increase activity convert them to oncogenes (cancer-causing); act dominantly (one mutated copy enough); like stuck accelerator.

Explain tumor suppressor genes: normal genes that inhibit cell division or promote apoptosis; mutations that inactivate them contribute to cancer; act recessively (both copies must be inactivated); examples: p53 (guardian of genome, triggers apoptosis if DNA damaged), RB (retinoblastoma gene, restrains cell cycle); like broken brakes.

Describe multi-hit hypothesis: cancer requires multiple mutations (typically 4-6) accumulating over time, affecting both oncogenes and tumor suppressors; explains why cancer incidence increases with age, why hereditary cancers occur earlier (already have one mutation), why carcinogens that damage DNA are dangerous.

sub_topics.name: Causes of Cancer
sub_topics.short_description: Identify factors that increase cancer risk by causing mutations.
example_tasks: Describe genetic factors: inherited mutations in tumor suppressors (BRCA1/BRCA2 increase breast cancer risk, Lynch syndrome increases colon cancer), inherited mutations in DNA repair genes (allow accumulation of mutations), family history; account for 5-10% of cancers.

Describe environmental factors: tobacco (lung, throat, bladder cancer), UV radiation (skin cancer), ionizing radiation (leukemia, thyroid cancer), certain chemicals (asbestos, benzene), certain viruses (HPV causes cervical cancer, hepatitis B/C cause liver cancer), diet and obesity; account for majority of cancers.

Explain carcinogenesis: process takes years or decades; initiated by mutation (DNA damaged by carcinogen), promoted by factors stimulating division of mutated cells, progression as additional mutations accumulate; prevention focuses on avoiding carcinogens, early detection improves outcomes.

sub_topics.name: Genomics and Bioinformatics
sub_topics.short_description: Explore study of entire genomes and computational analysis of biological data.

sub_topics.name: The Human Genome Project
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the landmark project to sequence the entire human genome.
example_tasks: Describe the project: international collaboration (1990-2003) to sequence all 3 billion base pairs of human DNA, identify all ~20,000-25,000 genes, make information publicly available; ahead of schedule and under budget, major scientific achievement.

Summarize key findings: humans have far fewer genes than expected (similar number to simpler organisms), only ~1.5% of genome codes for proteins, large amount of repetitive DNA and transposons, gene number doesn't correlate with complexity (complexity comes from alternative splicing, regulation), DNA 99.9% identical between individuals.

Describe impacts: revolutionized biology and medicine, enabled personalized medicine, comparative genomics, understanding of evolution, new diagnostic tests and treatments, raised ethical issues (privacy, discrimination, ownership of genetic information).

sub_topics.name: Comparative Genomics
sub_topics.short_description: Understand insights from comparing genomes of different organisms.
example_tasks: Explain approach: sequence and compare genomes from different species, identify similarities and differences, infer evolutionary relationships, identify functionally important sequences (conserved across species likely important).

Describe findings: many genes conserved across vast evolutionary distances (homologous genes in organisms from bacteria to humans), genome size doesn't correlate with complexity (some plants have larger genomes than humans), humans share ~99% with chimpanzees, ~85% with mice, ~60% with fruit flies.

Explain applications: identify disease genes (if gene conserved, study in model organisms), understand evolution (trace gene families, identify innovations), drug development (target genes shared with pathogens but different from human versions), agriculture (improve crops and livestock).

sub_topics.name: Functional Genomics
sub_topics.short_description: Understand approaches to determining gene function on genome-wide scale.
example_tasks: Describe gene expression profiling: DNA microarrays (gene chips) or RNA-seq measure expression of thousands of genes simultaneously, compare expression patterns between cell types or conditions, identify genes active in disease vs. healthy tissue.

Explain proteomics: study of all proteins expressed by genome, protein expression doesn't always match mRNA levels (post-transcriptional regulation), proteins are actual functional molecules, mass spectrometry identifies proteins in samples.

Describe systems biology: integrating data from genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics to understand how components interact, moving from individual genes to networks and pathways, computational modeling of biological systems.

sub_topics.name: Bioinformatics
sub_topics.short_description: Understand computational tools for analyzing biological data.
example_tasks: Explain need for bioinformatics: massive amounts of data generated (human genome is 3 billion base pairs), cannot analyze manually, need computational methods to store, organize, search, analyze, and interpret biological data.

Describe sequence alignment: comparing DNA or protein sequences to find similarities, identify conserved regions (likely functionally important), BLAST searches databases for similar sequences, helps predict function of unknown genes.

Describe other applications: genome annotation (identifying genes, regulatory elements), predicting protein structure from sequence, phylogenetic tree construction, designing drugs, analyzing gene expression data, modeling biological systems.

grade_11_12.name: Human Anatomy & Physiology I
grade_11_12.short_description: Integumentary, skeletal, and muscular systems. Students examine body covering, support framework, and movement systems in detail, understanding structure-function relationships.

sub_topics.name: The Integumentary System
sub_topics.short_description: Examine skin structure, accessory structures, and functions in detail.

sub_topics.name: Structure and Layers of Skin
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the three layers of skin and their components.
example_tasks: Describe epidermis: outermost layer, stratified squamous epithelium, avascular (no blood vessels), cells produced in deepest layer (stratum basale) push upward, undergo keratinization (fill with keratin protein), die, and eventually shed from surface (stratum corneum); protects against water loss, pathogens, UV radiation.

Describe dermis: middle layer, dense connective tissue, contains blood vessels, nerves, sensory receptors, hair follicles, glands, lymphatic vessels; papillary layer (upper, forms ridges creating fingerprints) and reticular layer (lower, dense collagen and elastic fibers provide strength and elasticity).

Describe hypodermis (subcutaneous layer): not technically part of skin but attaches skin to underlying tissues, adipose tissue (fat) provides insulation, energy storage, cushioning; thickness varies by location and individual.

sub_topics.name: Skin Cells and Pigmentation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand cell types in epidermis and factors determining skin color.
example_tasks: Describe keratinocytes: most abundant epidermal cells, produce keratin (tough fibrous protein), undergo keratinization as pushed toward surface, dead keratinized cells form protective layer that is waterproof.

Describe melanocytes: produce melanin (brown-black or red-yellow pigment), located in stratum basale, melanin transferred to keratinocytes, absorbs UV radiation protecting DNA from damage; sun exposure increases melanin production (tanning).

Explain skin color determination: melanin amount and type (all people have similar number of melanocytes, but amount and type of melanin produced varies), carotene (yellow-orange pigment from diet, accumulates in stratum corneum and fatty tissue), hemoglobin in dermal blood vessels (pinkish hue, more visible in light skin); genetic factors determine baseline, UV exposure causes darkening.

sub_topics.name: Accessory Structures: Hair, Nails, and Glands
sub_topics.short_description: Examine structures associated with skin.
example_tasks: Describe hair structure and function: shaft (visible part), root (embedded in follicle), hair bulb (growth region), composed of dead keratinized cells; functions include protection (scalp from UV, eyelashes protect eyes), insulation, sensory reception (movement detected by receptors around follicle); arrector pili muscles cause hair to stand up (goosebumps).

Describe nail structure: hard plate of tightly packed keratinized cells on dorsal surface of finger/toe tips, nail body (visible), nail root (growth region under skin), cuticle (seals edge), nail bed (epithelium underneath); protect fingertips, enhance dexterity, used for grasping.

Compare gland types: eccrine sweat glands (all over body, open to surface, watery sweat for cooling), apocrine sweat glands (armpits, groin, open to hair follicles, thicker secretion, bacterial breakdown causes body odor), sebaceous glands (associated with hair follicles, produce sebum that oils skin and hair, prevents drying).

sub_topics.name: Skin Functions and Homeostasis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand multiple roles of integumentary system in maintaining body health.
example_tasks: Explain temperature regulation: blood vessels in dermis dilate (vasodilation) to release heat or constrict (vasoconstriction) to conserve heat, sweat glands produce sweat that cools through evaporation, adipose layer insulates; maintains body temperature around 37°C.

Explain sensory reception: contains receptors for touch (Meissner's corpuscles), pressure (Pacinian corpuscles), temperature (thermoreceptors), pain (nociceptors); provides information about external environment, enables interaction and protection.

Describe other functions: synthesis of vitamin D (UV radiation converts precursor in skin to vitamin D, essential for calcium absorption), excretion (small amounts of waste in sweat), blood reservoir (dermal blood vessels can hold significant blood volume), immunity (Langerhans cells detect pathogens).

sub_topics.name: Skin Damage and Repair
sub_topics.short_description: Understand wound healing and effects of aging on skin.
example_tasks: Describe wound healing stages: (1) inflammation (blood clots form, vessels dilate, white blood cells clean wound), (2) organization/proliferation (granulation tissue forms, epithelial cells multiply and migrate covering wound), (3) regeneration/remodeling (scab falls off, connective tissue replaces granulation tissue, collagen reorganizes); deep wounds form scar tissue.

Explain factors affecting healing: age (slower in elderly), nutrition (need protein, vitamin C, zinc), blood circulation (adequate oxygen and nutrients needed), infection (delays healing), size and depth (larger/deeper wounds take longer).

Describe skin cancer types: basal cell carcinoma (most common, rarely metastasizes, easily treated), squamous cell carcinoma (can metastasize if untreated), melanoma (least common but most dangerous, arises from melanocytes, high metastasis rate); UV exposure major risk factor; ABCDE rule (Asymmetry, Border irregular, Color varied, Diameter >6mm, Evolving) helps identify suspicious moles.

sub_topics.name: The Skeletal System
sub_topics.short_description: Examine bone structure, function, and the organization of the human skeleton.

sub_topics.name: Functions of the Skeletal System
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the multiple roles bones play in the body.
example_tasks: Describe structural functions: support (framework for body, attachment for soft tissues), protection (skull protects brain, ribs protect heart and lungs, vertebrae protect spinal cord), movement (bones act as levers, muscles pull on bones to produce movement).

Describe metabolic functions: mineral storage (bones store 99% of body's calcium and much phosphorus, released into blood when needed), lipid storage (yellow bone marrow stores triglycerides as energy reserve), blood cell production (hematopoiesis in red bone marrow produces blood cells).

Explain clinical relevance: osteoporosis (decreased bone density, fracture risk), rickets (vitamin D deficiency affecting bone mineralization in children), bone marrow transplants (treat leukemia and other disorders), calcium homeostasis essential for muscle and nerve function.

sub_topics.name: Bone Tissue Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Understand cellular and molecular composition of bone tissue.
example_tasks: Describe bone cells: osteoblasts (build bone, secrete matrix), osteocytes (mature bone cells, maintain matrix, sense mechanical stress), osteoclasts (break down bone for remodeling and mineral release); balance between osteoblast and osteoclast activity determines whether bone is built up or broken down.

Describe bone matrix: organic components (collagen fibers provide flexibility and tensile strength) and inorganic components (calcium phosphate crystals/hydroxyapatite provide hardness and compressive strength); combination makes bone both strong and slightly flexible.

Compare compact bone (dense, forms outer shell, organized in osteons/Haversian systems with central canal containing blood vessels and nerves, concentric lamellae of matrix) and spongy bone (lattice of trabeculae following stress lines, spaces filled with red bone marrow, lighter weight, found at ends of long bones and inside flat bones).

sub_topics.name: Types and Structure of Bones
sub_topics.short_description: Classify bones by shape and examine long bone anatomy.
example_tasks: Classify bones by shape: long bones (longer than wide, limb bones like femur, humerus), short bones (roughly cube-shaped, wrist and ankle bones), flat bones (thin and flat, skull bones, ribs, sternum), irregular bones (complex shape, vertebrae, facial bones), sesamoid bones (within tendons, like patella).

Describe long bone structure: diaphysis (shaft, compact bone surrounding medullary cavity containing yellow marrow), epiphyses (ends, spongy bone with thin compact bone shell, red marrow), epiphyseal plate/line (growth plate in children, becomes line in adults when growth stops), periosteum (outer membrane, site of attachment for tendons/ligaments, contains osteoblasts for growth and repair), endosteum (lines medullary cavity).

Explain articular cartilage: hyaline cartilage covering ends of bones in joints, smooth surface reduces friction, absorbs shock, no blood vessels (receives nutrients from synovial fluid); damage causes arthritis.

sub_topics.name: Bone Growth and Remodeling
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how bones grow, develop, and change throughout life.
example_tasks: Describe ossification (bone formation): intramembranous (bones form directly from mesenchyme, flat bones like skull), endochondral (bones develop from hyaline cartilage model, most bones including long bones; cartilage replaced by bone tissue starting in center, progressing toward ends).

Explain longitudinal growth: occurs at epiphyseal plates; cartilage cells on epiphyseal side proliferate, cartilage calcifies, osteoblasts replace calcified cartilage with bone on diaphyseal side; continues until late teens/early twenties when epiphyseal plates close (become epiphyseal lines), bones can no longer lengthen; growth hormone and sex hormones regulate.

Describe bone remodeling: continuous throughout life, osteoclasts resorb old bone, osteoblasts deposit new bone; functions include reshaping in response to stress (Wolff's law - bone strengthens where stressed), repair of microfractures, maintaining calcium homeostasis; physical activity stimulates deposition, immobility causes loss.

sub_topics.name: Axial Skeleton
sub_topics.short_description: Examine bones of skull, vertebral column, and thoracic cage.
example_tasks: Describe skull bones: cranial bones (8 bones including frontal, parietal, temporal, occipital, protect brain), facial bones (14 bones including maxilla, mandible, zygomatic, support face, form cavities for sense organs); sutures (immovable joints) connect most skull bones, only mandible moves; fontanels (soft spots) in infant skull allow compression during birth, close by age 2.

Describe vertebral column: 26 bones (7 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 1 sacrum formed from 5 fused, 1 coccyx formed from 4 fused); functions include support body weight, protect spinal cord, provide attachment for ribs and muscles, allow movement; intervertebral discs (fibrocartilage) between vertebrae cushion and allow movement.

Describe thoracic cage: 12 pairs of ribs (true ribs attach directly to sternum via costal cartilages, false ribs attach indirectly or not at all), sternum (breastbone); protects heart and lungs, supports shoulder girdle, provides attachment for respiratory muscles; allows breathing by expanding and contracting.

sub_topics.name: Appendicular Skeleton
sub_topics.short_description: Examine bones of limbs and girdles.
example_tasks: Describe pectoral girdle: clavicle (collarbone) and scapula (shoulder blade) attach upper limb to axial skeleton; highly mobile joint allows wide range of arm motion; only bony attachment is clavicle to sternum (other connections via muscles/ligaments).

Describe upper limb bones: humerus (arm), radius and ulna (forearm, radius on thumb side), carpals (8 wrist bones), metacarpals (5 hand bones), phalanges (14 finger bones - 3 per finger, 2 per thumb); arrangement allows precision movements and grasping.

Describe pelvic girdle and lower limb: pelvis (hip bones formed from ilium, ischium, pubis, plus sacrum, strong and stable, supports body weight, protects pelvic organs); femur (thigh, longest/strongest bone), patella (kneecap), tibia and fibula (leg), tarsals (7 ankle bones), metatarsals (5 foot bones), phalanges (14 toe bones); adapted for bearing weight and locomotion.

sub_topics.name: Joints and Articulations
sub_topics.short_description: Understand structure, classification, and function of joints.

sub_topics.name: Classification of Joints
sub_topics.short_description: Classify joints by structure and function.
example_tasks: Classify by structure: fibrous (bones connected by dense connective tissue, no cavity, examples: sutures in skull, syndesmoses like between tibia-fibula), cartilaginous (bones connected by cartilage, no cavity, examples: epiphyseal plates, pubic symphysis, intervertebral discs), synovial (bones separated by fluid-filled cavity, most joints, most movable).

Classify by function: synarthrosis (immovable, examples: skull sutures, tooth in socket), amphiarthrosis (slightly movable, examples: intervertebral joints, pubic symphysis), diarthrosis (freely movable, all synovial joints).

Explain relationship: joint structure determines function; fibrous joints generally immovable, cartilaginous slightly movable, synovial freely movable; synovial joints sacrifice stability for mobility.

sub_topics.name: Synovial Joints
sub_topics.short_description: Examine structure and types of freely movable joints.
example_tasks: Describe synovial joint structure: articular cartilage (hyaline cartilage covering bone ends, reduces friction), joint cavity (fluid-filled space), synovial membrane (lines cavity, secretes synovial fluid for lubrication and nutrition), articular capsule (fibrous outer layer provides strength), reinforcing ligaments (capsular or extracapsular, prevent excessive movement).

Classify synovial joints by shape: hinge (elbow, knee - flexion/extension only), pivot (atlas-axis, radioulnar - rotation), ball-and-socket (shoulder, hip - movement in all planes), condyloid (knuckles, wrist - movement in two planes but no rotation), saddle (thumb - biaxial movement), plane (intercarpal - gliding movements).

Describe common movements: flexion (decrease angle), extension (increase angle), abduction (away from midline), adduction (toward midline), rotation (around long axis), circumduction (circular movement), pronation/supination (forearm rotation), dorsiflexion/plantarflexion (ankle).

sub_topics.name: Joint Disorders and Injuries
sub_topics.short_description: Understand common joint problems and treatments.
example_tasks: Describe arthritis types: osteoarthritis (wear-and-tear, cartilage degenerates, most common, usually affects older adults, weight-bearing joints), rheumatoid arthritis (autoimmune, synovial membrane inflamed, can affect young people, often symmetrical), gouty arthritis (uric acid crystals deposit in joints, very painful, often affects big toe).

Describe common injuries: sprain (ligament stretched or torn), dislocation (bone forced out of normal position), torn cartilage (menisci in knee especially vulnerable), bursitis (inflammation of bursa, fluid-filled sac that reduces friction), tendonitis (inflammation of tendon); treatment often includes RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation).

Explain joint replacement: severely damaged joints (especially hip and knee) can be surgically replaced with artificial joints (prostheses); restores mobility and reduces pain; materials include metal, plastic, ceramic; successful for many patients but has risks and limited lifespan.

sub_topics.name: The Muscular System
sub_topics.short_description: Examine muscle tissue structure, contraction mechanism, and major skeletal muscles.

sub_topics.name: Muscle Tissue Types and Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Review muscle types and general muscle functions.
example_tasks: Compare three muscle types: skeletal (attached to bones, voluntary, striated, multinucleate), cardiac (heart wall, involuntary, striated, branched with intercalated discs), smooth (walls of hollow organs, involuntary, non-striated, spindle-shaped); all produce movement through contraction.

List muscle functions: movement (locomotion, manipulation, facial expression), posture maintenance (continuous partial contraction holds body upright), joint stabilization (tendons cross joints providing support), heat generation (muscle contraction produces heat, important for maintaining body temperature).

Explain muscle properties: excitability (responds to stimuli), contractility (shortens forcefully), extensibility (can be stretched), elasticity (returns to original length after stretching); these properties enable muscle to function effectively.

sub_topics.name: Skeletal Muscle Anatomy
sub_topics.short_description: Understand organization from whole muscle to molecular level.
example_tasks: Describe muscle organization levels: whole muscle (organ) → fascicles (bundles of fibers) → muscle fiber (cell) → myofibril (organelle) → myofilaments (protein filaments - thick myosin, thin actin); connective tissue wraps each level (epimysium, perimysium, endomysium) and continues as tendon.

Describe muscle fiber structure: elongated cell (10-100 μm diameter, up to 30 cm long), multinucleate (nuclei under sarcolemma/plasma membrane), packed with myofibrils aligned in parallel, sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR, specialized smooth ER) stores calcium, T-tubules (extensions of sarcolemma) conduct signals deep into fiber.

Describe sarcomere: functional unit of contraction, repeating segment between two Z-lines, contains overlapping thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments; I band (thin filaments only), A band (thick filaments, includes overlap), H zone (thick only, center), M line (center, anchors thick filaments); contraction shortens sarcomere as filaments slide past each other.

sub_topics.name: Sliding Filament Theory of Contraction
sub_topics.short_description: Understand molecular mechanism of muscle contraction.
example_tasks: Explain the mechanism: thick and thin filaments don't change length but slide past each other; myosin heads form cross-bridges with actin, pull actin toward sarcomere center (power stroke), detach, reattach farther along actin, repeat (ratcheting); sarcomeres shorten, muscle contracts.

Describe role of ATP: myosin head hydrolyzes ATP → ADP + Pi (energizes head), head binds actin, releases Pi (power stroke, pulls actin), releases ADP, binds new ATP (allows detachment); without ATP, heads remain attached (rigor mortis after death when ATP depleted).

Explain role of calcium and regulatory proteins: tropomyosin blocks myosin binding sites on actin, troponin binds calcium and moves tropomyosin, exposing binding sites; when calcium present (during contraction), cross-bridges form; when calcium removed (relaxation), binding sites covered again, contraction stops.

sub_topics.name: Excitation-Contraction Coupling
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how nerve signal triggers muscle contraction.
example_tasks: Describe neuromuscular junction: motor neuron axon terminal (synaptic knob) close to muscle fiber, small gap (synaptic cleft), motor end plate (region of sarcolemma with receptors); neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) released from neuron, binds receptors on muscle, triggers action potential.

Trace the sequence: (1) action potential arrives at axon terminal, (2) calcium enters axon terminal, (3) ACh released into cleft, (4) ACh binds receptors, (5) muscle fiber action potential generated, (6) action potential spreads along sarcolemma and down T-tubules, (7) SR releases calcium into sarcoplasm, (8) calcium binds troponin, (9) contraction occurs.

Explain relaxation: nerve signal stops → no more ACh released → ACh broken down by acetylcholinesterase → no muscle action potential → calcium actively pumped back into SR (requires ATP) → calcium leaves troponin → tropomyosin blocks binding sites → cross-bridges detach → muscle relaxes (passively lengthened by opposing muscles or gravity).

sub_topics.name: Muscle Metabolism and Fatigue
sub_topics.short_description: Understand energy sources for muscle contraction and causes of fatigue.
example_tasks: Describe ATP sources: (1) stored ATP (few seconds only), (2) creatine phosphate (CP → C + P, transfers phosphate to ADP making ATP, lasts ~15 seconds), (3) anaerobic glycolysis (glucose → lactic acid + 2 ATP, fast but inefficient, few minutes), (4) aerobic respiration (glucose/fatty acids + O₂ → ATP, slow but efficient, prolonged activity); muscles switch between sources based on intensity and duration.

Explain muscle fatigue: reduced ability to contract after prolonged activity; causes include: ATP depletion (if production can't keep up), lactic acid accumulation (lowers pH, inhibits enzymes), ion imbalances (potassium, calcium), central nervous system factors (reduced motor neuron output); rest allows recovery.

Compare muscle fiber types: slow oxidative (Type I, red, many mitochondria and capillaries, fatigue-resistant, aerobic metabolism, posture/endurance), fast oxidative (Type IIa, intermediate properties, moderate fatigue resistance), fast glycolytic (Type IIb, white, few mitochondria, fatigue quickly, anaerobic metabolism, powerful rapid movements); most muscles have mixture, proportion varies between individuals and can change with training.

sub_topics.name: Major Skeletal Muscles
sub_topics.short_description: Identify location and function of major muscles of the body.
example_tasks: Identify head/neck muscles: frontalis (raises eyebrows), orbicularis oculi (closes eye), orbicularis oris (closes lips), masseter (closes jaw), temporalis (closes jaw), sternocleidomastoid (flexes/rotates head), trapezius (extends head, moves scapula).

Identify trunk muscles: pectoralis major (adducts/flexes arm), latissimus dorsi (extends/adducts arm), deltoid (abducts arm), external obliques (compress abdomen, flex/rotate trunk), rectus abdominis (flexes vertebral column, compresses abdomen, 'six-pack'), erector spinae (extends back).

Identify limb muscles: biceps brachii (flexes elbow), triceps brachii (extends elbow), brachioradialis (flexes elbow), gluteus maximus (extends hip), quadriceps group (extend knee), hamstring group (flex knee, extend hip), gastrocnemius (plantar flexes ankle), tibialis anterior (dorsiflexes ankle); understand antagonistic pairs work together for smooth movement.

grade_11_12.name: Human Anatomy & Physiology II
grade_11_12.short_description: Nervous and endocrine systems. Students explore the body's two major control and communication systems, examining how they coordinate responses and maintain homeostasis.

sub_topics.name: Organization of the Nervous System
sub_topics.short_description: Understand structural and functional divisions of the nervous system.

sub_topics.name: Divisions of the Nervous System
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish between CNS, PNS, and functional subdivisions.
example_tasks: Describe structural divisions: central nervous system (CNS - brain and spinal cord, integration and command center) and peripheral nervous system (PNS - all neural tissue outside CNS including cranial nerves, spinal nerves, ganglia, sensory receptors; communication lines).

Describe functional divisions of PNS: sensory/afferent division (conducts impulses from receptors to CNS, includes somatic sensory from skin/muscles/joints and visceral sensory from organs) and motor/efferent division (conducts impulses from CNS to effectors).

Subdivide motor division: somatic nervous system (voluntary, controls skeletal muscles, conscious control) and autonomic nervous system (involuntary, controls smooth muscle, cardiac muscle, glands, subconscious regulation); autonomic further divided into sympathetic ('fight or flight') and parasympathetic ('rest and digest').

sub_topics.name: Neuron Structure and Classification
sub_topics.short_description: Understand anatomy and types of neurons.
example_tasks: Describe neuron structure: cell body/soma (contains nucleus and organelles), dendrites (short branched extensions, receive signals from other neurons), axon (single long extension, transmits signals away from cell body, may have myelin sheath for faster conduction), axon terminals (enlarged tips, release neurotransmitters).

Classify by structure: multipolar (one axon, many dendrites, most common, include motor neurons and interneurons), bipolar (one axon, one dendrite, rare, found in retina and olfactory epithelium), unipolar (single process that divides, sensory neurons).

Classify by function: sensory/afferent neurons (carry signals to CNS), motor/efferent neurons (carry signals from CNS to effectors), interneurons/association neurons (lie between sensory and motor, entirely in CNS, outnumber other types, perform integration/processing).

sub_topics.name: Supporting Cells (Neuroglia)
sub_topics.short_description: Understand glial cells and their functions.
example_tasks: Describe CNS neuroglia: astrocytes (most abundant, form blood-brain barrier, regulate extracellular environment, support neurons), oligodendrocytes (form myelin sheaths around CNS axons, one cell myelinates multiple axons), microglia (immune function, phagocytize pathogens and debris), ependymal cells (line ventricles, produce cerebrospinal fluid).

Describe PNS neuroglia: Schwann cells (form myelin sheaths around PNS axons, one cell per internode, guide nerve regeneration), satellite cells (surround neuron cell bodies in ganglia, regulate environment).

Explain myelin sheath: multiple layers of plasma membrane wrapped around axon, acts as insulation, increases conduction speed; gaps between adjacent cells are nodes of Ranvier where action potential regenerates; multiple sclerosis involves myelin destruction, slowing/blocking transmission.

sub_topics.name: Neurophysiology: Electrical Signals
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how neurons generate and transmit electrical signals.

sub_topics.name: Resting Membrane Potential
sub_topics.short_description: Understand electrical properties of unstimulated neurons.
example_tasks: Explain resting potential: inside of neuron approximately -70 mV relative to outside when not stimulated; results from unequal ion distribution (high K⁺ inside, high Na⁺ outside) and selective permeability (membrane more permeable to K⁺ than Na⁺).

Describe role of sodium-potassium pump: actively transports 3 Na⁺ out and 2 K⁺ in (using ATP), maintains concentration gradients; without it, ions would equilibrate and neuron couldn't signal; chemical gradient opposes electrical gradient creating balance.

Explain significance: polarized membrane is ready to respond to stimulus, like loaded spring; all neurons maintain similar resting potentials; changes in membrane potential are basis of neural signals.

sub_topics.name: Graded Potentials and Action Potentials
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish between local and long-distance signals.
example_tasks: Compare graded potentials: small local changes in membrane potential (depolarization - less negative, hyperpolarization - more negative), magnitude varies with stimulus strength, decrease with distance, can be summed, occur in dendrites and cell body in response to stimuli.

Describe action potential: brief reversal of membrane potential (inside becomes positive, ~+30 mV), all-or-none (occurs fully if threshold reached, ~-55 mV, or not at all), doesn't decrease with distance, basis of long-distance neural communication, occurs along axon.

Explain threshold and all-or-none principle: if depolarization reaches threshold, voltage-gated channels open triggering action potential; subthreshold stimuli produce only graded potentials; stronger stimuli don't produce larger action potentials but higher frequency of action potentials.

sub_topics.name: Action Potential Mechanism
sub_topics.short_description: Understand ion movements during action potential.
example_tasks: Describe depolarization phase: voltage-gated Na⁺ channels open, Na⁺ rushes in (down concentration and electrical gradients), membrane potential becomes positive (approaches Na⁺ equilibrium potential of +60 mV).

Describe repolarization phase: Na⁺ channels close (inactivate), voltage-gated K⁺ channels open, K⁺ flows out, membrane potential returns toward negative; K⁺ channels close slowly causing brief hyperpolarization (undershoot below resting potential).

Explain refractory periods: absolute refractory period (Na⁺ channels inactivated, second action potential impossible, ensures unidirectional propagation), relative refractory period (during hyperpolarization, stronger stimulus required, limits maximum firing frequency).

sub_topics.name: Propagation of Action Potentials
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how signals travel along axons.
example_tasks: Explain continuous conduction: in unmyelinated axons, action potential at one location triggers action potential in adjacent region, wave of depolarization moves along entire axon, relatively slow (~1 m/s).

Explain saltatory conduction: in myelinated axons, action potential jumps from node to node (nodes of Ranvier), much faster (~100 m/s), more energy-efficient (fewer ions move so less ATP needed for pumps), myelin acts as insulation preventing ion flow between nodes.

Describe factors affecting speed: presence of myelin (saltatory faster), axon diameter (larger diameter = faster, less resistance), temperature (warmer = faster, cold slows or blocks); neurodegenerative diseases often involve demyelination, slowing conduction.

sub_topics.name: Synaptic Transmission
sub_topics.short_description: Understand communication between neurons and between neurons and effectors.

sub_topics.name: Structure of Chemical Synapses
sub_topics.short_description: Examine components of synaptic connections.
example_tasks: Identify synapse components: presynaptic neuron (sends signal, axon terminal contains synaptic vesicles filled with neurotransmitter), synaptic cleft (narrow gap ~20-40 nm, separates neurons), postsynaptic neuron (receives signal, membrane contains receptors).
Explain one-way transmission: neurotransmitter only released from presynaptic side, receptors only on postsynaptic side, ensures signal travels in one direction; allows complex neural circuits.
Describe synaptic delay: time for neurotransmitter release, diffusion, binding (~0.5 ms); explains why polysynaptic reflex slower than monosynaptic; limits maximum speed of neural processing.

sub_topics.name: Events in Synaptic Transmission
sub_topics.short_description: Trace the steps from action potential to postsynaptic response.
example_tasks: Trace the sequence: (1) action potential arrives at axon terminal, (2) voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels open, Ca²⁺ enters, (3) Ca²⁺ triggers exocytosis of synaptic vesicles, neurotransmitter released into cleft, (4) neurotransmitter binds postsynaptic receptors, (5) ion channels open or second messenger cascades triggered, (6) postsynaptic potential generated.

Explain signal termination: neurotransmitter removed from cleft by (1) enzymatic degradation (e.g., acetylcholinesterase breaks down ACh), (2) reuptake into presynaptic terminal or glial cells (e.g., serotonin reuptake), (3) diffusion away; allows neurons to respond to new signals.

Describe postsynaptic potentials: excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP - depolarization, brings closer to threshold, increases likelihood of action potential) and inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP - hyperpolarization, moves away from threshold, decreases likelihood); single EPSP usually insufficient, must be summed.

sub_topics.name: Major Neurotransmitters
sub_topics.short_description: Identify important neurotransmitters and their functions.
example_tasks: Describe acetylcholine (ACh): released at neuromuscular junctions (excitatory, triggers muscle contraction), autonomic synapses, many CNS synapses; involved in muscle activation, arousal, attention, memory; degraded by acetylcholinesterase; deficiency in Alzheimer's disease.

Describe biogenic amines: norepinephrine (arousal, alertness, mood), dopamine (movement, motivation, reward, pleasure; deficiency in Parkinson's, excess in schizophrenia), serotonin (mood, sleep, appetite; SSRIs increase availability to treat depression), histamine (wakefulness, inflammatory response).

Describe amino acid neurotransmitters: glutamate (major excitatory neurotransmitter in CNS, learning and memory, excess can cause excitotoxicity), GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid, major inhibitory neurotransmitter in CNS, reduces anxiety; anti-anxiety drugs enhance GABA action), glycine (inhibitory in spinal cord).

sub_topics.name: Integration of Neural Signals
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how neurons process multiple inputs.
example_tasks: Explain temporal summation: rapid repeated stimulation from single presynaptic neuron, EPSPs occur before previous ones decay, summed depolarization may reach threshold; allows weak stimulus to trigger response if repeated.
Explain spatial summation: simultaneous stimulation from multiple presynaptic neurons, EPSPs from different locations add together; allows multiple weak inputs to collectively trigger response.

Describe integration: postsynaptic neuron integrates all EPSPs and IPSPs (inhibitory cancel excitatory), if net depolarization reaches threshold at axon hillock (trigger zone with highest density of voltage-gated Na⁺ channels), action potential initiated; allows complex processing, decision-making.

sub_topics.name: Central Nervous System: Brain and Spinal Cord
sub_topics.short_description: Examine structure and function of CNS components.

sub_topics.name: Protection of the CNS
sub_topics.short_description: Understand bones, meninges, and cerebrospinal fluid that protect CNS.
example_tasks: Describe bony protection: skull (cranial bones) protects brain, vertebral column protects spinal cord; provides hard physical barrier against trauma.

Describe meninges (three membranes, superficial to deep): dura mater (tough outer layer attached to bone), arachnoid mater (middle web-like layer), pia mater (delicate inner layer adhering to brain/cord surface); meningitis is inflammation of meninges (usually bacterial or viral).

Describe cerebrospinal fluid (CSF): clear fluid produced by choroid plexuses in brain ventricles, circulates through ventricles and subarachnoid space (between arachnoid and pia), reabsorbed into blood; functions include cushioning (shock absorption), chemical protection (optimal environment), waste removal; analyzed in spinal tap to diagnose infections and other conditions.

sub_topics.name: Major Brain Regions and Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Identify main brain structures and their roles.
example_tasks: Describe cerebrum: largest part of brain, divided into left and right hemispheres (connected by corpus callosum), surface is cerebral cortex (gray matter, neuron cell bodies), interior white matter (myelinated axons), deep gray matter (basal nuclei); functions include conscious thought, sensory perception, voluntary movement, memory, language.

Describe diencephalon: includes thalamus (relay station for sensory information to cortex, regulates consciousness), hypothalamus (homeostatic control center, regulates temperature, hunger, thirst, circadian rhythms; controls pituitary gland), epithalamus (includes pineal gland producing melatonin).

Describe brain stem: midbrain (visual and auditory reflexes), pons (relay between cerebrum and cerebellum, respiratory control), medulla oblongata (autonomic control of heart rate, blood pressure, breathing, coughing, swallowing); ascending and descending tracts pass through; damage often fatal as it controls vital functions.

sub_topics.name: Cerebellum
sub_topics.short_description: Understand structure and role in motor coordination.
example_tasks: Describe structure: located posterior to brain stem, two hemispheres with convoluted surface, extensive connections with cerebral cortex, brain stem, and spinal cord; has more neurons than rest of brain combined but smaller volume.

Explain functions: coordinates voluntary movements (smooth, accurate motion), maintains posture and balance, motor learning (procedural memory like riding bike), compares intended movement with actual movement, makes corrections.

Describe effects of damage: ataxia (uncoordinated movements), intention tremor (tremor during voluntary movement), impaired balance, slurred speech; doesn't cause paralysis (cerebral cortex initiates movement) but makes movements uncoordinated.

sub_topics.name: Functional Areas of Cerebral Cortex
sub_topics.short_description: Map specialized regions of the cortex.
example_tasks: Identify lobes: frontal (front, separated by central sulcus), parietal (top/back, behind central sulcus), temporal (side, below lateral sulcus), occipital (very back); each lobe associated with different functions.

Describe primary areas: primary motor cortex (frontal, precentral gyrus, controls voluntary movements, organized somatotopically - 'motor homunculus'), primary somatosensory cortex (parietal, postcentral gyrus, receives touch/pressure/pain/temperature, somatotopic organization), primary visual cortex (occipital, receives visual information), primary auditory cortex (temporal, receives sound information).

Describe association areas: integrate information from primary areas and other sources, enable complex cognitive functions; examples: premotor cortex (plans movements), Broca's area (speech production, frontal), Wernicke's area (language comprehension, temporal), prefrontal cortex (personality, decision-making, working memory, executive functions).

sub_topics.name: Spinal Cord Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Examine anatomy and role in reflexes and communication.
example_tasks: Describe structure: extends from medulla to L1-L2 vertebra, protected by vertebral column, 31 pairs of spinal nerves emerge; internal gray matter (H-shaped, neuron cell bodies, dorsal horns receive sensory, ventral horns contain motor) surrounded by white matter (myelinated axons organized in columns/tracts).

Explain ascending tracts: carry sensory information to brain (pain, temperature, touch, pressure, proprioception); different tracts for different modalities; some cross to opposite side (decussation) before reaching brain, explaining why left brain controls right side.

Explain descending tracts: carry motor commands from brain to skeletal muscles; include pyramidal tracts (direct voluntary control) and extrapyramidal tracts (posture, balance, involuntary movements); most cross in medulla, so left brain controls right side of body.

sub_topics.name: Spinal Reflexes
sub_topics.short_description: Understand rapid automatic responses to stimuli.
example_tasks: Define reflex arc components: receptor (detects stimulus), sensory neuron (carries signal to CNS), integration center (CNS, may be single synapse or involve interneurons), motor neuron (carries signal to effector), effector (muscle or gland produces response); fastest possible response bypasses conscious control.

Describe stretch reflex (monosynaptic): muscle spindles detect stretch, sensory neuron synapses directly on motor neuron in spinal cord, motor neuron stimulates same muscle to contract, opposing stretch; example: patellar (knee-jerk) reflex; maintains posture, only one synapse (fastest reflex).

Describe withdrawal reflex (polysynaptic): pain receptors detect harmful stimulus, sensory neuron activates interneurons in spinal cord, interneurons stimulate motor neurons to flexor muscles (withdraw limb) and inhibit extensors, simultaneously crossed-extensor reflex extends opposite limb (maintain balance); protective, involves multiple synapses, conscious awareness comes later.

sub_topics.name: Peripheral Nervous System
sub_topics.short_description: Examine nerves and functional divisions outside CNS.

sub_topics.name: Structure and Classification of Nerves
sub_topics.short_description: Understand nerve anatomy and types.
example_tasks: Describe nerve structure: bundle of axons wrapped in connective tissue; endoneurium (around individual axons), perineurium (around fascicles/bundles of axons), epineurium (around entire nerve); blood vessels run through nerves; mixture of sensory and motor axons.

Classify nerves functionally: sensory nerves (afferent only, carry sensory to CNS), motor nerves (efferent only, carry commands from CNS), mixed nerves (both afferent and efferent, most nerves are mixed).

Describe regeneration: peripheral nerves can regenerate if cell body intact; Schwann cells form regeneration tube, axon sprouts and regrows at ~1-2 mm/day; CNS neurons cannot regenerate (oligodendrocytes don't form regeneration tubes, scar tissue forms); explains why spinal cord injuries cause permanent paralysis.

sub_topics.name: Cranial and Spinal Nerves
sub_topics.short_description: Identify the 12 cranial nerves and organization of spinal nerves.
example_tasks: Identify cranial nerves (12 pairs): I-Olfactory (smell), II-Optic (vision), III-Oculomotor (eye movement), IV-Trochlear (eye movement), V-Trigeminal (face sensation, chewing), VI-Abducens (eye movement), VII-Facial (facial expression, taste), VIII-Vestibulocochlear (hearing, balance), IX-Glossopharyngeal (taste, swallowing), X-Vagus (parasympathetic to organs), XI-Accessory (neck/shoulder movement), XII-Hypoglossal (tongue movement).

Describe spinal nerves: 31 pairs (8 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 5 sacral, 1 coccygeal), emerge from spinal cord through intervertebral foramina, formed by union of dorsal root (sensory, has dorsal root ganglion containing sensory neuron cell bodies) and ventral root (motor).

Explain nerve plexuses: networks where spinal nerves intermingle and redistribute (cervical, brachial, lumbar, sacral plexuses); fibers from several spinal segments combine into named nerves serving specific body regions; example: sciatic nerve from sacral plexus is largest nerve, serves leg.

sub_topics.name: Autonomic Nervous System
sub_topics.short_description: Compare sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions.
example_tasks: Contrast ANS with somatic: ANS involuntary control of smooth muscle, cardiac muscle, and glands, two-neuron pathway (preganglionic neuron in CNS synapses with postganglionic neuron in ganglion outside CNS), dual innervation (most organs receive both sympathetic and parasympathetic); somatic voluntary control of skeletal muscle, single motor neuron from CNS to muscle.

Describe sympathetic division: 'fight or flight' response to stress, thoracolumbar (originates T1-L2), short preganglionic fibers, long postganglionic fibers, chain ganglia near spinal cord; effects include increased heart rate, dilated pupils, bronchodilation, decreased digestion, glucose release; neurotransmitter norepinephrine (mostly).

Describe parasympathetic division: 'rest and digest', craniosacral (cranial nerves and S2-S4), long preganglionic fibers, short postganglionic fibers, ganglia near or in target organs; effects include decreased heart rate, constricted pupils, bronchoconstriction, increased digestion, bladder contraction; neurotransmitter acetylcholine.

sub_topics.name: The Endocrine System
sub_topics.short_description: Examine hormonal regulation and major endocrine glands.

sub_topics.name: Hormones and Hormone Action
sub_topics.short_description: Understand chemical messengers and their mechanisms.
example_tasks: Define hormones: chemical messengers secreted by endocrine glands into bloodstream, travel throughout body, bind to specific receptors on target cells, produce specific effects; slower but longer-lasting than nervous system signals.

Compare hormone types: amino acid-based (proteins, peptides, amines, water-soluble, cannot cross membrane, bind surface receptors, use second messengers - cAMP, calcium - to trigger intracellular responses) and steroids (lipid-soluble, derived from cholesterol, cross membrane, bind intracellular receptors, directly alter gene expression).

Explain specificity and amplification: only target cells with appropriate receptors respond (specificity), one hormone molecule can trigger production of many second messengers activating many enzymes (amplification), allows small amounts of hormone to have large effects.

sub_topics.name: Hypothalamus and Pituitary Gland
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the master control glands.
example_tasks: Explain hypothalamus role: neural and endocrine control center, links nervous and endocrine systems, regulates pituitary gland, controls temperature, hunger, thirst, circadian rhythms, produces hormones (ADH, oxytocin) stored in posterior pituitary, produces releasing and inhibiting hormones controlling anterior pituitary.

Describe anterior pituitary hormones and functions: GH (growth hormone - stimulates growth), TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone - stimulates thyroid), ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone - stimulates adrenal cortex), FSH and LH (follicle-stimulating and luteinizing hormones - regulate gonads), PRL (prolactin - stimulates milk production); called 'master gland' because many hormones control other glands.

Describe posterior pituitary hormones: ADH (antidiuretic hormone/vasopressin - increases water reabsorption in kidneys, concentrated urine), oxytocin (stimulates uterine contractions during childbirth and milk ejection during nursing); produced in hypothalamus, stored and released by posterior pituitary.

sub_topics.name: Thyroid and Parathyroid Glands
sub_topics.short_description: Examine glands regulating metabolism and calcium.
example_tasks: Describe thyroid hormones: T3 and T4 (triiodothyronine and thyroxine) regulate metabolic rate, require iodine for synthesis, increase cellular respiration and heat production; calcitonin lowers blood calcium (stores in bone); hypothyroidism causes decreased metabolism/weight gain, hyperthyroidism causes increased metabolism/weight loss, goiter (enlarged thyroid) from iodine deficiency.

Explain thyroid hormone regulation: hypothalamus releases TRH (thyrotropin-releasing hormone) → anterior pituitary releases TSH → thyroid releases T3/T4 → negative feedback to hypothalamus and pituitary; T3/T4 levels regulate their own production.

Describe parathyroid hormone (PTH): four small glands on posterior thyroid, secrete PTH which raises blood calcium (stimulates bone breakdown, increases kidney reabsorption, activates vitamin D for intestinal absorption); works opposite to calcitonin; calcium levels tightly regulated (essential for nerve/muscle function, blood clotting).

sub_topics.name: Adrenal Glands
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the stress response glands.
example_tasks: Describe adrenal medulla: inner portion, nervous tissue, secretes epinephrine and norepinephrine in response to sympathetic stimulation; 'fight or flight' response (rapid, similar to sympathetic nervous system effects); increases heart rate, blood pressure, blood glucose, dilates airways.

Describe adrenal cortex hormones: outer portion, three regions produce three classes of steroid hormones: (1) mineralocorticoids (aldosterone - regulates sodium and potassium, increases blood volume/pressure), (2) glucocorticoids (cortisol - raises blood glucose, anti-inflammatory, stress response), (3) sex hormones (small amounts of androgens).

Explain stress response: short-term (medulla - epinephrine/norepinephrine, rapid energy mobilization) and long-term (cortex - cortisol, sustained glucose elevation, immune suppression); chronic stress harmful (weakens immune system, damages tissues); Addison's disease (cortex deficiency), Cushing's syndrome (excess cortisol).

sub_topics.name: Pancreas and Glucose Regulation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand blood sugar control.
example_tasks: Describe pancreatic islets: clusters of endocrine cells in pancreas (pancreas also exocrine organ secreting digestive enzymes); alpha cells produce glucagon, beta cells produce insulin.

Explain insulin action: released when blood glucose high (after eating), promotes glucose uptake by cells (especially muscle and adipose), promotes glucose storage as glycogen in liver and muscle, promotes fat and protein synthesis; lowers blood glucose.

Explain glucagon action: released when blood glucose low (between meals, during exercise), promotes glycogen breakdown in liver (glycogenolysis), promotes glucose synthesis from amino acids (gluconeogenesis), promotes fat breakdown; raises blood glucose; insulin and glucagon work antagonistically to maintain glucose homeostasis; diabetes mellitus results from insulin deficiency (Type 1) or resistance (Type 2).

grade_11_12.name: Human Anatomy & Physiology III
grade_11_12.short_description: Cardiovascular and respiratory systems. Students explore the circulatory system that transports materials throughout the body and the respiratory system that exchanges gases with the environment.

sub_topics.name: Blood: Composition and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Understand blood as a specialized connective tissue and its components.

sub_topics.name: Physical Characteristics of Blood
sub_topics.short_description: Understand blood properties and composition.
example_tasks: Describe blood properties: sticky, opaque fluid, heavier and more viscous than water, pH 7.35-7.45 (slightly alkaline), temperature ~38°C (100.4°F), constitutes ~8% of body weight; average adult has 5-6 liters.

Explain blood composition: ~55% plasma (liquid matrix, mostly water with dissolved proteins, nutrients, gases, wastes, hormones, ions) and ~45% formed elements (cells and cell fragments suspended in plasma); hematocrit measures percentage of RBCs.

Describe functions: transportation (oxygen, CO₂, nutrients, wastes, hormones, heat), regulation (pH through buffers, temperature through distribution of heat, water volume), protection (clotting prevents blood loss, white blood cells fight infection, antibodies and complement proteins provide immunity).

sub_topics.name: Plasma Composition
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the liquid component of blood.
example_tasks: Describe plasma composition: 90% water, 7% plasma proteins (albumins, globulins, fibrinogen), remaining 3% includes nutrients (glucose, amino acids, lipids), gases (O₂, CO₂), electrolytes (Na⁺, K⁺, Ca²⁺, Cl⁻), wastes (urea, uric acid, creatinine), hormones.

Explain plasma protein functions: albumins (most abundant, maintain osmotic pressure, transport fatty acids and hormones), globulins (alpha and beta transport lipids and vitamins, gamma are antibodies for immunity), fibrinogen (converted to fibrin for clotting).
Define serum: plasma without clotting factors; used for blood tests measuring antibodies, hormones, etc.; obtained by allowing blood to clot and removing clot.

sub_topics.name: Red Blood Cells (Erythrocytes)
sub_topics.short_description: Examine structure and function of oxygen-transporting cells.
example_tasks: Describe RBC structure: biconcave disc shape (increases surface area for gas exchange, allows flexibility to squeeze through capillaries), no nucleus or organelles when mature (more room for hemoglobin), lifespan ~120 days; most abundant formed element (~5 million per μL).

Explain hemoglobin: protein with four polypeptide chains, each with heme group containing iron, one hemoglobin binds four O₂ molecules; oxyhemoglobin (bright red, O₂ bound), deoxyhemoglobin (dark red, O₂ released); also transports some CO₂ and buffers pH.

Describe erythropoiesis: RBC production in red bone marrow, regulated by erythropoietin (EPO, hormone from kidneys in response to low O₂), requires iron, vitamin B12, folic acid; mature RBCs released into bloodstream; old RBCs removed by spleen and liver, iron recycled, hemoglobin broken down to bilirubin (excreted in bile).

sub_topics.name: White Blood Cells (Leukocytes)
sub_topics.short_description: Examine cells that defend against infection and disease.
example_tasks: Describe WBC characteristics: less abundant than RBCs (~7,000 per μL), have nuclei and organelles, can move independently (amoeboid movement), squeeze out of capillaries (diapedesis) to reach infection sites; elevated count indicates infection or disease.

Compare granulocytes (contain visible cytoplasmic granules): neutrophils (most abundant WBC, 50-70%, phagocytize bacteria, 'first responders'), eosinophils (attack parasitic worms, involved in allergies), basophils (release histamine in inflammatory response and allergic reactions).

Compare agranulocytes (lack visible granules): lymphocytes (B cells produce antibodies, T cells directly attack infected cells and coordinate immune response, provide specific immunity), monocytes (leave blood and become macrophages in tissues, phagocytize pathogens and debris, antigen presentation).

sub_topics.name: Platelets and Hemostasis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand blood clotting mechanisms.
example_tasks: Describe platelets: cell fragments from megakaryocytes in bone marrow, no nucleus, ~250,000 per μL, lifespan ~10 days; contain clotting factors and chemicals to initiate clot formation.

Explain hemostasis phases: (1) vascular spasm (damaged vessel constricts, reducing blood loss), (2) platelet plug formation (platelets adhere to damaged site and each other, release chemicals attracting more platelets), (3) coagulation (clotting cascade produces fibrin threads that trap RBCs forming stable clot).

Describe clotting cascade: intrinsic pathway (initiated by damage to blood vessel lining) and extrinsic pathway (initiated by tissue damage) converge on common pathway; series of enzyme activations amplifies signal; prothrombin → thrombin → fibrinogen → fibrin; requires calcium and vitamin K; clot retraction pulls wound edges together; fibrinolysis dissolves clot after healing.

sub_topics.name: Blood Types and Transfusions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand ABO and Rh blood group systems.
example_tasks: Explain ABO system: based on antigens (agglutinogens) on RBC surface and antibodies (agglutinins) in plasma; Type A (A antigens, anti-B antibodies), Type B (B antigens, anti-A antibodies), Type AB (both antigens, no antibodies - universal recipient), Type O (no antigens, both antibodies - universal donor for RBCs).

Explain transfusion reactions: if incompatible blood transfused, antibodies bind antigens causing agglutination (clumping) and hemolysis (RBC rupture); potentially fatal; Type AB can receive any blood (no antibodies to attack donor cells), Type O can donate to any (no antigens to be attacked).

Explain Rh factor: Rh+ (have D antigen), Rh- (lack D antigen); Rh- individuals develop anti-Rh antibodies only after exposure to Rh+ blood; hemolytic disease of newborn occurs when Rh- mother carrying Rh+ fetus develops antibodies (especially second pregnancy); RhoGAM injection prevents antibody formation.

sub_topics.name: Heart: Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the pump that drives blood circulation.

sub_topics.name: Heart Anatomy
sub_topics.short_description: Understand structural features of the heart.
example_tasks: Describe heart size and location: size of closed fist, located in mediastinum (between lungs), apex points toward left hip, enclosed in pericardium (double-layered sac with fluid reducing friction).

Describe heart wall layers: endocardium (inner endothelial lining, continuous with blood vessel lining), myocardium (thick middle layer of cardiac muscle, responsible for contraction), epicardium (outer layer, visceral pericardium).

Identify chambers and vessels: four chambers (right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from body via superior/inferior vena cava, right ventricle pumps to lungs via pulmonary trunk, left atrium receives oxygenated blood from lungs via pulmonary veins, left ventricle pumps to body via aorta); interventricular and interatrial septa separate sides.

sub_topics.name: Heart Valves
sub_topics.short_description: Understand structures ensuring one-way blood flow.
example_tasks: Describe atrioventricular (AV) valves: between atria and ventricles, tricuspid valve (right side, three flaps), bicuspid/mitral valve (left side, two flaps); attached to papillary muscles by chordae tendineae (prevent valve inversion); open when atria contract, close when ventricles contract (prevent backflow to atria).

Describe semilunar valves: between ventricles and arteries, pulmonary valve (right ventricle to pulmonary trunk), aortic valve (left ventricle to aorta); three pocket-like cusps; open when ventricles contract (pressure forces blood into arteries), close when ventricles relax (prevent backflow to ventricles).

Explain heart sounds: 'lub-dub'; first sound (S1, 'lub') from AV valves closing at start of ventricular contraction, second sound (S2, 'dub') from semilunar valves closing at start of ventricular relaxation; murmurs indicate turbulent flow from valve defects (stenosis - narrowed, incompetent - doesn't close completely).

sub_topics.name: Coronary Circulation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand blood supply to heart muscle itself.
example_tasks: Explain need for coronary circulation: heart muscle highly active, requires constant oxygen and nutrient supply; blood in heart chambers doesn't supply myocardium (too thick, only endocardium receives some diffusion).

Describe coronary arteries: right and left coronary arteries branch from aorta just above aortic valve, branch extensively over heart surface and penetrate myocardium; deliver oxygenated blood during ventricular relaxation (vessels compressed during contraction).

Explain coronary artery disease (CAD): atherosclerosis (plaque buildup) narrows coronary arteries, reduces blood flow to myocardium; angina pectoris (chest pain from inadequate oxygen during exertion), myocardial infarction (heart attack - prolonged blockage causes tissue death); leading cause of death; risk factors include high cholesterol, hypertension, smoking, diabetes, obesity.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Cardiac Muscle
sub_topics.short_description: Understand unique features of heart muscle tissue.
example_tasks: Compare to skeletal muscle: striated (organized sarcomeres), but cells branched and connected by intercalated discs (contain desmosomes for strength and gap junctions for electrical coupling), uninucleate or binucleate, more mitochondria (aerobic metabolism, fatigue-resistant), longer contraction.

Explain autorhythmicity: cardiac muscle cells depolarize spontaneously without external stimulus; pacemaker cells (nodal cells) have unstable resting potential that drifts to threshold; heart contracts rhythmically without nervous input (denervated heart continues beating).

Describe functional syncytium: gap junctions electrically couple cardiac cells, allowing action potential to spread quickly through entire atrium or ventricle, all cells contract nearly simultaneously; atria and ventricles separated by fibrous skeleton (electrical insulation) ensuring proper sequence.

sub_topics.name: Cardiac Conduction System
sub_topics.short_description: Trace the pathway of electrical signals through the heart.
example_tasks: Identify components and pathway: (1) sinoatrial (SA) node (right atrium, pacemaker, sets rate ~75 bpm), (2) signal spreads through atria causing atrial contraction, (3) atrioventricular (AV) node (between atria and ventricles, delays signal ~0.1 sec allowing ventricles to fill), (4) AV bundle/bundle of His (only pathway through fibrous skeleton), (5) right and left bundle branches (in interventricular septum), (6) Purkinje fibers (spread throughout ventricles from apex upward, causing ventricular contraction).

Explain pacemaker hierarchy: SA node fastest (primary pacemaker), AV node ~50 bpm (backup if SA fails), Purkinje fibers ~30 bpm (backup if both fail); artificial pacemaker implanted if natural pacemakers fail.

Describe electrocardiogram (ECG/EKG): recording of electrical activity from body surface; P wave (atrial depolarization), QRS complex (ventricular depolarization, atrial repolarization hidden), T wave (ventricular repolarization); used to diagnose arrhythmias, conduction blocks, heart damage.

sub_topics.name: The Cardiac Cycle
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the sequence of events in one heartbeat.
example_tasks: Describe phases: (1) ventricular filling (ventricles relaxed, AV valves open, blood flows from atria, 70% passive, 30% from atrial contraction), (2) isovolumetric contraction (ventricles start contracting, all valves closed, pressure rises but no ejection yet), (3) ventricular ejection (pressure exceeds arterial pressure, semilunar valves open, blood ejected - 70 mL stroke volume), (4) isovolumetric relaxation (ventricles relax, all valves closed briefly, pressure drops).

Define terms: systole (contraction phase), diastole (relaxation phase); when referring to 'blood pressure,' ventricular systole and diastole meant; heart spends more time in diastole than systole (important for coronary filling).

Calculate cardiac output: CO = HR × SV (heart rate × stroke volume); average ~5 L/min at rest, can increase to 25-30 L/min during exercise; regulated by autonomic nervous system (sympathetic increases HR and contractility, parasympathetic decreases HR) and hormones (epinephrine increases both).

sub_topics.name: Blood Vessels and Circulation
sub_topics.short_description: Examine vessel types and pathways of blood flow.

sub_topics.name: Structure of Blood Vessels
sub_topics.short_description: Compare anatomy of arteries, veins, and capillaries.
example_tasks: Describe vessel wall layers (arteries and veins): tunica intima (inner endothelium, smooth surface reduces friction), tunica media (middle smooth muscle and elastic tissue, thickest in arteries), tunica externa (outer connective tissue, anchors to surrounding structures).

Compare arteries: thick walls (especially tunica media), small lumens, elastic (recoil maintains pressure between beats), carry blood away from heart under high pressure, pulse felt where near surface; arterioles (smallest) control blood flow to capillary beds via vasoconstriction/vasodilation.

Compare veins: thinner walls, larger lumens, less elastic, carry blood to heart under low pressure, contain valves preventing backflow (especially in limbs), blood moved by skeletal muscle pump and respiratory pump; venules collect blood from capillaries; serve as blood reservoirs (~65% of blood volume in veins).

sub_topics.name: Capillaries: Exchange Vessels
sub_topics.short_description: Understand sites of material exchange between blood and tissues.
example_tasks: Describe capillary structure: microscopic vessels (8 μm diameter, just wide enough for RBC to squeeze through single file), single layer of endothelial cells (thin for diffusion), no smooth muscle; form capillary beds between arterioles and venules.

Explain exchange mechanisms: diffusion (gases, nutrients, wastes move down concentration gradients through endothelial cells or between them), bulk flow (fluid movement through capillary walls driven by pressure differences - filtration out at arterial end, reabsorption in at venous end).

Describe Starling forces: blood hydrostatic pressure (pushes fluid out, higher at arterial end), blood osmotic pressure (pulls fluid in, due to plasma proteins), tissue pressures (usually favor filtration); net filtration at arterial end, net reabsorption at venous end, excess tissue fluid becomes lymph.

sub_topics.name: Blood Pressure
sub_topics.short_description: Understand pressure in arteries and factors affecting it.
example_tasks: Define blood pressure: force blood exerts on vessel walls; measured in mmHg; systolic (peak pressure during ventricular contraction, ~120 mmHg) over diastolic (lowest pressure during ventricular relaxation, ~80 mmHg); decreases as blood moves away from heart (arteries > arterioles > capillaries > venules > veins).

Explain factors affecting blood pressure: cardiac output (increased CO increases BP), blood volume (increased volume increases BP), peripheral resistance (vasoconstriction increases BP, vasodilation decreases BP), blood viscosity (thicker blood increases BP), vessel elasticity (rigid vessels increase BP).

Describe regulation: short-term (baroreceptor reflex - pressure receptors in carotid arteries and aorta detect changes, medulla adjusts sympathetic/parasympathetic output affecting heart rate and vessel diameter), long-term (kidneys regulate blood volume via urine output); hypertension (chronic high BP, damages vessels, increases heart attack/stroke risk), hypotension (low BP, may cause fainting).

sub_topics.name: Circulatory Pathways
sub_topics.short_description: Trace blood flow through pulmonary and systemic circuits.
example_tasks: Describe pulmonary circulation: right ventricle → pulmonary trunk → pulmonary arteries (left and right, carry deoxygenated blood) → lungs (gas exchange in alveolar capillaries, CO₂ released, O₂ picked up) → pulmonary veins (carry oxygenated blood) → left atrium; short circuit, low pressure.
