Describe systemic circulation: left ventricle → aorta → arteries → arterioles → systemic capillaries (exchange with tissues, O₂ released, CO₂ picked up, nutrients delivered, wastes removed) → venules → veins → vena cava (superior from upper body, inferior from lower body) → right atrium; long circuit, high pressure, supplies all body tissues.

Identify major arteries: aorta (ascending, aortic arch, descending), brachiocephalic (supplies right arm and right head/neck), left common carotid and left subclavian (supply left head/neck and left arm), celiac trunk (stomach, liver, spleen), superior and inferior mesenteric (intestines), renal (kidneys), common iliac (divide into internal and external, pelvis and legs).

sub_topics.name: Special Circulations
sub_topics.short_description: Examine unique circulatory routes to specific organs.
example_tasks: Describe hepatic portal circulation: veins from digestive organs (stomach, intestines, spleen, pancreas) drain into hepatic portal vein → liver sinusoids (not directly to heart); allows liver to process nutrients, detoxify substances, remove bacteria before blood enters general circulation; hepatic veins drain liver to inferior vena cava.

Describe fetal circulation: placenta exchanges materials with maternal blood; umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from placenta to fetus, ductus venosus bypasses liver, foramen ovale (opening between atria) and ductus arteriosus (vessel between pulmonary trunk and aorta) shunt blood past non-functional lungs; these shunts close at birth.

Describe cerebral circulation: brain receives ~15% of cardiac output, very sensitive to O₂ deprivation; carotid and vertebral arteries supply brain, circle of Willis (arterial circle) provides alternate routes if one vessel blocked; blood-brain barrier (tight junctions between endothelial cells, astrocyte processes) protects brain from harmful substances but limits drug delivery.

sub_topics.name: Respiratory System Anatomy
sub_topics.short_description: Examine structures of the respiratory tract and lungs.

sub_topics.name: Overview and Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand purposes of respiratory system.
example_tasks: Define respiration: (1) pulmonary ventilation (breathing, moving air in and out of lungs), (2) external respiration (gas exchange between lungs and blood), (3) transport of gases in blood, (4) internal respiration (gas exchange between blood and tissues), (5) cellular respiration (cells use O₂ and produce CO₂).

List functions: supply oxygen for cellular respiration, remove carbon dioxide (waste from cellular respiration), regulate blood pH (by controlling CO₂ levels), produce sounds for speech, sense of smell, filter/warm/humidify incoming air.

Divide into zones: conducting zone (nose → bronchioles, no gas exchange, ~150 mL dead space, filters/warms/humidifies air, includes nose, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi) and respiratory zone (respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, alveoli, site of gas exchange).

sub_topics.name: Upper Respiratory Tract
sub_topics.short_description: Examine nose, pharynx, and larynx.
example_tasks: Describe nose and nasal cavity: external nose (bone and cartilage), internal nasal cavity (divided by septum), conchae (turbinates, increase surface area), mucous membranes (warm and humidify air), hairs and mucus (trap particles), paranasal sinuses (lighten skull, produce mucus, resonance for voice).

Describe pharynx: throat, shared by respiratory and digestive systems; nasopharynx (superior, behind nasal cavity, contains pharyngeal tonsil/adenoids), oropharynx (middle, behind mouth, contains palatine tonsils), laryngopharynx (inferior, opens to larynx and esophagus).

Describe larynx: voice box, connects pharynx to trachea, cartilages include thyroid (Adam's apple), cricoid (ring), epiglottis (closes over glottis during swallowing preventing food entering trachea); vocal cords (folds of mucous membrane, vibrate as air passes producing sound, pitch controlled by tension).

sub_topics.name: Lower Respiratory Tract
sub_topics.short_description: Examine trachea, bronchi, and bronchioles.
example_tasks: Describe trachea: windpipe, 12 cm tube from larynx to primary bronchi, C-shaped cartilage rings (prevent collapse, open side posterior against esophagus allows expansion during swallowing), lined with ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium and goblet cells (mucus traps particles, cilia sweep upward toward pharynx - mucociliary escalator).

Describe bronchial tree: trachea → primary bronchi (right and left, enter lungs at hilum) → secondary (lobar) bronchi (3 right, 2 left) → tertiary (segmental) bronchi → bronchioles → terminal bronchioles; cartilage decreases, smooth muscle increases as branches get smaller; diameter regulated by smooth muscle (parasympathetic constricts, sympathetic dilates).

Explain clinical relevance: asthma (bronchiole constriction from inflammation, wheezing, difficulty breathing), bronchitis (inflammation of bronchi, excess mucus, cough), COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, includes emphysema and chronic bronchitis, progressive airflow limitation, often from smoking).

sub_topics.name: Lungs and Alveoli
sub_topics.short_description: Examine structure of lungs and gas exchange surfaces.
example_tasks: Describe lung anatomy: paired organs in thoracic cavity, separated by mediastinum, surrounded by pleural membranes (visceral pleura on lung surface, parietal pleura lining thoracic wall, pleural fluid between reduces friction); right lung (3 lobes), left lung (2 lobes, cardiac notch accommodates heart); occupy most thoracic volume.

Describe alveoli: microscopic air sacs (~300 million per lung), clustered at ends of respiratory bronchioles, walls one cell thick (simple squamous epithelium - type I cells), surrounded by dense capillary network; type II cells produce surfactant (reduces surface tension, prevents collapse); site of gas exchange.

Explain structure-function relationship: enormous surface area (~70 m² - half tennis court), minimal diffusion distance (~0.5 μm between air and blood), extensive capillary coverage maximizes gas exchange; respiratory membrane (alveolar wall, basement membranes, capillary wall) allows rapid diffusion; diseases damaging alveoli (emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis) severely impair gas exchange.

sub_topics.name: Pulmonary Ventilation (Breathing)
sub_topics.short_description: Understand mechanics of air movement into and out of lungs.

sub_topics.name: Pressure Relationships in Thoracic Cavity
sub_topics.short_description: Understand pressures driving airflow.
example_tasks: Explain pressure gradients: air flows from high to low pressure; atmospheric pressure (760 mmHg at sea level), intrapulmonary pressure (pressure in alveoli, fluctuates around atmospheric, air flows in when below atmospheric, out when above), intrapleural pressure (pressure in pleural cavity, always slightly negative ~756 mmHg, keeps lungs inflated against chest wall).

Explain importance of negative intrapleural pressure: creates pressure gradient keeping lungs expanded against chest wall; if thoracic wall punctured (pneumothorax), air enters pleural cavity, intrapleural pressure equals atmospheric, lung collapses (no gradient to hold it open); must be sealed and air removed.

Describe elasticity and compliance: lungs naturally recoil (elastic tissue and surface tension), tend to collapse; chest wall tends to expand; intrapleural pressure results from opposing forces; lung compliance (ease of expansion) reduced in fibrosis, increased in emphysema.

sub_topics.name: Inspiration and Expiration
sub_topics.short_description: Trace the muscle contractions producing breathing.
example_tasks: Describe inspiration (active process): diaphragm contracts (flattens, moves down ~1 cm), external intercostals contract (ribs elevate and move outward), thoracic cavity volume increases, intrapleural pressure becomes more negative, lungs expand, intrapulmonary pressure drops below atmospheric (~758 mmHg), air flows in; deep inspiration involves scalenes, sternocleidomastoids (elevate ribs further).

Describe quiet expiration (passive process): diaphragm relaxes (domes upward), external intercostals relax (ribs move down and inward), thoracic volume decreases, elastic recoil of lungs, intrapulmonary pressure rises above atmospheric (~763 mmHg), air flows out; no muscle contraction needed.
Describe forced expiration (active): internal intercostals and abdominal muscles contract, compress thoracic cavity, increase air outflow; used during exercise, coughing, playing wind instruments.

sub_topics.name: Respiratory Volumes and Capacities
sub_topics.short_description: Understand measurements of lung function.
example_tasks: Define volumes: tidal volume (TV, ~500 mL, normal breath at rest), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV, ~3000 mL, extra air inhaled with deep breath), expiratory reserve volume (ERV, ~1200 mL, extra air exhaled with forced exhalation), residual volume (RV, ~1200 mL, air remaining after maximum exhalation, keeps alveoli inflated).

Calculate capacities (sum of two or more volumes): inspiratory capacity (IC = TV + IRV, ~3500 mL), functional residual capacity (FRC = ERV + RV, ~2400 mL), vital capacity (VC = TV + IRV + ERV, ~4700 mL, maximum air exhaled after maximum inhalation), total lung capacity (TLC = VC + RV, ~6000 mL).

Explain clinical applications: spirometry measures volumes/capacities, diagnoses restrictive diseases (reduced VC, lung expansion limited) vs. obstructive diseases (reduced expiratory flow rate, airways narrowed), monitors disease progression and treatment; FEV₁ (forced expiratory volume in 1 sec) particularly useful diagnostic.

sub_topics.name: Nonrespiratory Air Movements
sub_topics.short_description: Understand modified breathing patterns.
example_tasks: Describe cough reflex: irritation of respiratory passages → deep inspiration → glottis closes → abdominal/internal intercostals contract building pressure → glottis opens suddenly → high-velocity air blast clears passages.

Describe other movements: sneeze (similar to cough but air directed through nose, clears nasal passages), hiccup (spasmodic diaphragm contraction, glottis closes producing sound), yawn (deep inspiration stretching lungs, reason unclear), laugh/cry (modified respiratory movements expressing emotion).
Explain purposes: most nonrespiratory movements protective (clear airways), some social/emotional; some involuntary reflexes, others partially voluntary.

sub_topics.name: Gas Exchange and Transport
sub_topics.short_description: Understand diffusion of gases and their transport in blood.

sub_topics.name: External Respiration
sub_topics.short_description: Examine gas exchange between lungs and blood.
example_tasks: Explain Dalton's law: total pressure is sum of partial pressures of individual gases; atmospheric pressure (760 mmHg at sea level) = PO₂ (160 mmHg, 21% of total) + PCO₂ (~0.3 mmHg) + PN₂ (593 mmHg, 78%) + PH₂O (variable); gases diffuse independently down their partial pressure gradients.

Describe O₂ diffusion: alveolar PO₂ (~104 mmHg) > pulmonary capillary blood PO₂ (~40 mmHg in deoxygenated blood from tissues) → O₂ diffuses into blood → blood leaving lungs has PO₂ ~100 mmHg (nearly equilibrates with alveolar air).

Describe CO₂ diffusion: pulmonary capillary blood PCO₂ (~45 mmHg in blood from tissues) > alveolar PCO₂ (~40 mmHg) → CO₂ diffuses into alveoli → blood leaving lungs has PCO₂ ~40 mmHg; CO₂ more soluble than O₂ so diffuses faster despite smaller gradient.

sub_topics.name: Internal Respiration
sub_topics.short_description: Examine gas exchange between blood and tissues.
example_tasks: Describe O₂ diffusion at tissues: systemic capillary blood PO₂ (~100 mmHg) > tissue PO₂ (~40 mmHg or lower in active tissues) → O₂ diffuses out of blood into cells → blood leaving tissues has PO₂ ~40 mmHg (venous blood).

Describe CO₂ diffusion at tissues: tissue PCO₂ (~45 mmHg or higher in active tissues) > systemic capillary blood PCO₂ (~40 mmHg) → CO₂ diffuses from cells into blood → blood leaving tissues has PCO₂ ~45 mmHg.

Explain factors enhancing exchange: exercise increases tissue metabolism (lower tissue PO₂, higher tissue PCO₂, steeper gradients), increased temperature and CO₂ shift oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve right (hemoglobin releases O₂ more readily), increased capillary density in active tissues.

sub_topics.name: Oxygen Transport
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how O₂ is carried in blood.
example_tasks: Explain O₂ transport forms: 1.5% dissolved in plasma (only form that diffuses), 98.5% bound to hemoglobin as oxyhemoglobin (Hb + O₂ ⇌ HbO₂); each hemoglobin can bind 4 O₂ (one per heme group); blood normally 98% saturated with O₂ leaving lungs, 75% saturated returning from tissues (unloaded 23% of O₂).

Describe oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve: S-shaped curve relating PO₂ to hemoglobin saturation; plateau at high PO₂ (in lungs, remains highly saturated even if PO₂ drops), steep part at lower PO₂ (in tissues, small PO₂ decrease causes large O₂ release); curve shifts with pH, temperature, CO₂.

Explain factors affecting O₂ unloading: decreased pH (more acidic), increased CO₂, increased temperature, increased 2,3-BPG shift curve right (Bohr effect) → hemoglobin releases O₂ more readily at given PO₂; all occur in active tissues (metabolism produces heat, CO₂, H⁺) → more O₂ delivered where needed; carbon monoxide (CO) binds hemoglobin 200× stronger than O₂, prevents O₂ transport, deadly.

sub_topics.name: Carbon Dioxide Transport
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how CO₂ is carried in blood.
example_tasks: Explain CO₂ transport forms: 7-10% dissolved in plasma, 20% bound to hemoglobin (carbaminohemoglobin, binds amino acids not heme), 70% as bicarbonate ion (HCO₃⁻) in plasma; reversible reactions allow loading at tissues, unloading at lungs.

Describe bicarbonate formation: CO₂ + H₂O ⇌ H₂CO₃ ⇌ H⁺ + HCO₃⁻; occurs in RBCs catalyzed by carbonic anhydrase (fast enzyme); HCO₃⁻ diffuses into plasma (chloride shift maintains electrical balance), H⁺ buffered by hemoglobin (prevents pH drop); at lungs, reactions reverse (HCO₃⁻ enters RBCs, combines with H⁺, forms CO₂ that diffuses into alveoli).

Explain Haldane effect: deoxygenated blood (in tissues) carries more CO₂ than oxygenated blood; deoxyhemoglobin binds H⁺ better (promotes CO₂ → HCO₃⁻ conversion), binds more CO₂ as carbaminohemoglobin; at lungs, binding O₂ to hemoglobin promotes CO₂ release; O₂ and CO₂ loading/unloading mutually enhance each other.

sub_topics.name: Regulation of Respiration
sub_topics.short_description: Understand neural and chemical control of breathing.

sub_topics.name: Neural Control of Breathing
sub_topics.short_description: Examine brain centers controlling respiratory rhythm.
example_tasks: Describe medullary respiratory centers: ventral respiratory group (VRG, neurons control both inspiration and expiration, generate basic rhythm), dorsal respiratory group (DRG, integrates sensory input, controls VRG, primarily inspiration); medulla generates involuntary breathing rhythm; damage causes breathing to stop.

Describe pontine respiratory centers: pneumotaxic center (inhibits inspiration, limits depth, increases rate), apneustic center (stimulates inspiration, prolongs inhalation); modulate medullary centers, fine-tune breathing pattern.

Explain voluntary control: cerebral cortex can override medullary control temporarily (hold breath, hyperventilate, speaking, singing); cannot override long-term (eventually rising CO₂ forces breathing); breath-holding limited by increasing PCO₂ and decreasing PO₂ triggering strong breathing urge.

sub_topics.name: Chemical Regulation of Breathing
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how blood gases and pH affect respiration.
example_tasks: Describe central chemoreceptors: in medulla, monitor cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pH which reflects blood PCO₂ (CO₂ crosses blood-brain barrier easily, forms H⁺ in CSF); increased PCO₂ → decreased pH → stimulates breathing (most important factor regulating breathing under normal conditions); maintains PCO₂ near 40 mmHg.

Describe peripheral chemoreceptors: carotid bodies (carotid arteries) and aortic bodies (aortic arch), monitor blood PO₂, PCO₂, and pH; decreased PO₂ below ~60 mmHg strongly stimulates breathing (backup system, not normally active because O₂ remains adequate); respond to decreased pH (acidosis) and increased PCO₂.

Explain integrated control: normally, increased PCO₂ (from metabolism) is primary stimulus → central chemoreceptors detect → increase breathing rate and depth → blow off excess CO₂ → PCO₂ normalized; at high altitude, decreased PO₂ stimulates peripheral chemoreceptors; during exercise, multiple factors increase breathing matching metabolic needs.

sub_topics.name: Respiratory Disorders
sub_topics.short_description: Understand common conditions affecting breathing.
example_tasks: Describe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): chronic bronchitis (airway inflammation, excess mucus, chronic cough) and emphysema (alveolar wall destruction, reduced surface area, loss of elasticity, air trapping); usually from smoking; progressive airflow limitation, hypoxemia, hypercapnia; treatment includes bronchodilators, oxygen.

Describe asthma: chronic inflammatory disorder, airway hyperresponsiveness to triggers (allergens, exercise, cold air), bronchoconstriction, inflammation, excess mucus; symptoms include wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness; treated with bronchodilators (relieve acute symptoms) and anti-inflammatory medications (prevent attacks).

Describe other disorders: pneumonia (lung infection, alveoli fill with fluid/pus, impairs gas exchange), tuberculosis (bacterial infection, destroys lung tissue), lung cancer (usually from smoking, uncontrolled cell growth), sleep apnea (breathing stops periodically during sleep, from airway obstruction or neural control issues), cystic fibrosis (genetic, thick mucus blocks airways).

grade_11_12.name: Human Anatomy & Physiology IV
grade_11_12.short_description: Digestive, excretory, and lymphatic/immune systems. Students explore nutrient processing, waste elimination, fluid balance, and body defense mechanisms.

sub_topics.name: Digestive System Overview and Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand processes and organs of the digestive system.

sub_topics.name: Overview of Digestive Processes
sub_topics.short_description: Identify six essential activities of digestion.
example_tasks: List digestive processes: (1) ingestion (taking food into mouth), (2) propulsion (moving food through tract via swallowing and peristalsis), (3) mechanical digestion (physical breakdown by chewing, churning, segmentation), (4) chemical digestion (enzymatic breakdown of large molecules to absorbable units), (5) absorption (passage of nutrients into blood or lymph), (6) defecation (elimination of indigestible residue).

Distinguish alimentary canal (GI tract): continuous tube from mouth to anus (~9 meters long), includes mouth, pharynx, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine; where food processing occurs.

Identify accessory digestive organs: teeth, tongue, salivary glands, liver, gallbladder, pancreas; aid digestion but food doesn't pass through them (except briefly in mouth); produce secretions entering GI tract.

sub_topics.name: Basic Structure of Digestive Tract Wall
sub_topics.short_description: Understand four-layered organization shared by most of GI tract.
example_tasks: Describe mucosa: innermost layer, moist epithelium (type varies by region) facing lumen, lamina propria (connective tissue, blood vessels, lymphatics), muscularis mucosae (thin smooth muscle layer); secretes mucus, digestive enzymes, hormones; absorbs nutrients.
Describe submucosa: connective tissue layer, contains blood vessels, lymphatic vessels, nerve plexus (submucosal/Meissner's plexus regulating secretion); elastic properties allow distention.

Describe remaining layers: muscularis externa (usually two layers of smooth muscle - inner circular, outer longitudinal; myenteric/Auerbach's plexus between layers regulates motility, contractions mix and propel food), serosa or adventitia (outermost layer, visceral peritoneum in abdominal cavity or connective tissue securing to surrounding structures).

sub_topics.name: Organs of the Digestive System
sub_topics.short_description: Examine anatomy and function of each digestive organ.

sub_topics.name: Mouth, Pharynx, and Esophagus
sub_topics.short_description: Understand structures initiating digestion and food transport.
example_tasks: Describe mouth (oral cavity): lips and cheeks (keep food between teeth), hard and soft palates (roof), tongue (manipulates food, taste, swallowing, speech), teeth (mechanical digestion); salivary glands (parotid, submandibular, sublingual) produce saliva (moistens food, contains salivary amylase beginning starch digestion, lysozyme kills bacteria, mucus lubricates).

Explain swallowing (deglutition): voluntary phase (tongue pushes bolus to pharynx), pharyngeal phase (involuntary, soft palate rises closing nasopharynx, epiglottis covers larynx, upper esophageal sphincter relaxes, food enters esophagus), esophageal phase (peristaltic waves propel food to stomach, lower esophageal sphincter relaxes); takes ~4-8 seconds.

Describe esophagus: ~25 cm muscular tube from pharynx to stomach, passes through diaphragm; upper third skeletal muscle, lower two-thirds smooth muscle; functions solely in propulsion; gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) when stomach acid enters esophagus (sphincter malfunction), causes heartburn.

sub_topics.name: Stomach
sub_topics.short_description: Examine structure and functions of the stomach.
example_tasks: Describe stomach structure: J-shaped, size varies with contents (~50 mL empty, 1-1.5 L typical meal, up to 4 L); regions include cardia (near esophagus), fundus (superior dome), body (main part), pylorus (narrow lower region, pyloric sphincter controls emptying into small intestine); rugae (folds) allow expansion; three muscle layers allow vigorous churning.

Explain gastric secretions: gastric pits lined with specialized cells: mucous cells (produce protective mucus), parietal cells (produce HCl making pH ~2, intrinsic factor needed for vitamin B12 absorption), chief cells (produce pepsinogen, inactive enzyme precursor), enteroendocrine cells (produce hormones like gastrin); HCl activates pepsinogen → pepsin (digests proteins), kills most bacteria.

Describe stomach functions: storage (holds food 2-6 hours), mechanical digestion (churning mixes food with gastric juice forming chyme - thick acidic fluid), chemical digestion (pepsin begins protein digestion, gastric lipase minimal fat digestion), limited absorption (water, alcohol, some drugs); slow emptying rate controlled by stomach distention and duodenal factors.

sub_topics.name: Small Intestine
sub_topics.short_description: Examine primary site of digestion and absorption.
example_tasks: Describe structure and regions: longest part (~6 m), narrow (2.5 cm), coiled in abdomen; duodenum (first 25 cm, receives secretions from liver and pancreas, most chemical digestion), jejunum (middle 2.5 m, absorption), ileum (last 3.5 m, absorption, contains Peyer's patches - lymphoid tissue); ileocecal valve connects to large intestine.

Explain structural adaptations for absorption: circular folds (permanent folds increase surface area), villi (fingerlike projections of mucosa, 1 mm tall, contain capillaries and lacteal for nutrient absorption), microvilli (tiny projections on epithelial cells, brush border, contain enzymes); adaptations increase surface area ~600-fold (~200 m² - tennis court).

Describe digestion completion: receives pancreatic juice (enzymes for carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, nucleic acids, bicarbonate neutralizes acid chyme), bile from liver (emulsifies fats), brush border enzymes complete carbohydrate and protein digestion; by end of small intestine, most nutrients absorbed (90%), only water, indigestible materials, bacteria remain.

sub_topics.name: Accessory Organs: Liver, Gallbladder, and Pancreas
sub_topics.short_description: Examine organs producing digestive secretions.
example_tasks: Describe liver: largest internal organ (~1.5 kg), right side of abdomen below diaphragm; over 500 functions including: produces bile (500-1000 mL/day, bile salts emulsify fats, bilirubin from hemoglobin breakdown gives color), processes nutrients from hepatic portal blood, stores glycogen/vitamins/minerals, detoxifies drugs and toxins, synthesizes plasma proteins (albumin, clotting factors), breaks down hormones.

Describe gallbladder and bile: small sac under liver, stores and concentrates bile (removes water), releases bile into duodenum when fatty chyme present (stimulated by hormone CCK - cholecystokinin); bile travels through bile duct; gallstones (crystallized cholesterol or bilirubin) can block duct causing pain.

Describe pancreas: ~15 cm long, extends from duodenum to spleen; exocrine function produces pancreatic juice (1-1.5 L/day containing enzymes: trypsin, chymotrypsin, carboxypeptidase digest proteins; pancreatic amylase digests starch; pancreatic lipase digests fats; nucleases digest nucleic acids; plus bicarbonate neutralizes acid chyme); endocrine function (islet cells produce insulin and glucagon, already covered).

sub_topics.name: Large Intestine
sub_topics.short_description: Examine final processing and waste elimination.
example_tasks: Describe structure and regions: ~1.5 m long, 6 cm diameter (wider but shorter than small intestine); cecum (receives chyme from ileum, appendix attached), ascending colon, transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, rectum (~20 cm), anal canal (internal sphincter involuntary, external sphincter voluntary); teniae coli (longitudinal muscle bands) create haustra (pouches).

Explain functions: water absorption (500 mL chyme enters, mostly absorbed leaving ~100-200 mL in feces), absorption of vitamins produced by bacteria (K, B12, thiamine, riboflavin), houses gut bacteria (digest cellulose, synthesize vitamins, inhibit pathogens - microbiome), propulsion (slow, mass movements few times daily push toward rectum), defecation (feces stored in rectum, distention triggers defecation reflex).

Describe feces composition: water (75%), bacteria (dead and living, 1/3 of dry mass), indigestible materials (cellulose fiber), epithelial cells, bile pigments (give color); diarrhea (too rapid propulsion, insufficient water absorption), constipation (slow propulsion, excessive water absorption, hard dry feces); fiber intake important for healthy colon function.

sub_topics.name: Chemical Digestion and Absorption
sub_topics.short_description: Understand enzymatic breakdown and nutrient uptake.

sub_topics.name: Carbohydrate Digestion and Absorption
sub_topics.short_description: Trace breakdown of starches and sugars.
example_tasks: Trace digestion pathway: mouth (salivary amylase begins breaking starch → maltose and dextrins), stomach (amylase inactivated by acid), small intestine (pancreatic amylase continues starch → maltose, brush border enzymes complete digestion: maltase splits maltose → glucose, sucrase splits sucrose → glucose + fructose, lactase splits lactose → glucose + galactose).

Explain absorption: monosaccharides (glucose, fructose, galactose) absorbed by enterocytes (intestinal epithelial cells); glucose and galactose via secondary active transport (coupled with Na⁺), fructose by facilitated diffusion; enter capillaries → hepatic portal vein → liver; liver regulates blood glucose.

Describe lactose intolerance: deficiency of lactase enzyme, undigested lactose remains in intestine, bacteria ferment it producing gas, osmotic effect draws water causing bloating, cramps, diarrhea; common in adults (especially Asian, African, Native American descent); can avoid dairy or take lactase supplements.

sub_topics.name: Protein Digestion and Absorption
sub_topics.short_description: Trace breakdown of proteins to amino acids.
example_tasks: Trace digestion pathway: stomach (pepsin begins breaking proteins → polypeptides, HCl denatures proteins making them easier to digest), small intestine (trypsin, chymotrypsin, carboxypeptidase from pancreas break polypeptides → smaller peptides and amino acids, brush border peptidases complete digestion → amino acids, dipeptides, tripeptides).

Explain absorption: amino acids, dipeptides, tripeptides absorbed by enterocytes via secondary active transport (with Na⁺); peptides broken down to amino acids inside cells; amino acids enter capillaries → hepatic portal vein → liver; used for protein synthesis or converted to other molecules.

Note efficiency: protein digestion very efficient, 95-98% absorbed; very little protein reaches large intestine; intestinal bacteria that decompose proteins produce foul-smelling gases (H₂S, methane, ammonia).

sub_topics.name: Lipid Digestion and Absorption
sub_topics.short_description: Understand fat processing requiring emulsification.
example_tasks: Explain emulsification: lipids insoluble in water, form large droplets; bile salts emulsify fats (break into smaller droplets, increase surface area for lipase action), prevent droplets from re-aggregating; without bile, fat digestion severely impaired.

Trace digestion: minimal in mouth and stomach (lingual and gastric lipases, limited effect), small intestine (pancreatic lipase breaks triglycerides → monoglycerides + fatty acids, phospholipase breaks phospholipids, cholesterol esterase breaks cholesterol esters); micelles (tiny droplets of bile salts + lipid products) transport to enterocytes.

Explain absorption: lipids leave micelles and diffuse across membrane into enterocytes, reassembled into triglycerides inside cells, packaged with cholesterol and proteins forming chylomicrons (lipoprotein droplets), exocytosed into lacteals (lymphatic capillaries) → lymphatic system → bloodstream (bypasses liver initially); makes lymph milky after fatty meal.

sub_topics.name: Nucleic Acid, Vitamin, and Mineral Absorption
sub_topics.short_description: Understand absorption of other essential nutrients.
example_tasks: Describe nucleic acid digestion: pancreatic nucleases break DNA and RNA → nucleotides, brush border enzymes break nucleotides → bases, sugars, phosphates; absorbed by active transport; not essential nutrients (body synthesizes own).

Explain vitamin absorption: water-soluble vitamins (B, C) absorbed with water by diffusion or active transport; fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) absorbed with fats in micelles, packed into chylomicrons; vitamin B12 requires intrinsic factor from stomach (binds B12, complex absorbed in ileum).

Describe mineral absorption: iron absorbed in duodenum (more absorbed when deficient, controlled by regulatory proteins), transported bound to transferrin, stored as ferritin; calcium absorption enhanced by vitamin D and parathyroid hormone (active transport in duodenum); other minerals (phosphorus, magnesium, zinc) absorbed by various mechanisms; sodium, potassium, chloride actively transported.

sub_topics.name: The Urinary (Excretory) System
sub_topics.short_description: Examine kidneys and urine formation in detail.

sub_topics.name: Kidney Anatomy
sub_topics.short_description: Understand external and internal kidney structure.
example_tasks: Describe external anatomy: paired bean-shaped organs on posterior abdominal wall (retroperitoneal), 12 cm tall, indented medial surface (hilum - where vessels, nerves, ureter enter/exit), surrounded by protective layers (renal capsule, adipose capsule, renal fascia).

Describe internal anatomy: outer renal cortex (granular appearance, contains glomeruli and proximal/distal tubules), inner renal medulla (striped appearance, organized into renal pyramids containing collecting ducts and loops of Henle), renal pelvis (funnel-shaped tube, collects urine from calyces, becomes ureter).

Identify nephron: functional unit of kidney, ~1 million per kidney; each nephron consists of renal corpuscle (glomerulus surrounded by Bowman's capsule, site of filtration) and renal tubule (proximal convoluted tubule, loop of Henle, distal convoluted tubule → collecting duct); cortical nephrons (most, short loops) and juxtamedullary nephrons (20%, long loops extending into medulla, important for concentrating urine).

sub_topics.name: Urine Formation: Glomerular Filtration
sub_topics.short_description: Understand first step of urine production.
example_tasks: Explain filtration process: blood enters glomerulus under high pressure (afferent arteriole wider than efferent, increases pressure), forces fluid through filtration membrane (glomerular capillaries - fenestrated, basement membrane, podocytes with filtration slits) into Bowman's capsule; filtrate similar to plasma but lacks cells and large proteins (too big to pass).

Define glomerular filtration rate (GFR): volume of filtrate formed per minute by both kidneys, normally ~125 mL/min or 180 L/day (!); 99% must be reabsorbed or excessive fluid loss; GFR maintained relatively constant by intrinsic regulation (myogenic mechanism, tubuloglomerular feedback) and extrinsic regulation (sympathetic nervous system, renin-angiotensin system).

Describe filtration membrane selectivity: size barrier (fenestrations, basement membrane block large molecules) and charge barrier (negative charges repel plasma proteins); allows small molecules (water, glucose, amino acids, ions, urea, uric acid) to pass; diseases damaging membrane allow protein in urine (proteinuria, sign of kidney damage).

sub_topics.name: Urine Formation: Tubular Reabsorption
sub_topics.short_description: Understand reclaiming of useful substances from filtrate.
example_tasks: Explain reabsorption in proximal convoluted tubule (PCT): ~65% of filtrate reabsorbed here; all glucose and amino acids reabsorbed (unless blood levels extremely high - glucose in urine indicates diabetes), most Na⁺ (active transport, creates osmotic gradient driving water reabsorption), much Cl⁻, K⁺, bicarbonate, water follows osmotically; tubular epithelium has microvilli increasing surface area.

Explain reabsorption in loop of Henle: descending limb (permeable to water, impermeable to solutes, water leaves by osmosis, filtrate becomes concentrated), ascending limb (impermeable to water, actively pumps Na⁺ and Cl⁻ out, filtrate becomes dilute); creates osmotic gradient in medulla essential for water reabsorption in collecting duct.

Explain reabsorption in distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and collecting duct: variable reabsorption regulated by hormones; aldosterone increases Na⁺ reabsorption (and K⁺ secretion); antidiuretic hormone (ADH) increases water reabsorption by inserting aquaporins in collecting duct (concentrated urine when dehydrated), absence of ADH produces dilute urine.

sub_topics.name: Urine Formation: Tubular Secretion
sub_topics.short_description: Understand selective addition of substances to filtrate.
example_tasks: Define tubular secretion: active transport of substances from blood in peritubular capillaries into tubular filtrate; opposite of reabsorption; fine-tunes urine composition.

Identify secreted substances: K⁺ (regulated by aldosterone, important for maintaining blood K⁺ levels), H⁺ (regulates blood pH, excreting excess acid), ammonia (buffer for secreted H⁺), drugs and toxins (penicillin, creatinine, metabolites), some hormones.

Explain importance: allows regulation of blood pH (secreting H⁺ when too acidic, secreting HCO₃⁻ when too basic), eliminates substances not freely filtered (protein-bound drugs), disposes of substances produced by body (creatinine from muscle metabolism, urea from protein breakdown).

sub_topics.name: Characteristics and Composition of Urine
sub_topics.short_description: Understand properties of normal urine.
example_tasks: Describe physical characteristics: sterile (no bacteria in normal urine), clear yellow color (from urochrome, pigment from hemoglobin breakdown), characteristic odor (from diet and waste products), slightly acidic pH (~6, range 4.5-8), specific gravity 1.001-1.035 (indicates concentration).

Describe composition: 95% water, 5% solutes; nitrogenous wastes (urea ~half of solutes, from protein metabolism; uric acid from nucleic acid metabolism; creatinine from creatine phosphate breakdown in muscle), ions (Na⁺, K⁺, Cl⁻, Ca²⁺, PO₄³⁻, SO₄²⁻, HCO₃⁻), possibly small amounts of other substances depending on diet and metabolism.

Explain abnormal constituents: glucose (glycosuria, indicates diabetes or very high blood sugar), proteins (proteinuria, indicates kidney damage), blood (hematuria, indicates infection, stones, or injury), ketone bodies (ketonuria, indicates diabetes or starvation), bile pigments (bilirubinuria, indicates liver disease); urinalysis screens for these abnormalities.

sub_topics.name: Ureters, Bladder, and Urethra
sub_topics.short_description: Examine urine transport, storage, and elimination structures.
example_tasks: Describe ureters: two tubes (~25-30 cm) from kidneys to bladder, retroperitoneal, muscular walls (peristaltic contractions propel urine, gravity not required), enter bladder at oblique angle (acts as valve preventing backflow).

Describe urinary bladder: collapsible muscular sac in pelvic cavity, stores urine (~200-400 mL comfortable capacity, up to 600-800 mL maximum); wall contains detrusor muscle (smooth muscle, contracts to expel urine), lined with transitional epithelium (stretches), trigone (triangular area between ureter openings and urethra, infection-prone).

Describe micturition (urination): stretch receptors signal when bladder fills → parasympathetic stimulation contracts detrusor muscle, relaxes internal urethral sphincter → external urethral sphincter (skeletal muscle, voluntary control) relaxes → urine expelled; infants lack voluntary control, develops ~2-3 years; incontinence (inability to control) can result from spinal injury, aging, childbirth damage.

sub_topics.name: Lymphatic and Immune Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Examine fluid balance, immunity, and body defense mechanisms.

sub_topics.name: Lymphatic System Structure and Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand components and roles of lymphatic system.
example_tasks: List functions: (1) return excess tissue fluid to bloodstream (maintain fluid balance, ~3 L/day), (2) transport dietary lipids from small intestine to blood (via lacteals), (3) immune function (houses and transports lymphocytes, filters pathogens).

Describe lymphatic vessels: begin as lymphatic capillaries (blind-ended, very permeable, found in most tissues), converge into larger lymphatic vessels (similar to veins - thin walls, valves prevent backflow), flow aided by skeletal muscle pump and respiratory pump, empty into subclavian veins (right lymphatic duct drains right upper body, thoracic duct drains rest).

Identify lymphoid organs: primary (red bone marrow - lymphocyte production, thymus - T cell maturation), secondary (lymph nodes - filter lymph, trap pathogens; spleen - filters blood, removes old RBCs, stores platelets; tonsils - trap pathogens in throat; Peyer's patches - in small intestine); contain many lymphocytes and macrophages.

sub_topics.name: Innate (Nonspecific) Immunity
sub_topics.short_description: Understand first and second lines of defense.
example_tasks: Describe first line of defense (surface barriers): skin (physical barrier, sebum and sweat acidic and contain antimicrobial chemicals), mucous membranes (mucus traps microbes, cilia sweep them away, gastric acid and enzymes kill many pathogens), normal microbiota (compete with pathogens for resources, produce antimicrobial substances).

Describe second line of defense (internal defenses): phagocytes (neutrophils, macrophages engulf and destroy pathogens), natural killer (NK) cells (attack infected or cancerous cells, cause apoptosis), inflammation (redness, heat, swelling, pain; increases blood flow, brings WBCs, walls off infection, promotes healing), fever (elevated body temperature inhibits pathogen growth, speeds immune responses), complement system (proteins that enhance inflammation, attract phagocytes, lyse pathogens), interferons (proteins that inhibit viral replication, activate NK cells and macrophages).

Explain inflammatory response: tissue damage → mast cells release histamine → vasodilation and increased permeability → redness, heat, swelling → phagocytes migrate to site (chemotaxis) → engulf pathogens and debris → healing begins; chronic inflammation can be harmful.

sub_topics.name: Adaptive (Specific) Immunity Overview
sub_topics.short_description: Understand third line of defense characteristics.
example_tasks: Define adaptive immunity: specific response to particular pathogens, slow on first exposure (3-5 days to mount full response), creates immunological memory (subsequent responses faster and stronger), carried out by lymphocytes (B cells and T cells).

Explain key characteristics: specificity (recognizes and targets specific antigens), memory (enhanced response to previously encountered antigens), diversity (can respond to millions of different antigens), self-tolerance (normally doesn't attack body's own cells).

Define antigens: substances that trigger adaptive immune response, usually large complex molecules (proteins, polysaccharides, nucleic acids), foreign (from pathogens, transplanted tissues, allergens); epitopes are specific regions of antigen that antibodies or T cell receptors recognize; haptens are small molecules that must bind to body proteins to trigger response.

sub_topics.name: Humoral (Antibody-Mediated) Immunity
sub_topics.short_description: Understand B cell response and antibody production.
example_tasks: Describe B cell activation: B cell receptors bind specific antigen, B cell engulfs and displays antigen pieces (antigen presentation), helper T cell recognizes displayed antigen and releases cytokines, B cell activates and proliferates (clonal selection), producing plasma cells (secrete antibodies) and memory B cells (long-lived, rapid response if antigen encountered again).

Explain antibody structure and function: Y-shaped protein (immunoglobulin), two identical antigen-binding sites (variable regions specific for one antigen), constant region (determines antibody class); functions include neutralization (blocking pathogen attachment), agglutination (clumping pathogens together), precipitation (making soluble antigens insoluble), complement activation, opsonization (marking for phagocytosis).

Compare antibody classes: IgG (most abundant, crosses placenta providing passive immunity to fetus, most versatile), IgA (in secretions - tears, saliva, mucus, breast milk), IgM (first produced in primary response, pentamer - very effective at agglutination), IgE (involved in allergic reactions, binds mast cells and basophils), IgD (on B cell surface, function unclear).

sub_topics.name: Cellular (Cell-Mediated) Immunity
sub_topics.short_description: Understand T cell response to intracellular pathogens and abnormal cells.
example_tasks: Describe T cell types: cytotoxic T cells (CD8+, attack infected cells, cancer cells, transplanted tissue; recognize antigen + MHC I; release perforin and granzymes causing apoptosis), helper T cells (CD4+, activate B cells, cytotoxic T cells, macrophages; recognize antigen + MHC II; release cytokines; central role coordinating immune response), regulatory T cells (suppress immune response, prevent autoimmunity), memory T cells.

Explain T cell activation: requires two signals - (1) T cell receptor binding to antigen presented by MHC on antigen-presenting cell (dendritic cell, macrophage, B cell), (2) costimulation (additional surface molecules interact); activated T cell proliferates (clonal selection) producing effector cells and memory cells.

Explain MHC molecules: major histocompatibility complex proteins on cell surfaces; MHC I (on all nucleated cells, display cellular proteins including viral proteins if infected, recognized by cytotoxic T cells), MHC II (on antigen-presenting cells, display engulfed extracellular antigens, recognized by helper T cells); MHC very polymorphic (many alleles), basis of tissue rejection in transplants.

sub_topics.name: Immunological Memory and Vaccination
sub_topics.short_description: Understand basis of long-term immunity and vaccines.
example_tasks: Compare primary vs secondary immune response: primary (first exposure to antigen, 3-5 days lag, IgM produced first then IgG, relatively weak, creates memory cells), secondary (second exposure, 1-2 days lag, faster and stronger, mostly IgG, more antibodies, memory cells respond rapidly).

Explain types of immunity: active (produces own antibodies/memory cells, natural - from infection, artificial - from vaccination, long-lasting), passive (receives antibodies from another source, natural - maternal antibodies across placenta or in breast milk, artificial - antibody injection, immediate but temporary protection).

Describe vaccination: introduces antigen (killed/inactivated pathogens, attenuated/weakened live pathogens, toxoids, subunit vaccines with specific proteins) to stimulate adaptive immunity without causing disease; creates memory cells; booster shots enhance memory; herd immunity (high vaccination rates) protects those who cannot be vaccinated; vaccines have eliminated/controlled many diseases (smallpox eradicated, polio nearly eradicated, measles/mumps/rubella rare where vaccinations common).

sub_topics.name: Disorders of the Immune System
sub_topics.short_description: Understand immune deficiencies, autoimmune diseases, and hypersensitivities.
example_tasks: Describe immunodeficiency: inadequate immune response; congenital (genetic, severe combined immunodeficiency/SCID, 'bubble boy disease'), acquired (HIV/AIDS destroys helper T cells, immunosuppressive drugs after transplants, malnutrition, aging); susceptibility to infections, certain cancers.

Describe autoimmune diseases: immune system attacks body's own tissues; loss of self-tolerance; examples: type 1 diabetes (attacks pancreatic beta cells), rheumatoid arthritis (attacks joints), multiple sclerosis (attacks myelin), lupus (attacks many tissues, produces antibodies against DNA and other self-antigens), Graves' disease (antibodies stimulate thyroid); treatments suppress immune response.

Describe allergies (hypersensitivities): exaggerated immune responses to harmless antigens (allergens); immediate (IgE-mediated, rapid, mast cells release histamine causing inflammation - hay fever, asthma, food allergies, anaphylaxis), delayed (T cell-mediated, slower, poison ivy, tuberculin skin test); treatments include antihistamines, corticosteroids, epinephrine for anaphylaxis, desensitization therapy.

grade_11_12.name: Human Reproduction & Development
grade_11_12.short_description: Reproductive systems, embryology, and developmental biology. Students examine gamete production, fertilization, pregnancy, birth, and human development from conception through aging.

sub_topics.name: Male Reproductive System
sub_topics.short_description: Examine anatomy, spermatogenesis, and male reproductive functions.

sub_topics.name: Male Reproductive Anatomy
sub_topics.short_description: Identify structures of the male reproductive system.
example_tasks: Describe testes: paired oval glands in scrotum (outside body cavity, 3°C cooler optimal for sperm production), divided into lobules containing seminiferous tubules (site of sperm production), interstitial cells/Leydig cells (between tubules, produce testosterone); descent into scrotum before birth.

Describe duct system: epididymis (coiled tube on testis, sperm mature and stored here, ~20 days), ductus/vas deferens (muscular tube from epididymis, propels sperm by peristalsis, cut in vasectomy), ejaculatory duct (ductus deferens + seminal vesicle duct), urethra (through prostate and penis, carries sperm and urine, but not simultaneously).

Describe accessory glands: seminal vesicles (60% of semen volume, fructose for energy, prostaglandins, alkaline to neutralize vaginal acid), prostate gland (30% of semen, milky fluid, clotting enzymes, citrate, enzymes), bulbourethral/Cowper's glands (mucus for lubrication, pre-ejaculate); semen ~3-5 mL, 50-150 million sperm/mL.

sub_topics.name: Spermatogenesis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand sperm production process.
example_tasks: Describe process: begins at puberty, continues throughout life; spermatogonium (diploid stem cell) → primary spermatocyte (diploid, undergoes meiosis I) → two secondary spermatocytes (haploid) → meiosis II → four spermatids (haploid) → spermiogenesis (differentiation into mature sperm); supported by Sertoli cells (nurse cells, form blood-testis barrier, provide nutrients); takes ~74 days.

Describe sperm structure: head (contains nucleus with 23 chromosomes, acrosome cap with enzymes to penetrate egg), midpiece (mitochondria provide ATP for movement), tail (flagellum, propels sperm ~30-50 μm/min); designed for delivering DNA to egg.

Explain hormonal regulation: hypothalamus releases GnRH → anterior pituitary releases FSH (stimulates Sertoli cells, spermatogenesis) and LH (stimulates Leydig cells to produce testosterone) → testosterone promotes spermatogenesis, develops male characteristics, negative feedback to hypothalamus and pituitary.

sub_topics.name: Female Reproductive System
sub_topics.short_description: Examine anatomy, oogenesis, and female reproductive cycles.

sub_topics.name: Female Reproductive Anatomy
sub_topics.short_description: Identify structures of the female reproductive system.
example_tasks: Describe ovaries: paired almond-sized organs in pelvic cavity, contain follicles (oocytes surrounded by follicle cells), produce ova and hormones (estrogen, progesterone); at birth, ~2 million oocytes, decreases to ~400,000 at puberty, ~400 will ovulate in lifetime.

Describe uterine/fallopian tubes: ~10 cm tubes from near ovaries to uterus, fimbriae (fingerlike projections) sweep ovulated oocyte into tube, cilia and peristalsis move oocyte toward uterus, usual site of fertilization.

Describe uterus: pear-shaped muscular organ, ~7.5 cm, supports developing embryo/fetus; fundus (upper rounded region), body (main part), cervix (narrow neck opening to vagina); wall layers - endometrium (inner, where implantation occurs, sheds during menstruation), myometrium (thick smooth muscle, contractions during labor), perimetrium (outer covering); vagina (~10 cm) receives penis, birth canal, menstrual flow exits.

sub_topics.name: Oogenesis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand egg production process.
example_tasks: Describe process: begins before birth, arrested stages; oogonium (diploid) → primary oocyte (diploid, arrested in prophase I) present at birth, each in primordial follicle; at puberty, monthly FSH stimulates some follicles to develop → primary oocyte completes meiosis I → secondary oocyte (haploid, most cytoplasm) + first polar body (degenerates) → arrested in metaphase II → completes meiosis II only if fertilized → ovum (haploid) + second polar body.

Compare to spermatogenesis: similarities (both meiosis, produce haploid gametes), differences (oogenesis starts before birth and arrests, produces one functional gamete vs. four, unequal division conserves cytoplasm for embryo, monthly vs. continuous, ends at menopause vs. continues for life).

Describe follicle development: primordial follicle (primary oocyte + single layer cells) → primary follicle (oocyte grows, multiple cell layers) → secondary follicle (fluid-filled spaces) → mature/Graafian follicle (large fluid-filled antrum, oocyte on stalk, ovulates) → corpus luteum (after ovulation, secretes progesterone and estrogen); atresia (degeneration of follicles that don't ovulate).

sub_topics.name: Ovarian and Uterine Cycles
sub_topics.short_description: Understand monthly reproductive cycles and hormonal regulation.
example_tasks: Describe ovarian cycle phases: follicular phase (days 1-14, FSH stimulates follicle development, follicle secretes estrogen which causes endometrium to thicken), ovulation (day 14, LH surge triggers release of secondary oocyte from follicle), luteal phase (days 15-28, corpus luteum secretes progesterone and estrogen maintaining endometrium, preparing for implantation).

Describe uterine/menstrual cycle phases: menstrual phase (days 1-5, endometrium sheds if no pregnancy, bleeding), proliferative phase (days 6-14, estrogen causes endometrium to thicken/rebuild), secretory phase (days 15-28, progesterone causes endometrium to secrete nutrients, prepares for implantation); if no fertilization, corpus luteum degenerates → hormone levels drop → menstruation.

Explain hormonal regulation: hypothalamus releases GnRH → anterior pituitary releases FSH and LH → FSH stimulates follicle development and estrogen secretion → estrogen causes endometrial growth and triggers LH surge → LH surge causes ovulation and forms corpus luteum → progesterone from corpus luteum maintains endometrium and inhibits FSH/LH (negative feedback); if pregnancy occurs, hCG maintains corpus luteum.

grade_11_12.name: Microbiology
grade_11_12.short_description: Bacteria, viruses, fungi, protists, and disease mechanisms. Students explore the diversity of microorganisms, their roles in ecosystems and human health, and how they cause disease.

sub_topics.name: Bacteria: Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Examine prokaryotic cell organization and bacterial diversity.

sub_topics.name: Bacterial Cell Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Understand components and variations in bacterial cells.
example_tasks: Describe essential structures: cell wall (peptidoglycan provides shape and protection), plasma membrane (phospholipid bilayer controls entry/exit), cytoplasm (contains ribosomes, nucleoid region with circular chromosome, plasmids - small DNA circles), ribosomes (smaller than eukaryotic, 70S, target of some antibiotics).

Describe optional structures: capsule (polysaccharide layer outside cell wall, protects from phagocytosis, enhances adherence), flagella (locomotion, movement toward/away from stimuli - chemotaxis), pili/fimbriae (attachment to surfaces, sex pili for conjugation), endospores (dormant resistant structures formed by some bacteria under harsh conditions, can survive extreme heat, desiccation, chemicals).

Compare Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria: Gram-positive (thick peptidoglycan layer, no outer membrane, retain crystal violet stain appearing purple), Gram-negative (thin peptidoglycan, outer membrane with lipopolysaccharide/LPS, lose stain, counterstained pink/red); difference affects antibiotic susceptibility and pathogenicity.

sub_topics.name: Bacterial Metabolism and Growth
sub_topics.short_description: Understand metabolic diversity and reproduction in bacteria.
example_tasks: Classify by energy and carbon source: photoautotrophs (light energy, CO₂ carbon - cyanobacteria), chemoautotrophs (chemical energy from inorganic compounds, CO₂ carbon - nitrifying bacteria), photoheterotrophs (light energy, organic carbon - purple nonsulfur bacteria), chemoheterotrophs (chemical energy from organic compounds, organic carbon - most bacteria, all pathogens).

Classify by oxygen requirements: obligate aerobes (require O₂), obligate anaerobes (killed by O₂, live in oxygen-free environments), facultative anaerobes (prefer O₂ but can survive without), microaerophiles (require low O₂), aerotolerant anaerobes (don't use O₂ but tolerate it).

Describe binary fission: asexual reproduction, chromosome replicates, cell elongates, septum forms dividing cell, two identical daughter cells; generation time 20 minutes to days depending on species and conditions; exponential growth under ideal conditions; bacteria can also exchange genetic material through conjugation (plasmid transfer), transformation (uptake of DNA from environment), transduction (viral transfer of DNA).

sub_topics.name: Bacterial Diversity and Ecological Roles
sub_topics.short_description: Explore major bacterial groups and their importance.
example_tasks: Describe beneficial bacteria: decomposers (recycle nutrients by breaking down organic matter), nitrogen fixers (convert atmospheric N₂ to ammonia in soil and root nodules - Rhizobium), normal microbiota (inhabit human body, outcompete pathogens, synthesize vitamins - E. coli in intestine), food production (yogurt - Lactobacillus, cheese, vinegar, fermented foods), biotechnology (produce insulin, vaccines, enzymes).

Describe pathogenic bacteria: cause disease through toxin production (endotoxin - LPS from Gram-negative cell walls, exotoxin - secreted proteins with specific toxic effects) or tissue damage; examples: Streptococcus (strep throat, scarlet fever), Staphylococcus (skin infections, food poisoning), Mycobacterium tuberculosis (tuberculosis), Clostridium tetani (tetanus), Salmonella (food poisoning), Vibrio cholerae (cholera).

Explain antibiotic resistance: bacteria evolve resistance through mutations and plasmid transfer; mechanisms include enzyme production (beta-lactamase breaks down penicillin), altered target sites (ribosomes modified so antibiotics don't bind), efflux pumps (actively pump antibiotics out), decreased permeability; overuse and misuse of antibiotics accelerates resistance; MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) major concern; importance of completing antibiotic courses, not using for viral infections.

sub_topics.name: Viruses
sub_topics.short_description: Examine viral structure, replication, and disease.

sub_topics.name: Viral Structure and Characteristics
sub_topics.short_description: Understand what viruses are and how they're organized.
example_tasks: Describe viral characteristics: not cells, not considered alive (no metabolism, growth, or reproduction outside host), obligate intracellular parasites (must infect host cell to replicate), very small (20-400 nm, smaller than bacteria), highly specific (each virus infects specific hosts and often specific cell types due to surface proteins matching host receptors).

Describe basic structure: nucleic acid core (DNA or RNA, single or double-stranded, linear or circular), protein coat (capsid, protects nucleic acid, determines shape), sometimes envelope (lipid bilayer from host cell membrane, with viral glycoproteins for attachment); bacteriophages (viruses infecting bacteria) often have complex structures with tail fibers.

Classify viruses: by nucleic acid type (DNA vs RNA), structure (helical, icosahedral, complex), presence of envelope (enveloped vs naked/non-enveloped), host (animal, plant, bacterial); examples: influenza (enveloped RNA), HIV (enveloped RNA retrovirus), adenovirus (naked DNA), bacteriophage T4 (complex DNA).

sub_topics.name: Viral Replication Cycles
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how viruses reproduce within host cells.
example_tasks: Describe lytic cycle: (1) attachment (viral proteins bind specific receptors on host cell), (2) penetration (virus or viral DNA enters cell), (3) biosynthesis (viral DNA takes over host machinery, directs synthesis of viral components), (4) maturation/assembly (viral components assembled into complete viruses), (5) release (host cell lyses, releasing viruses to infect new cells); host cell destroyed.

Describe lysogenic cycle: virus integrates its DNA into host chromosome (provirus/prophage), replicated along with host DNA when cell divides, viral genes mostly inactive, can remain dormant for long periods, eventually may enter lytic cycle triggered by environmental stress; example: lambda phage in bacteria, herpes viruses in humans (can remain latent in nerve cells).

Describe retrovirus replication (HIV): RNA virus, enzyme reverse transcriptase synthesizes DNA from RNA template, viral DNA integrates into host chromosome, uses host machinery to transcribe viral RNA and translate viral proteins, new viruses assembled and bud from cell (acquiring envelope), host cell eventually dies; difficult to cure because integrated into host DNA.

sub_topics.name: Viral Diseases and Prevention
sub_topics.short_description: Examine important viral infections and control methods.
example_tasks: Describe examples of viral diseases: influenza (flu - respiratory, mutates rapidly requiring new vaccines), HIV/AIDS (attacks helper T cells, destroys immune system), hepatitis (liver inflammation, types A-E, some preventable by vaccine), measles/mumps/rubella (childhood diseases, preventable by MMR vaccine), rabies (fatal if untreated, transmitted by animal bites), COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2, respiratory disease, pandemic 2019-present), herpes (HSV, causes cold sores and genital herpes, remains latent), HPV (human papillomavirus, causes warts and cervical cancer, vaccine available).

Explain difficulties treating viral infections: antibiotics don't work (target bacteria, not viruses), few antiviral drugs available (hard to target viruses without harming host cells), viruses use host machinery (difficult to inhibit without damaging host), viruses mutate rapidly (especially RNA viruses like flu, HIV), some integrate into host genome; most antiviral drugs interfere with specific stages of replication.

Describe prevention strategies: vaccines (stimulate immune response to prevent infection - successful for smallpox, polio, measles, etc.), hygiene (handwashing, covering coughs, sanitizing surfaces), avoiding exposure (quarantine, social distancing during outbreaks), vector control (eliminating mosquitoes for dengue, Zika), safe practices (condoms for sexually transmitted viruses, avoiding sharing needles).

sub_topics.name: Fungi and Protists
sub_topics.short_description: Examine diversity and roles of fungi and protists.

sub_topics.name: Fungi: Characteristics and Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Understand unique features of fungi.
example_tasks: Describe fungal characteristics: eukaryotic, mostly multicellular (yeasts unicellular), heterotrophic (absorptive nutrition - secrete enzymes externally, absorb digested nutrients), cell walls of chitin (not cellulose like plants), store glycogen (like animals), reproduce via spores (sexual and asexual).

Describe structure: mycelium (network of branching filaments), hyphae (individual filaments, may be septate with crosswalls or coenocytic without crosswalls), fruiting body (mushroom - reproductive structure producing spores, only visible part, most of fungus underground); large surface area to volume ratio enhances absorption.

Classify major groups: Zygomycota (bread molds - Rhizopus, reproduce via zygospores), Ascomycota (sac fungi - yeasts, morels, truffles, cup fungi, reproduce via ascospores in asci), Basidiomycota (club fungi - mushrooms, puffballs, shelf fungi, reproduce via basidiospores on basidia), Deuteromycota (imperfect fungi - no known sexual reproduction, Penicillium).

sub_topics.name: Ecological and Economic Roles of Fungi
sub_topics.short_description: Examine importance of fungi in ecosystems and human society.
example_tasks: Describe decomposers: break down organic matter (wood, leaves, dead organisms), essential nutrient recycling in ecosystems, along with bacteria are primary decomposers; some can break down cellulose and lignin that many organisms cannot.

Describe mutualistic relationships: mycorrhizae (fungus-plant root associations, fungus provides water and minerals especially phosphorus, plant provides carbohydrates, found in ~90% of plants, essential for plant growth in many ecosystems), lichens (fungus-algae or cyanobacteria symbiosis, fungus provides structure and water retention, photosynthesizer provides food, pioneers on bare rock).

Describe human uses and impacts: beneficial (food - mushrooms, cheese production, fermentation - bread/beer/wine using yeasts, antibiotics - penicillin from Penicillium, biotechnology, vitamin production), harmful (pathogens causing athlete's foot, ringworm, yeast infections, histoplasmosis; plant diseases - rusts, smuts, blights destroy crops; food spoilage; wood rot; production of mycotoxins like aflatoxin - carcinogenic).

sub_topics.name: Protist Diversity
sub_topics.short_description: Explore the diverse kingdom of mostly unicellular eukaryotes.
example_tasks: Describe animal-like protists (protozoa): heterotrophic, motile; examples: amoeba (move by pseudopodia, phagocytosis, found in freshwater and soil), paramecium (ciliates, move by cilia, two nuclei, contractile vacuoles), Plasmodium (apicomplexan, causes malaria, transmitted by mosquitoes, complex life cycle), Trypanosoma (flagellate, causes African sleeping sickness, transmitted by tsetse fly), Giardia (flagellate, intestinal parasite, waterborne).

Describe plant-like protists (algae): photosynthetic, diverse sizes (unicellular to multicellular); examples: diatoms (silica shells, major producers in oceans and freshwater), dinoflagellates (two flagella, some bioluminescent, some toxic causing red tides), euglenoids (flagella, eyespot, both autotrophic and heterotrophic), green algae (Chlorophyta, ancestors of plants), brown algae (kelp, multicellular), red algae (mostly marine, some produce agar).

Describe fungus-like protists: heterotrophic, absorptive; slime molds (plasmodial slime molds form multinucleate mass, cellular slime molds form multicellular aggregate, both produce spores), water molds (oomycetes, include potato blight that caused Irish potato famine, fish parasites); not true fungi (different cell wall composition, different life cycles).

sub_topics.name: Infectious Disease and Epidemiology
sub_topics.short_description: Understand disease transmission, progression, and control.

sub_topics.name: Disease Transmission
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how infectious diseases spread.
example_tasks: Describe direct contact transmission: person-to-person (touching, kissing, sexual contact - STIs), droplet transmission (coughing, sneezing - influenza, COVID-19, spread ~1 meter), vertical transmission (mother to child - during pregnancy, birth, or breastfeeding - HIV, rubella, syphilis).

Describe indirect transmission: airborne (small particles remain suspended, travel long distances - tuberculosis, measles), vehicle (contaminated food/water - Salmonella, cholera, hepatitis A; contaminated objects/fomites - doorknobs, surfaces), vector-borne (insects or animals carry pathogen - mosquitoes transmit malaria, dengue, Zika; ticks transmit Lyme disease).

Identify factors affecting transmission: portal of entry (skin, mucous membranes, respiratory tract, GI tract, urogenital tract, parenteral - injection), infectious dose (number of pathogens needed to cause infection, varies by pathogen), susceptibility of host (immune status, age, nutrition, chronic diseases, genetic factors), pathogen virulence (ability to cause disease).

sub_topics.name: Disease Progression and Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Understand stages of infectious disease and epidemiological patterns.
example_tasks: Describe disease stages: incubation period (pathogen multiplying, no symptoms yet, length varies by disease), prodromal period (early mild symptoms, often most contagious), period of illness (most severe symptoms, pathogen numbers peak, immune response active), period of decline (symptoms subsiding, pathogen numbers decreasing), convalescence period (recovery, regaining strength, may still be infectious).

Define epidemiological terms: sporadic disease (occasional cases, no pattern), endemic disease (constantly present in population at relatively stable level - common cold, influenza), epidemic (unusually high number of cases in particular area - flu outbreaks), pandemic (epidemic spread worldwide - COVID-19, 1918 flu, HIV/AIDS), outbreak (cluster of cases in specific area/time).

Describe disease reservoirs: human (person with disease or carrier - asymptomatic but infectious, like Typhoid Mary), animal (zoonotic diseases transmitted from animals - rabies from dogs, avian flu from birds), environmental (soil for tetanus, water for cholera); understanding reservoirs important for disease control.

sub_topics.name: Disease Prevention and Control
sub_topics.short_description: Examine public health strategies for managing infectious diseases.
example_tasks: Describe primary prevention: preventing disease before it occurs; vaccination (most effective for many diseases), sanitation (clean water, sewage treatment, food safety), hygiene (handwashing, sterilization), vector control (insecticides, eliminating breeding sites), education (safe sex practices, avoiding IV drug use), quarantine (isolating healthy people who were exposed), lifestyle modifications (nutrition, exercise for strong immune system).

Describe secondary prevention: early detection and treatment to prevent progression; screening programs (TB testing, STI testing), contact tracing (identifying and testing people exposed to infected person), surveillance (monitoring disease trends, detecting outbreaks early), rapid diagnosis and treatment (antibiotics for bacterial infections, antivirals for some viral infections).

Describe tertiary prevention: reducing complications and disability from established disease; treatment to prevent transmission (antiretroviral therapy for HIV reduces viral load and transmission), treatment of complications (preventing progression from HIV to AIDS), rehabilitation, public health measures during epidemics (isolation of cases, social distancing, mask mandates, closure of gathering places); eradication programs (smallpox successfully eradicated 1980, polio nearly eradicated).

sub_topics.name: Emerging and Re-emerging Infectious Diseases
sub_topics.short_description: Understand why new diseases appear and old diseases resurge.
example_tasks: Define emerging infectious diseases: diseases that have newly appeared in population or are rapidly increasing in incidence or geographic range; examples: HIV/AIDS (emerged 1980s), Ebola (periodic outbreaks in Africa), SARS (2003), MERS (2012), Zika (spread to Americas 2015), COVID-19 (2019-present); many are zoonotic (jumped from animals to humans).

Explain factors contributing to emergence: ecological changes (deforestation, climate change bringing humans into contact with new pathogens or expanding vector ranges), human demographics and behavior (urbanization, international travel spreads diseases globally, sexual practices, IV drug use), technology and industry (large-scale food processing spreads contamination, medical procedures like transplants and blood transfusions), microbial adaptation (evolution of antibiotic resistance, viral mutations allowing human infection), breakdown of public health measures (inadequate vaccination programs).

Describe re-emerging diseases: previously controlled diseases increasing again; examples: tuberculosis (drug-resistant strains, HIV co-infection), measles (declining vaccination rates lead to outbreaks), pertussis (whooping cough, waning vaccine immunity), dengue (expanding range due to climate change and urbanization); reasons for re-emergence include antibiotic/antiviral resistance, decreased vaccination rates, poverty, weakened public health infrastructure, pathogen evolution.

grade_11_12.name: Plant Biology
grade_11_12.short_description: Plant structure, physiology, reproduction, and responses to environment. Students explore the unique characteristics of plants and how they function and adapt to their surroundings.

sub_topics.name: Plant Structure and Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Examine plant tissues, organs, and body organization.

sub_topics.name: Plant Tissue Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understand three tissue systems found in plants.
example_tasks: Describe dermal tissue: epidermis (outer protective layer, may have cuticle - waxy coating reducing water loss, stomata - pores for gas exchange with guard cells regulating opening, trichomes - hairs that reduce water loss or deter herbivores); periderm (in woody plants replaces epidermis, includes cork cells - dead cells providing protection).

Describe vascular tissue: xylem (conducts water and minerals from roots upward, cells include tracheids and vessel elements - dead at maturity with thick lignified walls, one-way flow) and phloem (conducts sugars and organic compounds bidirectionally, cells include sieve tube elements - living without nuclei at maturity, companion cells - provide support).

Describe ground tissue: fills space between dermal and vascular tissues; parenchyma (thin-walled, alive at maturity, photosynthesis, storage, secretion - most common), collenchyma (thicker walls, flexible support in growing regions), sclerenchyma (very thick lignified walls, dead at maturity, rigid support - fibers and sclereids).

sub_topics.name: Roots: Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Examine root anatomy and roles.
example_tasks: Describe root functions: anchor plant in soil, absorb water and minerals from soil, store nutrients (carrots, beets store carbohydrates), produce hormones, some form symbiotic relationships (mycorrhizae with fungi, nitrogen-fixing bacteria in nodules of legumes).

Describe root structure: root cap (protects apical meristem as root pushes through soil), zone of cell division (apical meristem produces new cells), zone of elongation (cells lengthen pushing root deeper), zone of maturation (cells differentiate, root hairs - extensions of epidermal cells increasing surface area for absorption appear here); vascular cylinder in center, cortex surrounding it stores starch.

Compare root types: taproot system (one main root with smaller lateral roots - carrots, oak trees, deep penetration for water), fibrous root system (many thin roots of similar size - grasses, shallow but holds soil well preventing erosion), adventitious roots (arise from stems or leaves - prop roots of corn, aerial roots of orchids).

sub_topics.name: Stems: Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Examine stem anatomy and roles.
example_tasks: Describe stem functions: support (hold leaves up to light), transport (xylem and phloem connect roots and leaves), storage (potatoes are modified stems storing starch), photosynthesis (in green herbaceous stems), produce new growth (from apical and lateral meristems).

Describe stem structure: nodes (points where leaves attach), internodes (stem segments between nodes), apical meristem (at tip, produces primary growth - length), lateral/axillary buds (potential for branch formation, kept dormant by apical dominance), vascular bundles (xylem and phloem, arrangement differs in monocots and dicots).

Compare monocot and dicot stems: monocots (corn, lilies - vascular bundles scattered throughout ground tissue, no vascular cambium, no secondary growth), dicots (oak, sunflower - vascular bundles arranged in ring, vascular cambium between xylem and phloem produces secondary growth - girth); modified stems include stolons (runners), rhizomes (underground), tubers (potatoes), bulbs (onions).

sub_topics.name: Leaves: Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Examine leaf anatomy specialized for photosynthesis.
example_tasks: Describe leaf structure: blade (flat photosynthetic surface), petiole (stalk attaching to stem, allows movement toward light), veins (vascular bundles providing support and transport); upper and lower epidermis (protective layers, upper often has thicker cuticle), mesophyll (photosynthetic tissue - palisade layer with columnar cells tightly packed near upper surface, spongy layer with loosely arranged cells near lower surface with air spaces for gas exchange).

Explain stomata function: pores (mostly on lower surface) for gas exchange, each surrounded by two guard cells; open stomata allow CO₂ in for photosynthesis and O₂ out, but also allow water loss (transpiration); guard cells regulate opening - when turgid (full of water) they curve opening pore, when flaccid they close pore; typically open during day, closed at night.

Describe leaf adaptations: large surface area maximizes light capture, thin structure allows CO₂ to reach all cells quickly, vein arrangement (parallel in monocots, netted in dicots) supports and supplies all areas; modifications include tendrils (peas - climbing), spines (cacti - defense, reduced water loss), storage leaves (onions), reproductive leaves (some succulents propagate from leaves).

sub_topics.name: Transport in Plants
sub_topics.short_description: Understand water and nutrient movement through plants.

sub_topics.name: Water Transport in Xylem
sub_topics.short_description: Examine mechanisms moving water from roots to leaves.
example_tasks: Explain transpiration-cohesion-tension theory: (1) transpiration - water evaporates from leaf mesophyll cells into air spaces and exits through stomata creating 'pull', (2) cohesion - water molecules stick together due to hydrogen bonding forming continuous column from roots to leaves, (3) tension - pull from top creates negative pressure throughout xylem pulling water up, (4) adhesion - water sticks to xylem walls preventing column breaking; most important mechanism in tall plants.

Describe root pressure: active transport of minerals into root xylem creates lower water potential, water enters by osmosis creating positive pressure that pushes water upward; minor contributor in tall plants but can cause guttation (water droplets on leaf edges at night when stomata closed).

Explain factors affecting transpiration rate: light (stomata open in light for photosynthesis increasing transpiration), temperature (increased temperature increases evaporation), humidity (low humidity increases gradient for evaporation), wind (removes humid air near leaf surface increasing gradient); plants lose 90% of water absorbed through transpiration; adaptations to reduce water loss include thick cuticle, reduced leaf surface, CAM photosynthesis.

sub_topics.name: Sugar Transport in Phloem
sub_topics.short_description: Understand translocation of organic compounds.
example_tasks: Explain pressure-flow hypothesis: (1) at source (photosynthetic leaves or storage organs), sugars actively loaded into sieve tube elements, (2) water follows by osmosis creating high pressure, (3) at sink (growing tissues, roots, fruits, flowers, storage organs), sugars actively unloaded and used or stored, (4) water follows by osmosis creating lower pressure, (5) pressure difference causes bulk flow from source to sink; requires energy for active loading/unloading.

Describe phloem loading mechanisms: symplastic (sugars move through plasmodesmata from mesophyll to sieve tubes), apoplastic (sugars exported from mesophyll, actively transported into companion cells then sieve tubes via H⁺-sucrose cotransport); companion cells maintain sieve tube elements.

Explain bidirectional flow: unlike xylem (always upward), phloem can transport in any direction depending on source and sink locations; direction can change seasonally (spring - storage organs are sources sending sugars to growing shoots, late summer - mature leaves are sources sending sugars to roots for storage); different sieve tubes can transport in different directions simultaneously.

sub_topics.name: Mineral Nutrient Uptake
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how plants acquire essential elements.
