example_tasks: List essential nutrients: macronutrients needed in large amounts (nitrogen - proteins/nucleic acids, phosphorus - ATP/DNA, potassium - enzyme activation/water balance, calcium - cell walls/signaling, magnesium - chlorophyll, sulfur - proteins), micronutrients needed in trace amounts (iron - chlorophyll synthesis, chlorine, copper, zinc, manganese, boron, molybdenum).

Explain selective uptake: soil water enters roots passively by osmosis, but minerals must be actively transported (requires ATP) because soil concentration often lower than plant needs; root hairs increase surface area; Casparian strip in endodermis forces minerals through selective plasma membranes; selectivity allows accumulation of needed minerals while excluding others.

Describe deficiency symptoms: nitrogen (chlorosis - yellowing of older leaves, stunted growth), phosphorus (dark green/purple leaves, poor root/flower development), potassium (yellow/brown leaf edges, weak stems), iron (chlorosis of young leaves, veins remain green), magnesium (chlorosis between veins of older leaves); soil testing and fertilizers correct deficiencies.

sub_topics.name: Plant Reproduction
sub_topics.short_description: Examine sexual and asexual reproduction in plants.

sub_topics.name: Flower Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Understand anatomy of reproductive structures.
example_tasks: Identify flower parts (from outside to center): sepals (typically green, protect flower bud, collectively called calyx), petals (often colorful attracting pollinators, collectively called corolla), stamens (male reproductive structures - filament supporting anther where pollen produced), carpel/pistil (female reproductive structure - stigma receives pollen, style connects to ovary containing ovules/eggs).

Describe complete vs. incomplete flowers: complete (have all four parts - sepals, petals, stamens, carpels - roses, tulips), incomplete (lack one or more parts); perfect (have both stamens and carpels - capable of self-pollination), imperfect (have only stamens or only carpels - require cross-pollination); monoecious (separate male and female flowers on same plant - corn), dioecious (male and female flowers on different plants - holly).

Explain pollination syndromes: bee-pollinated (bright colors especially blue/yellow, sweet scent, landing platform, nectar guides), butterfly-pollinated (bright red/orange, narrow tubes, daytime), moth-pollinated (white/pale, strong scent especially at night), bird-pollinated (red/orange, tubular, no scent, copious nectar), wind-pollinated (small drab flowers, no nectar/scent, large amounts of pollen, feathery stigmas - grasses, oaks).

sub_topics.name: Pollination and Fertilization
sub_topics.short_description: Trace the process from pollen transfer to seed formation.
example_tasks: Describe pollination: transfer of pollen from anther to stigma; self-pollination (pollen to stigma of same flower or another flower on same plant), cross-pollination (pollen to stigma of different plant - promotes genetic diversity); agents include insects (bees, butterflies, beetles), birds (hummingbirds), bats, wind, water; many plants have mechanisms preventing self-pollination (different maturation times, incompatibility systems).

Explain double fertilization (unique to angiosperms): (1) pollen grain lands on stigma, germinates forming pollen tube growing down style toward ovule, (2) pollen grain contains two sperm cells, (3) one sperm fertilizes egg forming diploid zygote (develops into embryo), (4) other sperm fuses with two polar nuclei forming triploid endosperm (food storage for embryo), (5) both fertilizations must occur for seed to develop.

Describe seed development: after fertilization, ovule becomes seed (contains embryo, endosperm, seed coat), ovary becomes fruit (protects seeds, aids dispersal); embryo develops from zygote (has radicle - embryonic root, hypocotyl - embryonic stem, cotyledons - seed leaves storing or absorbing nutrients, epicotyl - embryonic shoot); seed enters dormancy (metabolically inactive, can survive unfavorable conditions), germinates when conditions favorable.

sub_topics.name: Fruits and Seed Dispersal
sub_topics.short_description: Understand mechanisms spreading seeds away from parent plant.
example_tasks: Define fruit: mature ovary of flower, may include other flower parts; function is seed dispersal and protection; simple fruits (one ovary - tomato, peach, peanut), aggregate fruits (multiple ovaries from one flower - raspberry, strawberry), multiple fruits (multiple flowers - pineapple, fig); fleshy fruits (tomato, apple, grape), dry fruits (nuts, grains, pods).

Describe dispersal mechanisms: animal dispersal (fleshy fruits eaten, seeds pass through digestive system unharmed and deposited with fertilizer; burs/hooks stick to fur), wind dispersal (lightweight seeds, wings like maple samaras, parachutes like dandelion), water dispersal (buoyant, waterproof - coconuts), explosive dispersal (seed pods burst open forcefully scattering seeds - touch-me-not).

Explain importance of dispersal: reduces competition with parent plant and siblings, colonizes new habitats, maintains genetic diversity, escapes seed predators, humans important dispersal agents (agriculture spreads plants globally, fruits adapted to attract humans - sweet, colorful, large).

sub_topics.name: Asexual Reproduction in Plants
sub_topics.short_description: Examine vegetative propagation methods.
example_tasks: Describe natural vegetative reproduction: runners/stolons (horizontal stems producing new plants - strawberries, spider plants), rhizomes (underground stems - irises, ginger), tubers (enlarged underground stems - potatoes, each eye is a bud), bulbs (short underground stems with fleshy leaves - onions, tulips), corms (solid underground stems - gladiolus), plantlets (miniature plants on leaves - Kalanchoe), fragmentation (pieces of plant regenerate - cacti).

Describe artificial propagation: cuttings (stem, leaf, or root pieces develop roots and shoots - geraniums, African violets), grafting (joining stem from one plant to rootstock of another - fruit trees to maintain variety and use hardy rootstock), layering (stem remains attached to parent while developing roots), tissue culture/micropropagation (growing plants from single cells or small tissue pieces in sterile conditions - orchids, bananas).

Compare sexual and asexual reproduction: sexual produces genetic diversity but requires energy for flowers/fruits, slower, dependent on pollinators/favorable conditions; asexual produces genetically identical clones (maintains successful genotype) but lacks diversity, faster, independent of pollinators, can reproduce in poor conditions; many plants use both strategies depending on circumstances.

sub_topics.name: Plant Responses and Regulation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how plants respond to environmental stimuli and regulate growth.

sub_topics.name: Plant Hormones
sub_topics.short_description: Examine chemical messengers controlling plant growth and development.
example_tasks: Describe auxins: promote cell elongation (responsible for phototropism and gravitropism), apical dominance (suppressing lateral buds), root formation, fruit development; produced in shoot tips and young leaves; synthetic auxins used as herbicides (2,4-D kills dicots but not monocots - lawn care).

Describe other major hormones: gibberellins (stem elongation, seed germination, flowering), cytokinins (promote cell division especially in roots, delay senescence - aging, work antagonistically with auxins in apical dominance), abscisic acid (closes stomata during drought, seed dormancy, stress responses), ethylene (fruit ripening, leaf abscission, senescence; gas that can spread between plants - one rotten apple spoils the bunch).

Explain hormone interactions: plant responses usually result from interactions among multiple hormones with ratios being important; example: high auxin/cytokinin ratio promotes root development, low ratio promotes shoot development (used in tissue culture); commercial applications include extending fruit shelf life (blocking ethylene), seedless fruits (using gibberellins), rooting cuttings (auxin powder).

sub_topics.name: Tropisms: Directional Growth Responses
sub_topics.short_description: Understand growth toward or away from stimuli.
example_tasks: Explain phototropism: growth toward light (positive) or away from light (negative); shoots show positive phototropism, roots often negative or neutral; mechanism - auxin accumulates on shaded side causing more elongation on that side, bending toward light; ensures leaves positioned for maximum light capture.

Explain gravitropism: growth in response to gravity; roots show positive gravitropism (grow downward), shoots show negative gravitropism (grow upward); mechanism involves statoliths (starch-containing plastids) settling in cells, triggering auxin redistribution; ensures proper orientation even if seed lands upside down.

Describe other tropisms: thigmotropism (growth in response to touch - vines coil around supports, tendrils), hydrotropism (roots grow toward water), chemotropism (pollen tubes grow toward chemicals released by ovules); tropisms are growth responses (permanent changes due to differential growth rates), not movements.

sub_topics.name: Photoperiodism and Flowering
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how day length affects plant development.
example_tasks: Define photoperiodism: physiological response to changes in day length (photoperiod); critical for timing flowering, dormancy, leaf senescence; allows plants to anticipate seasonal changes.

Classify plants by flowering response: long-day plants (flower when day length exceeds critical period, actually short-night plants, bloom in spring/early summer - spinach, lettuce, iris), short-day plants (flower when day length shorter than critical period, actually long-night plants, bloom in late summer/fall - chrysanthemums, poinsettias), day-neutral plants (flower regardless of photoperiod, respond to other cues like temperature or age - tomatoes, roses).

Explain mechanism: phytochrome (photoreceptor protein) exists in two interconvertible forms (Pr absorbs red light converting to Pfr, Pfr absorbs far-red light converting to Pr); Pfr is active form triggering responses; during day (sunlight has more red than far-red) Pfr accumulates, at night Pfr slowly converts to Pr; critical night length determines if enough Pfr broken down; interrupting night with light (even briefly) can prevent flowering in short-day plants; commercial applications include controlling flowering time for holidays (poinsettias for Christmas).

sub_topics.name: Plant Defenses Against Herbivores and Pathogens
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how plants protect themselves.
example_tasks: Describe physical defenses: thorns and spines (modified stems/leaves - roses, cacti), tough leaves (silica, thick cuticle, sclerenchyma - grasses), trichomes (hair-like structures may be barbed or secrete sticky/toxic substances), bark (protective covering on woody stems).

Describe chemical defenses: toxins (alkaloids like nicotine, caffeine, morphine deter herbivores, can be poisonous to humans), digestibility reducers (tannins bind proteins making leaves less nutritious, lignin hard to digest), volatile compounds (release airborne chemicals that attract predators of herbivores or warn neighboring plants); many plant chemicals used as drugs, spices.

Describe responses to attack: induced defenses (chemicals produced only when attacked, conserves resources), systemic acquired resistance (localized infection triggers defense responses throughout plant), releasing volatiles that attract predators/parasites of attacking herbivore, rapidly increasing production of defensive chemicals; plants can even distinguish between different herbivores and respond differently; some plants have evolved alongside specific pollinators or herbivores in coevolutionary relationships.

grade_11_12.name: Animal Biology & Comparative Anatomy
grade_11_12.short_description: Animal diversity, body plans, and evolutionary relationships. Students explore the major animal phyla, comparing anatomical structures and understanding adaptations to different environments and lifestyles.

sub_topics.name: Animal Characteristics and Body Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Understand features defining animals and levels of organization.

sub_topics.name: Defining Characteristics of Animals
sub_topics.short_description: Identify features shared by all animals.
example_tasks: List animal characteristics: multicellular eukaryotes, heterotrophic (ingest food then digest internally), most can move at some life stage, lack cell walls (have extracellular matrix instead), reproduce sexually (though some also asexually), diploid life cycle (gametes only haploid stage), embryonic development (zygote undergoes cleavage forming blastula).

Describe nutritional mode: animals are consumers unable to make their own food; methods include filter/suspension feeding (sponges, baleen whales), substrate feeding (earthworms, caterpillars eat through food), fluid feeding (mosquitoes, aphids, hummingbirds), bulk feeding (most animals ingest large pieces, carnivores eat other animals, herbivores eat plants, omnivores eat both, detritivores eat decaying matter).

Explain colonial vs. truly multicellular: colonial organisms (like Volvox) are aggregates of similar cells with little differentiation or integration; true animals have specialized cell types organized into tissues performing different functions, cells dependent on each other, complex organization.

sub_topics.name: Body Plans and Symmetry
sub_topics.short_description: Compare different organizational patterns in animals.
example_tasks: Compare symmetry types: asymmetry (no symmetry - most sponges), radial symmetry (body parts arranged around central axis, multiple planes of symmetry, oral-aboral axis - cnidarians, adult echinoderms), bilateral symmetry (left and right sides mirror images, one plane of symmetry, anterior-posterior axis, dorsal-ventral axis, cephalization - concentration of sensory organs and nervous tissue at anterior end - most animals).

Explain advantages: radial symmetry suits sessile or slow-moving animals (can detect stimuli from all directions), bilateral symmetry suits actively moving animals (can move directionally, anterior end encounters environment first allowing cephalization for sensory processing and rapid response).

Describe germ layers: diploblastic (two embryonic tissue layers - ectoderm and endoderm - cnidarians), triploblastic (three layers - ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm - most animals); layers give rise to different adult tissues (ectoderm → skin and nervous system, endoderm → digestive lining, mesoderm → muscles and most organs).

sub_topics.name: Body Cavities
sub_topics.short_description: Compare presence and type of coelom.
example_tasks: Define coelom: fluid-filled body cavity completely lined by mesoderm; functions include cushioning organs, allowing independent movement of organs, space for organ development, hydrostatic skeleton in some animals.

Compare types: acoelomate (no coelom, solid body between gut and outer wall - flatworms), pseudocoelomate (body cavity partially lined by mesoderm - roundworms), coelomate/eucoelomate (true coelom fully lined by mesoderm - annelids, mollusks, arthropods, echinoderms, chordates).

Explain evolutionary trend: coelom evolved independently in different lineages (protostomes and deuterostomes), provided advantages allowing evolution of more complex organ systems, larger body sizes, more efficient circulation.

sub_topics.name: Protostome and Deuterostome Development
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish two major evolutionary lineages based on embryonic development.
example_tasks: Compare cleavage patterns: protostomes - spiral determinate cleavage (cell fates determined early, cells cannot develop into complete embryo if separated), deuterostomes - radial indeterminate cleavage (cell fates determined later, cells can develop into complete embryos if separated - allows identical twins).
Compare coelom formation: protostomes - schizocoelous (coelom forms from splits in mesoderm), deuterostomes - enterocoelous (coelom forms from outpocketings of archenteron/primitive gut).

Compare fate of blastopore (first opening in gastrula): protostomes (blastopore becomes mouth, includes mollusks, annelids, arthropods), deuterostomes (blastopore becomes anus, mouth forms secondarily, includes echinoderms and chordates); molecular data confirms these are major evolutionary branches.

sub_topics.name: Invertebrate Diversity
sub_topics.short_description: Survey major invertebrate phyla and their characteristics.

sub_topics.name: Sponges and Cnidarians
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the simplest animal groups.
example_tasks: Describe sponges (Porifera): asymmetrical, sessile, no true tissues, body wall with pores (ostia), central cavity (spongocoel), collar cells/choanocytes (flagellated cells create water current and capture food), filter feeders, skeleton of spicules (silica or calcium carbonate) or spongin (protein fibers), most marine; represent early divergence in animal evolution.

Describe cnidarians: radial symmetry, diploblastic (two germ layers), gastrovascular cavity (digestive compartment with single opening), cnidocytes (specialized stinging cells with nematocysts for defense and capturing prey), nerve net (decentralized nervous system), two body forms - polyp (sessile like Hydra, sea anemones) and medusa (swimming like jellyfish), some alternate between forms (obelia).

Compare hydra, jellyfish, corals: Hydra (freshwater, solitary polyp, asexual budding and sexual), jellyfish (medusa dominant, planula larva settles and becomes polyp that buds off medusae), corals (colonial polyps secreting calcium carbonate skeleton, mutualistic relationship with zooxanthellae algae, build coral reefs - important ecosystems and biodiversity hotspots threatened by climate change).

sub_topics.name: Worm Phyla: Flatworms, Roundworms, and Segmented Worms
sub_topics.short_description: Compare different worm body plans.
example_tasks: Describe flatworms (Platyhelminthes): bilateral symmetry, cephalization, acoelomate, gastrovascular cavity (single opening), protonephridia (flame cells for excretion/osmoregulation); free-living (planarians in freshwater, capable of regeneration) or parasitic (flukes and tapeworms cause diseases - blood flukes/schistosomiasis, tapeworms absorb nutrients through body wall, complex life cycles with multiple hosts).

Describe roundworms (Nematoda): bilateral, pseudocoelomate, complete digestive tract (mouth and anus), tough cuticle (molted as grow), unsegmented; very abundant and diverse (more individual nematodes than all other animals combined), many free-living in soil and water, many parasitic (Ascaris, hookworms, pinworms, Trichinella from undercooked pork, heartworms in dogs, C. elegans model organism in research).

Describe segmented worms (Annelida): bilateral, coelomate, segmentation (repeated body units, allows specialization and efficient movement), complete digestive tract, closed circulatory system; classes include Oligochaeta (earthworms - terrestrial, hermaphroditic, important soil aerators), Polychaeta (marine worms - paddle-like parapodia, some tube-dwelling), Hirudinea (leeches - parasites, anticoagulant in saliva used medicinally).

sub_topics.name: Mollusks
sub_topics.short_description: Examine diverse phylum with soft bodies often protected by shells.
example_tasks: Describe mollusk characteristics: soft body, muscular foot (for movement), visceral mass (contains organs), mantle (tissue layer secreting shell in most species, may form siphons or tentacles), radula (rasping feeding structure in many species), most have open circulatory system (except cephalopods), coelomates, protostomes.

Compare classes: Gastropoda (snails, slugs, largest class, most aquatic, some terrestrial - garden snails and slugs, coiled shell in snails, torsion during development twists body), Bivalvia (clams, oysters, mussels, scallops, two hinged shells, suspension feeders using gills to filter, lack radula, mostly sessile or burrow), Cephalopoda (octopuses, squid, cuttlefish, nautilus, most intelligent invertebrates, closed circulatory system, reduced or internal shell, jet propulsion, tentacles, excellent vision, chromatophores for color change).

Explain ecological and economic importance: food source (clams, oysters, squid), produce pearls, some serious agricultural pests (snails and slugs), some transmit parasites (snails intermediate hosts for schistosomiasis), indicators of water quality, important in food webs.

sub_topics.name: Arthropods
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the most diverse animal phylum.
example_tasks: Describe arthropod characteristics: segmented bodies with specialized segments (tagmosis - fusion of segments into functional units like head, thorax, abdomen), jointed appendages (arthropod means 'jointed foot'), exoskeleton of chitin (provides protection and support, must molt/ecdyze to grow), open circulatory system, coelomate, protostome, bilateral, ventral nerve cord; most successful animal phylum (over 1 million species described, estimates of 5-10 million total).

Compare major groups: Chelicerata (spiders, scorpions, ticks, mites, horseshoe crabs - two body parts, six pairs of appendages including chelicerae, no antennae), Crustacea (crabs, lobsters, shrimp, barnacles, pill bugs - mostly aquatic, two pairs antennae, gills, many legs), Myriapoda (centipedes and millipedes - many body segments, many legs, terrestrial), Hexapoda/Insecta (insects - three body parts, three pairs legs, one pair antennae, most have wings, most diverse group).

Describe insect diversity and importance: most diverse group of animals (beetles alone ~400,000 species), complete metamorphosis (egg → larva → pupa → adult - butterflies, beetles, bees) or incomplete metamorphosis (egg → nymph → adult - grasshoppers, dragonflies); essential pollinators, decomposers, food for other animals; agricultural pests, disease vectors (mosquitoes transmit malaria, ticks transmit Lyme disease), some beneficial (bees make honey, silkworms produce silk, ladybugs eat aphids).

sub_topics.name: Echinoderms
sub_topics.short_description: Examine the closest invertebrate relatives to vertebrates.
example_tasks: Describe echinoderm characteristics: radial symmetry as adults (bilateral as larvae - shows evolutionary relationship to chordates), water vascular system (unique hydraulic system with tube feet for locomotion, feeding, gas exchange), endoskeleton of calcium carbonate plates (ossicles), spiny skin, coelomate, deuterostome, all marine; classes include sea stars, brittle stars, sea urchins, sand dollars, sea cucumbers.

Explain water vascular system: network of fluid-filled canals, madreporite (intake plate) on surface, radial canals extend into arms, tube feet with suction cups controlled by ampullae (muscular sacs), creates hydraulic pressure for movement and gripping; unique to echinoderms.

Describe sea star characteristics and regeneration: five or more arms radiating from central disk, mouth on bottom (oral surface), anus on top (aboral surface), predators (can pull apart bivalve shells using tube feet), remarkable regenerative ability (can regrow lost arms, entire individual can regenerate from single arm with part of central disk if damaged).

sub_topics.name: Vertebrate Diversity
sub_topics.short_description: Survey major vertebrate groups and their evolutionary adaptations.

sub_topics.name: Chordate Characteristics
sub_topics.short_description: Identify features defining the phylum Chordata.
example_tasks: List four defining characteristics (present at some stage of development): notochord (flexible rod providing support, replaced by vertebral column in vertebrates), dorsal hollow nerve cord (develops into brain and spinal cord in vertebrates, contrasts with ventral solid nerve cord of invertebrates), pharyngeal slits/pouches (openings in pharynx, become gill slits in aquatic chordates, develop into other structures in terrestrial vertebrates - parts of ear, tonsils, thymus, parathyroid), muscular post-anal tail (extends beyond anus, aids locomotion).

Describe non-vertebrate chordates: tunicates/sea squirts (larvae have all chordate features and swim, adults sessile filter feeders, only pharyngeal slits remain), lancelets/amphioxus (retain all chordate features as adults, fishlike, segmented muscles, filter feeders in sand); demonstrate ancestral chordate body plan.

Explain vertebrate innovations: vertebral column (backbone of vertebrae protects spinal cord, provides support for larger size), cranium (braincase protects enlarged brain), complex organs and organ systems, well-developed sensory organs; most vertebrates also have paired appendages (fins or limbs).

sub_topics.name: Fishes
sub_topics.short_description: Compare jawless, cartilaginous, and bony fishes.
example_tasks: Describe jawless fishes (Agnatha): most primitive vertebrates, no jaws or paired fins, cartilaginous skeleton, notochord persists; hagfishes (marine scavengers, slime production, can tie body in knot) and lampreys (some parasitic attaching to other fish, some free-living); represent earliest vertebrate body plan.

Describe cartilaginous fishes (Chondrichthyes): jaws (major evolutionary innovation allowing diverse feeding), cartilaginous skeleton (lighter than bone), no swim bladder (must swim continuously to avoid sinking or rest on bottom), placoid scales (toothlike), multiple gill slits visible externally; sharks, rays, skates (highly successful predators, acute senses especially smell and electroreception, internal fertilization).

Describe bony fishes (Osteichthyes): bony skeleton, operculum (flap covering gills), swim bladder (gas-filled sac for buoyancy control), scales (dermal, overlapping), most with external fertilization; most diverse vertebrate group (~30,000 species), ray-finned fishes (vast majority, thin flexible fins) and lobe-finned fishes (fleshy fins with bones, includes coelacanth thought extinct and lungfishes, ancestors of tetrapods).

sub_topics.name: Amphibians
sub_topics.short_description: Examine first terrestrial vertebrates with dual lifestyle.
example_tasks: Describe amphibian characteristics: first tetrapods (four limbs, evolved from lobe-finned fish), thin moist skin (used for gas exchange, must stay moist), ectothermic (body temperature depends on environment), three-chambered heart (two atria, one ventricle, some mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood), most have biphasic life cycle (aquatic larval stage with gills, terrestrial adult stage with lungs).

Compare major groups: frogs and toads (Anura - tailless as adults, powerful hind legs for jumping, most carnivorous, vocal cords for calling), salamanders (Urodela - tailed, some aquatic, some terrestrial, some neotenic retaining larval features as adults - axolotl), caecilians (Apoda - legless, wormlike, tropical, burrow in soil).

Explain metamorphosis: eggs laid in water (no amnion, desiccate easily) → aquatic tadpole/larva (gills, tail, herbivorous in many frogs) → metamorphosis triggered by thyroid hormone (develops legs, lungs, absorbs tail, changes to carnivorous) → adult moves to land; some salamanders bypass metamorphosis; amphibian populations declining worldwide due to habitat loss, disease (chytrid fungus), pollution, climate change.

sub_topics.name: Reptiles
sub_topics.short_description: Examine adaptations for fully terrestrial life.
example_tasks: Describe reptilian adaptations for land: amniotic egg (shell and membranes - amnion, chorion, allantois, yolk sac - protect embryo and prevent desiccation, allow reproduction away from water), dry scaly skin (keratinized scales prevent water loss, shed periodically), efficient lungs (better developed than amphibians), three-chambered heart (crocodilians have four chambers), ectothermic (behavioral thermoregulation - basking, seeking shade), internal fertilization.

Compare major groups: turtles (body enclosed in shell made of fused bones and plates, ribs fused to shell, toothless beak, some terrestrial/tortoises, some aquatic), snakes and lizards (Squamata, most diverse reptiles, lizards usually four legs, snakes legless evolved from lizards, highly flexible skull, Jacobson's organ for chemoreception, some venomous), crocodilians (crocodiles, alligators, most like dinosaur ancestors, semiaquatic predators, four-chambered heart, parental care), tuataras (only two species in New Zealand, superficially lizard-like, living fossils).

Describe evolutionary importance: first fully terrestrial vertebrates, dominated terrestrial ecosystems for 200+ million years (dinosaurs), most dinosaurs extinct 65 million years ago (K-T extinction - asteroid impact), birds are living dinosaurs (evolved from theropod dinosaurs, more closely related to crocodilians than to other reptiles).

sub_topics.name: Birds
sub_topics.short_description: Examine adaptations for flight and unique characteristics.
example_tasks: Describe adaptations for flight: feathers (modified scales, provide insulation, lift, flight control, display), wings (modified forelimbs with strong flight muscles attached to enlarged sternum/keel), lightweight skeleton (hollow bones with air sacs connected to lungs, fused bones), no teeth (lightweight beak instead), high metabolism (endothermic/warm-blooded, four-chambered heart, efficient respiratory system with air sacs and one-way airflow through lungs), excellent vision.

Describe bird diversity: ~10,000 species, diverse beaks and feet adapted to different diets and habitats (seed-eating finches, fish-eating pelicans, nectar-feeding hummingbirds, predatory hawks), complex behaviors (elaborate courtship displays, territoriality, migration over thousands of miles, tool use in some species - crows), most fly but some flightless (ostriches, penguins - wings used for swimming, kiwis).

Explain reproduction and parental care: internal fertilization, hard-shelled amniotic eggs (require incubation for development), most build nests, extensive parental care (brooding eggs, feeding chicks), altricial young (born helpless, naked, require care - most songbirds) vs. precocial young (born with down feathers, mobile soon after hatching - ducks, chickens), monogamy common in birds (both parents invest in offspring).

sub_topics.name: Mammals
sub_topics.short_description: Examine characteristics and diversity of mammals.
example_tasks: Describe mammalian characteristics: hair (provides insulation, sensory function, camouflage, display), mammary glands (produce milk, extensive parental care), endothermic (maintain constant body temperature through metabolism), four-chambered heart, diaphragm (aids breathing), differentiated teeth (incisors, canines, premolars, molars adapted to diet), large brain relative to body size, most viviparous (give birth to live young, extended development inside mother).

Compare major groups: monotremes (egg-laying mammals - platypus, echidnas, found only in Australia/New Guinea, primitive features but produce milk), marsupials (young born very immature, complete development in pouch - kangaroos, koalas, opossums, mostly Australia but some Americas, separate evolution on isolated continent), placentals/eutherians (longest gestation with placenta nourishing fetus, most diverse and widespread, most mammals including humans).

Describe placental diversity: orders include Primates (grasping hands, binocular vision, large brains - humans, apes, monkeys, lemurs), Rodentia (gnawing teeth - mice, rats, squirrels, beavers, most species), Carnivora (meat-eaters with carnassial teeth - cats, dogs, bears, seals), Cetacea (whales, dolphins, fully aquatic, evolved from terrestrial mammals), Chiroptera (bats, only flying mammals, echolocation), Proboscidea (elephants), Ungulates (hoofed - horses, cattle, pigs, deer, rhinoceros); mammals adapted to every habitat from oceans to deserts to arctic to underground.

grade_11_12.name: Advanced Ecology & Environmental Science
grade_11_12.short_description: Ecosystem analysis, succession, and climate change. Students examine complex ecological interactions, long-term community changes, and environmental challenges facing the modern world.

sub_topics.name: Community Ecology
sub_topics.short_description: Examine interactions among species in communities.

sub_topics.name: Community Structure and Diversity
sub_topics.short_description: Understand factors determining community composition.
example_tasks: Define community: all populations of different species living and interacting in the same area at the same time; characterized by species diversity (number of species and their relative abundance), trophic structure (feeding relationships), spatial distribution, temporal changes.

Explain species diversity indices: species richness (number of different species), species evenness (relative abundance of each species), Shannon diversity index (accounts for both richness and evenness); high diversity generally indicates healthy, stable communities but depends on environment.

Describe factors affecting diversity: latitude (diversity generally increases toward equator - tropics most diverse), habitat complexity (more niches support more species), environmental stability (stable environments allow specialization), community age (mature communities often more diverse), island size and isolation (larger, closer islands more diverse - island biogeography theory).

sub_topics.name: Ecological Succession
sub_topics.short_description: Understand community changes over time.
example_tasks: Review primary succession: colonization of lifeless areas (rock, sand, lava), pioneer species (lichens, mosses tolerant of harsh conditions, break down rock creating soil), followed by grasses, shrubs, eventually trees if climate permits; slow process (centuries to millennia).

Review secondary succession: occurs after disturbance (fire, farming abandonment, logging, hurricane) where soil remains; faster than primary (decades to century), begins with seed bank or surviving roots, progresses through grasses → shrubs → pioneer trees → shade-tolerant trees.

Explain mechanisms: early species modify environment making it suitable for later species (facilitation - early plants build soil), species replacement occurs through competition (late species outcompete early species in changed conditions), inhibition (early species prevent later species), tolerance (later species unaffected by early species); climax community (stable endpoint) determined by climate and soil, but may never be reached due to ongoing disturbances.

sub_topics.name: Disturbance and Intermediate Disturbance Hypothesis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand role of disturbance in maintaining diversity.
example_tasks: Define disturbance: events that remove organisms and change resource availability (fires, storms, floods, droughts, disease outbreaks, human activities); natural part of ecosystems, create patchiness in communities.

Explain intermediate disturbance hypothesis: moderate levels of disturbance create highest diversity; low disturbance allows competitive dominants to exclude others (low diversity), high disturbance allows only disturbance-tolerant species (low diversity), intermediate disturbance prevents competitive exclusion while not being too severe, maintains diverse community with early, mid, and late-successional species.

Provide examples: forest fires (clear out understory, germinate some seeds, create openings for sun-loving species), prairie fires (prevent tree invasion maintaining grassland, stimulate growth), flood plains (periodic flooding prevents succession to forest, maintains diverse wetland communities); fire suppression in some ecosystems actually reduces diversity.

sub_topics.name: Ecosystem Ecology: Advanced Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Examine energy flow and nutrient cycling in depth.

sub_topics.name: Energy Flow and Ecological Efficiency
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze energy transfer between trophic levels.
example_tasks: Calculate ecological efficiency: percent of energy transferred from one trophic level to next, typically ~10% (ranges 5-20%); remaining 90% lost as heat during metabolism, movement, growth, reproduction, unconsumed biomass, indigestible material; explains why food chains rarely exceed 4-5 trophic levels (insufficient energy to support higher levels).

Explain production concepts: gross primary production (GPP - total photosynthesis), net primary production (NPP - GPP minus plant respiration, energy available to herbivores), net secondary production (energy incorporated into consumer biomass, available to next level); NPP varies by ecosystem (tropical forests and estuaries highest, open ocean and deserts lowest).

Analyze food web efficiency: calculate energy available at each level given inputs (e.g., if 10,000 kcal at producer level, ~1,000 kcal at primary consumer, ~100 kcal at secondary consumer, ~10 kcal at tertiary consumer); explain why large predators rare (require large territory to obtain sufficient energy), why eating lower on food chain more efficient for feeding humans.

sub_topics.name: Detailed Nutrient Cycling
sub_topics.short_description: Examine biogeochemical cycles and human impacts in depth.
example_tasks: Analyze carbon cycle complexity: atmospheric CO₂ ↔ terrestrial plants (photosynthesis/respiration) ↔ soil organic matter (decomposition) ↔ fossil fuels (over millions of years); oceanic reservoirs (dissolved CO₂, bicarbonate, carbonate, phytoplankton, deep ocean sediments); human impacts (burning fossil fuels adding ~10 GtC/year, deforestation reducing carbon storage, cement production, ocean acidification from CO₂ absorption).

Analyze nitrogen cycle complexity: atmospheric N₂ (largest reservoir, unavailable to most organisms) → biological/industrial fixation → ammonia → nitrification to nitrates → plant uptake → animal consumption → decomposition → ammonification or denitrification back to N₂; human impacts (Haber-Bosch process doubles natural nitrogen fixation, excess fertilizer causes eutrophication, creates dead zones, nitrous oxide from fertilizers is greenhouse gas).

Explain limiting nutrients: Liebig's law of minimum (growth limited by scarcest resource), nitrogen often limiting in terrestrial ecosystems, phosphorus often limiting in aquatic ecosystems (no atmospheric reservoir, released slowly from rocks); fertilizers supplement limiting nutrients increasing productivity but excess causes problems.

sub_topics.name: Trophic Cascades
sub_topics.short_description: Understand indirect effects through food webs.
example_tasks: Define trophic cascade: changes at one trophic level cause reciprocal changes at other levels, propagating through food web; top-down control (predators control herbivores control plants) vs. bottom-up control (nutrients control plant growth control herbivore abundance).

Provide classic example - Yellowstone wolves: wolves extirpated early 1900s → elk populations exploded → overgrazing of willows and aspens → reduced beaver habitat, songbirds, riparian vegetation, increased erosion; wolf reintroduction 1995 → reduced elk numbers → vegetation recovery → beaver return, increased biodiversity, stabilized riverbanks → demonstrates importance of apex predators.

Describe other examples: sea otters control sea urchins control kelp forests, sharks control smaller predators affecting entire reef communities, fishing of top predators affects entire marine ecosystems; loss of top predators generally reduces ecosystem stability and diversity.

sub_topics.name: Climate Change: Causes, Impacts, and Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Examine global warming in depth.

sub_topics.name: Climate Science and Evidence
sub_topics.short_description: Understand mechanisms and evidence for anthropogenic climate change.
example_tasks: Explain enhanced greenhouse effect: naturally occurring greenhouse gases (H₂O, CO₂, CH₄, N₂O) trap heat maintaining Earth's temperature; human activities increasing concentrations (CO₂ from fossil fuels, CH₄ from agriculture/landfills, N₂O from fertilizers); CO₂ increased from 280 ppm pre-industrial to >420 ppm current, highest in 800,000+ years (ice core data); enhanced greenhouse effect causing warming.

Present multiple lines of evidence: global temperature records (land, ocean, satellite), glacier retreat worldwide, Arctic sea ice decline, ice sheet mass loss (Greenland, Antarctica), sea level rise (~20 cm since 1900, accelerating), ocean heat content increase, earlier spring events, species range shifts; consistency across independent measurements strengthens conclusions.

Address common misconceptions: weather vs. climate (weather is short-term, climate is long-term average; cold weather doesn't disprove warming trend), climate has changed before naturally (true, but current rate unprecedented for past 10,000 years and correlates with human activities), scientific consensus very strong (>97% of climate scientists agree humans causing current warming based on evidence).

sub_topics.name: Impacts of Climate Change
sub_topics.short_description: Examine wide-ranging consequences of global warming.
example_tasks: Describe physical impacts: more frequent/intense heat waves, altered precipitation (droughts in some regions, floods in others), stronger hurricanes (warmer water provides more energy), sea level rise threatening coastal cities (thermal expansion + melting ice), ocean acidification (absorbed CO₂ forms carbonic acid, pH decreased 0.1 since pre-industrial, harms shell-forming organisms), permafrost thaw (releases stored carbon - positive feedback), disrupted ocean currents potentially including Gulf Stream.

Describe ecological impacts: phenological mismatches (species respond differently to temperature - plants flowering before pollinators emerge), range shifts (species moving poleward/upward, limited by dispersal ability, barriers, habitat availability), coral bleaching (heat stress causes symbiotic algae loss, repeated bleaching kills reefs), increased wildfire frequency/intensity, changing disease vector distributions, extinction risk especially for specialized species, Arctic ecosystems changing dramatically.

Describe human impacts: agricultural disruption (changing growing seasons, crop failures, shifts in suitable areas), water scarcity (glacier-fed rivers, groundwater depletion, drought), increased heat-related deaths, disease spread (mosquito-borne diseases expanding), climate refugees (displacement from sea level rise, drought, extreme weather), economic costs (infrastructure damage, adaptation needs, loss of ecosystem services), disproportionate effects on vulnerable populations and developing nations.

sub_topics.name: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation
sub_topics.short_description: Explore strategies for addressing climate change.
example_tasks: Describe mitigation strategies (reducing emissions): transition to renewable energy (solar, wind, geothermal, reducing fossil fuel use), improve energy efficiency (buildings, transportation, industry), sustainable transportation (electric vehicles, public transit, biking/walking), reduce deforestation and promote reforestation (trees absorb CO₂), sustainable agriculture (reduced emissions, carbon sequestration in soil), carbon capture and storage (experimental, capturing CO₂ from power plants), reduce consumption and waste.

Describe adaptation strategies (adjusting to changes): coastal defenses (seawalls, managed retreat from vulnerable areas), water management (storage, efficient use, desalination), heat-resilient infrastructure and urban planning, drought-resistant crops, disease surveillance and prevention, early warning systems for extreme weather, protecting biodiversity refugia, planned relocation of vulnerable communities; adaptation necessary because some warming inevitable even with emissions reductions.

Discuss policy approaches: international agreements (Paris Agreement - limit warming to 1.5-2°C, requires dramatic emissions cuts), carbon pricing (tax or cap-and-trade making emissions costly, incentivizing cleaner alternatives), regulations (emission standards, renewable energy mandates), subsidies for clean energy, individual actions matter but systemic changes essential; challenges include economic concerns, political will, international cooperation, balancing development and sustainability.

sub_topics.name: Conservation Biology
sub_topics.short_description: Examine science and practice of protecting biodiversity.

sub_topics.name: The Biodiversity Crisis
sub_topics.short_description: Understand current extinction rates and causes.
example_tasks: Quantify crisis: current extinction rate estimated 100-1000× natural background rate, sixth mass extinction in Earth's history but first caused by single species (humans); many species declining even if not yet extinct (functionally extinct if population too small to fulfill ecological role); exact numbers uncertain (many species undescribed, especially invertebrates, tropical species).

Explain HIPPO threats in detail: Habitat destruction/fragmentation (most important, includes deforestation, wetland drainage, urbanization, agriculture expansion, fragments isolate populations causing genetic problems), Invasive species (outcompete natives, predate, transmit diseases - rats, cats, snakes on islands devastating; Burmese pythons in Everglades), Pollution (pesticides, plastics, heavy metals, endocrine disruptors), human Population growth (increasing resource demands), Overharvesting (overfishing, bushmeat, ivory trade, pet trade), Climate change increasingly important.

Describe effects of biodiversity loss: ecosystem services reduced (pollination, pest control, water purification, climate regulation), less resilience to environmental changes, cascading extinctions (species depend on each other), loss of potential medicines and resources, ethical/aesthetic arguments for preservation, 'extinction debt' (species committed to extinction due to past habitat loss may not disappear for decades).

sub_topics.name: Conservation Approaches and Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Examine methods for protecting species and ecosystems.
example_tasks: Describe protected areas: national parks, wilderness areas, marine reserves; need adequate size (island biogeography - larger areas support more species), connectivity (corridors allow movement between patches), representation (protect all ecosystem types), enforcement (prevent poaching, illegal logging); current coverage ~15% land, ~8% ocean, goal to increase; challenges include lack of funding, human-wildlife conflict at boundaries, 'paper parks' with inadequate protection.

Explain population management: captive breeding (zoos, botanical gardens maintain populations of critically endangered species for potential reintroduction - California condor success), genetic management (maintaining diversity, preventing inbreeding in small populations), translocation (moving individuals to establish new populations or supplement declining ones), managing invasive species (eradication from islands, biocontrol - introducing natural enemies, careful to avoid unintended consequences).

Describe ecosystem-level approaches: protecting keystone species has cascading effects, protecting umbrella species (large-ranging species like tigers, protecting their habitat protects many other species), ecosystem restoration (re-establishing habitats, removing invasive species, reintroducing locally extinct species), sustainable use (allowing limited harvesting if managed properly - fisheries quotas, sustainable forestry, ecotourism providing economic incentive for conservation).

sub_topics.name: Conservation Challenges and Ethics
sub_topics.short_description: Examine difficult questions in conservation practice.
example_tasks: Discuss prioritization dilemmas: limited resources require difficult choices (which species to save? charismatic megafauna vs. ecologically important but less popular species? species richness hotspots vs. unique evolutionary lineages?), triage approach controversial (write off species with no hope?), taxonomic bias (vertebrates, plants get more attention than invertebrates, fungi).

Address human dimensions: balancing conservation with human needs especially in developing countries, involving local communities essential (people support conservation when they benefit - jobs, education, sustainable resource use), land rights and indigenous peoples (traditional practices often sustainable), ecotourism benefits and problems (revenue for conservation but can disturb wildlife).

Examine ethical questions: does species have intrinsic value beyond usefulness to humans? obligations to future generations? acceptable to let species go extinct to help humans? de-extinction (using cloning, genetic engineering to revive extinct species like mammoth - scientifically possible but is it wise? diverts resources from protecting living species, ecosystem roles may no longer exist).

grade_11_12.name: Evolutionary Biology & Speciation
grade_11_12.short_description: Mechanisms of speciation, phylogeny, and evolutionary patterns. Students explore how new species arise, how evolutionary relationships are determined, and large-scale patterns in the history of life.

sub_topics.name: Speciation Mechanisms
sub_topics.short_description: Examine how reproductive isolation evolves and new species form.

sub_topics.name: Allopatric Speciation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand speciation through geographic isolation in depth.
example_tasks: Explain process in detail: (1) continuous population divided by geographic barrier (mountain range forms, river changes course, sea level rises creating islands, habitat fragmentation), (2) gene flow prevented between populations, (3) populations experience different selection pressures and genetic drift, (4) mutations accumulate independently, (5) populations diverge genetically and phenotypically, (6) if barrier removed, populations may no longer interbreed (reproductive isolation evolved); time required varies (thousands to millions of years).

Describe evidence: most speciation probably allopatric (supported by species distributions - many closely related species in adjacent geographic areas), island species resemble nearest mainland species more than other islands (Galápagos finches resemble South American finches), ring species (populations can interbreed with neighbors around geographic barrier but terminal populations cannot interbreed - salamanders around California's Central Valley).

Discuss peripatric speciation: type of allopatric speciation where small population becomes isolated at edge of main range; founder effect (small population doesn't represent full genetic diversity), genetic drift stronger in small populations, may diverge rapidly; explains many island species (Hawaii - many species evolved from single colonist).

sub_topics.name: Sympatric Speciation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand speciation without geographic isolation.
example_tasks: Explain polyploidy in plants: autopolyploidy (chromosome doubling within species - meiosis error produces diploid gametes, fusion creates tetraploid, reproductively isolated from diploid parents because triploid offspring usually sterile), allopolyploidy (hybridization between species + chromosome doubling, hybrid initially sterile but chromosome doubling makes it fertile, new species); common in plants (~70% angiosperms show evidence), rare in animals (incompatible with sex determination in most groups, occurs in some amphibians and fish).

Describe sexual selection: divergence in mate preferences can lead to reproductive isolation without geographic separation; African cichlid fishes (hundreds of species in same lakes, diverged based on female color preferences, body shape, feeding specialization), Hawaiian Drosophila (elaborate courtship behaviors diverged), process accelerated if preferences linked to ecologically important traits.

Explain habitat differentiation: populations specialize on different resources/habitats within same area; apple maggot flies (originally on hawthorn, shifted to apples when introduced, now two host races, partial reproductive isolation - mate on their host fruit and emergence times differ), palm species on same island specializing on different soil types; disruptive selection favoring extremes can lead to reproductive isolation if mating occurs in specialized habitat.

sub_topics.name: Reinforcement
sub_topics.short_description: Understand strengthening of reproductive isolation.
example_tasks: Define reinforcement: when two diverging populations come back into contact and produce low-fitness hybrids, selection favors traits that prevent hybridization (strengthening prezygotic barriers), completing speciation; essentially natural selection favoring assortative mating (mating with own type).

Provide evidence: closely related species in sympatry (living together) often show greater differences in mate recognition signals than in allopatry (reproductive character displacement); example: two frog species have different calls where they co-occur but similar calls where allopatric, European flycatchers show reinforcement in plumage and song.

Explain hybrid zones: regions where populations interbreed producing hybrids; stable hybrid zones (hybrids persist, gene flow continues, may be maintained by environmental gradient) vs. tension zones (hybrids less fit, hybrid zone moves over time); studying hybrid zones reveals strength of reproductive barriers and ongoing selection.

sub_topics.name: Phylogenetics and Systematics
sub_topics.short_description: Examine methods for reconstructing evolutionary history.

sub_topics.name: Methods for Constructing Phylogenies
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how evolutionary trees are built.
example_tasks: Explain morphological approach: compare anatomical features, use shared derived characters (synapomorphies) to group species, outgroup comparison determines ancestral vs. derived states; advantages - works for fossils, can see adaptations; disadvantages - homoplasy (convergent evolution or reversal can mislead), limited number of characters, subjective character selection.

Explain molecular approach: compare DNA or protein sequences, assume more similar sequences indicate more recent common ancestor, statistical methods build trees; advantages - objective, many characters (thousands of nucleotides), works for all organisms; disadvantages - doesn't work for fossils, molecular clock not perfectly regular, horizontal gene transfer complicates bacterial phylogenies.

Describe parsimony principle: simplest explanation preferred (tree requiring fewest evolutionary changes most likely correct); maximum likelihood (tree that makes observed data most probable), Bayesian methods (incorporates prior knowledge and uncertainty); different methods sometimes produce different trees, consensus methods combine results.

sub_topics.name: Reading and Interpreting Phylogenies
sub_topics.short_description: Extract information from phylogenetic trees.
example_tasks: Identify monophyletic groups (clades): include ancestor and all descendants, evolutionarily meaningful groupings, what taxonomy should reflect; paraphyletic groups (include ancestor and some but not all descendants - reptiles excluding birds, problematic because artificial) vs. polyphyletic groups (don't include common ancestor - warm-blooded animals including birds and mammals but not other descendants of their common ancestor, not valid taxonomic groups).

Interpret branch lengths: can represent time (chronogram - older nodes deeper, branch lengths proportional to time), genetic change (phylogram - longer branches mean more mutations), or no information (cladogram - only topology matters); examine molecular clock - calibrated using fossil dates, estimates divergence times, can reveal rapid radiations (many species in short time) or stasis (little change over long time).

Use phylogenies to test hypotheses: ancestral state reconstruction (infer features of ancestors - when did flight evolve?), biogeography (where did groups originate? how did they disperse?), coevolution (do phylogenies of hosts and parasites match?), timing of innovations (when did key features evolve?), gene family evolution (duplications, losses, subfunctionalization).

sub_topics.name: Macroevolution and Large-Scale Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Examine evolution above the species level.

sub_topics.name: Rates and Patterns of Evolution
sub_topics.short_description: Understand variation in evolutionary tempo.
example_tasks: Compare gradualism vs. punctuated equilibrium: gradualism (Darwin's view - steady accumulation of small changes), punctuated equilibrium (Eldredge & Gould - long periods of stasis punctuated by rapid change during speciation); fossil record often shows stasis then sudden appearance of new forms (could be gaps in record or real pattern); both probably occur, relative frequency debated.

Explain adaptive radiation: rapid diversification of single lineage into many species occupying different ecological niches; occurs when: new habitat becomes available (islands, post-extinction), key innovation evolves (flight, flowers), competitors removed; examples: Darwin's finches (14 species from one ancestor in ~2 million years), Hawaiian honeycreepers, Cambrian explosion (most animal phyla appear in fossil record in geologically short period ~542 million years ago).

Describe evolutionary trends: directionality in evolution (increasing complexity, body size changes, shifts in traits over time); Cope's rule (tendency for body size to increase in lineages, but not universal), horse evolution showing increasing size and changing teeth (not linear progression, bushy tree with many branches), brain size increase in hominids; trends result from selection, constraints, or random walk.

sub_topics.name: Mass Extinctions
sub_topics.short_description: Examine major biodiversity crises in Earth's history.
example_tasks: Describe 'Big Five' mass extinctions: Ordovician (444 mya, ~85% species lost), Devonian (375 mya, ~75%), Permian (251 mya, >90%, 'Great Dying'), Triassic (200 mya, ~80%), Cretaceous-Paleogene/K-T (66 mya, ~75% including non-avian dinosaurs); each followed by adaptive radiation of survivors.

Explain K-T extinction causes: asteroid impact (Chicxulub crater Mexico, iridium layer worldwide, caused tsunamis, fires, impact winter blocking sunlight, global cooling); possibly also Deccan Traps volcanism (India, massive lava flows); eliminated dominant terrestrial vertebrates (dinosaurs), marine reptiles, ammonites; mammals and birds diversified afterward.

Discuss current sixth extinction: caused by humans (habitat destruction, overexploitation, invasive species, pollution, climate change), rate 100-1000× background, differs from previous extinctions (caused by single species in geologically instantaneous time), consequences unknown but concerning (ecosystem collapse, loss of services humans depend on), conservation urgent.

sub_topics.name: Evolutionary Developmental Biology (Evo-Devo)
sub_topics.short_description: Understand how developmental changes produce evolutionary innovations.
example_tasks: Explain Hox genes role: master control genes determining body plan, highly conserved across animals, changes in number, expression pattern, or timing produce major morphological changes; example: arthropod diversity (insects, spiders, crustaceans) results partly from Hox gene expression differences determining leg and wing number/position.

Describe heterochrony: changes in timing of developmental events produce evolutionary change; paedomorphosis (adult retains juvenile features - axolotls retain gills, humans retain juvenile ape skull shape), peramorphosis (extended development produces exaggerated adult features); explains how small genetic changes can produce large morphological differences.

Explain developmental constraints: not all variants possible, development limits variation, channels evolution along certain paths; example: tetrapod limbs show variations but always five or fewer digits (developmental program constrains), segmentation in arthropods constrains possible body plans; helps explain why certain forms never evolve despite potential advantages.

grade_11_12.name: Bioethics & Modern Biology
grade_11_12.short_description: Ethical issues in genetic engineering, cloning, and medical research. Students examine moral, social, and legal questions arising from advances in biological technology.

sub_topics.name: Ethics of Genetic Engineering
sub_topics.short_description: Examine moral questions surrounding genetic modification.

sub_topics.name: GMO Crops and Foods
sub_topics.short_description: Understand ethical debates about genetically modified organisms.
example_tasks: Present benefits arguments: increased crop yields (feeding growing population), reduced pesticide use (Bt crops), enhanced nutrition (Golden Rice with vitamin A), drought/disease resistance (improving food security), economic benefits for farmers; proponents argue GMOs essential for food security and sustainability.

Present concerns/objections: potential health risks (allergens, unknown long-term effects, though no confirmed cases in approved GMOs), environmental risks (gene flow to wild relatives, evolution of resistance in pests, effects on non-target organisms), corporate control of seeds (patents, terminator technology, farmer dependence), labeling and consumer choice (right to know what's in food), ethical objections to 'tampering with nature'.

Discuss ethical frameworks: utilitarian (maximize benefits - feeding people - vs. minimize harms - environmental risks), rights-based (consumer right to know, farmer autonomy), precautionary principle (absence of proof of harm doesn't mean safe, better safe than sorry vs. stifles beneficial innovation), justice (who benefits? will GMOs help poor or increase inequality?); importance of science-based regulation, case-by-case assessment, transparency.

sub_topics.name: Human Genetic Modification
sub_topics.short_description: Examine gene therapy and germline editing debates.
example_tasks: Distinguish somatic vs. germline modification: somatic gene therapy (modifying body cells to treat disease in individual, changes not inherited - treating sickle cell by modifying blood stem cells), germline editing (modifying eggs, sperm, or embryos, changes inherited - affects future generations); somatic therapy generally accepted if safe/effective, germline highly controversial.

Present arguments for germline editing: prevent genetic diseases (eliminate harmful mutations from family lines), more effective than repeated somatic therapy, reduces suffering; enhancement possibilities (increase intelligence, athleticism, appearance) might benefit individuals and society.

Present arguments against germline editing: safety concerns (off-target effects, mosaicism, unknown long-term consequences affecting descendants who can't consent), enhancement leads to inequality (genetic haves and have-nots), designer babies undermine human dignity, slippery slope (treatment → enhancement → eugenics), playing God/unnatural; most countries ban germline editing pending ethical consensus; 2018 Chinese researcher creating gene-edited babies condemned worldwide, imprisoned.

sub_topics.name: Cloning and Stem Cell Research Ethics
sub_topics.short_description: Examine debates over cloning and embryonic stem cells.

sub_topics.name: Therapeutic vs. Reproductive Cloning
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish goals and ethical status.
example_tasks: Define reproductive cloning: creating genetically identical organism (cloned animals - Dolly sheep 1996, many species since); if applied to humans would produce genetically identical person; universally condemned for humans (safety - very high failure rate, abnormalities; psychological harm - expectations, identity issues; reduces people to products; affects gene pool).

Define therapeutic cloning: creating embryo for stem cell harvest (matches patient's DNA, no immune rejection), embryo destroyed in process; could treat diseases (Parkinson's, diabetes, spinal cord injury); main controversy - creates embryo to destroy it, moral status of embryo.

Present ethical positions: embryo is person from conception (destroying is murder, even for beneficial purposes - many religious views), embryo is potential person deserving respect but not full rights (can sacrifice for greater good of treating disease - utilitarian), focus on reducing suffering of existing people (embryos in IVF clinics will be destroyed anyway, better to use for research); iPSCs (induced pluripotent stem cells from adult cells) partially bypass issue but therapeutic cloning may still be useful.

sub_topics.name: Medical Research Ethics
sub_topics.short_description: Understand ethical principles governing research.

sub_topics.name: Principles of Research Ethics
sub_topics.short_description: Examine guidelines protecting research subjects.
example_tasks: Explain informed consent: participants must: understand study (risks, benefits, procedures), voluntarily agree (no coercion), be competent to decide, be able to withdraw; special protections for vulnerable populations (children, prisoners, mentally impaired); exceptions - emergency research where consent impossible, must have community input.

Explain institutional review boards (IRBs): committees review research protocols before approval, assess risks and benefits (benefits must justify risks), ensure informed consent procedures adequate, monitor ongoing studies, can stop studies if problems; established after Tuskegee syphilis study (1932-1972, infected Black men not told diagnosis or treated even after treatment available - major ethics violation).

Discuss animal research ethics: '3 Rs' - Replacement (use alternatives when possible - cell cultures, computer models), Reduction (minimize animal numbers while getting valid data), Refinement (minimize pain and distress - anesthesia, analgesics, enriched housing11:37); animal research essential for medical progress (vaccines, treatments, surgical techniques) but must minimize suffering; IACUC (Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee) oversees animal research.

grade_11_12.name: Independent Research & Lab Techniques
grade_11_12.short_description: Advanced laboratory skills, experimental design, and scientific communication. Students conduct independent investigations and communicate findings using scientific conventions.

sub_topics.name: Advanced Laboratory Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Master sophisticated biological research methods.

sub_topics.name: Molecular Biology Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Perform DNA/RNA extraction, PCR, and gel electrophoresis.
example_tasks: Perform DNA extraction: lyse cells (detergent breaks membranes), remove proteins (protease enzyme, phenol-chloroform extraction or salting out), precipitate DNA (cold ethanol or isopropanol), assess quantity and quality (spectrophotometry - A260/A280 ratio ~1.8 for pure DNA, gel electrophoresis for integrity).

Set up and run PCR: design primers (18-25 bp, Tm 55-65°C, no self-complementarity), optimize reaction conditions (annealing temperature, MgCl₂ concentration, cycle number), run thermal cycler, analyze products on agarose gel; applications include DNA fingerprinting, pathogen detection, cloning.

Perform gel electrophoresis: prepare agarose gel (concentration depends on DNA fragment size - 0.8% for large, 2% for small), load samples with loading dye (provides density and tracking dye), run at appropriate voltage (too high causes overheating), stain with ethidium bromide or safer alternatives, visualize under UV light, compare to DNA ladder to determine sizes.

sub_topics.name: Advanced Microscopy
sub_topics.short_description: Use different microscopy methods for specialized applications.
example_tasks: Prepare microscope slides: wet mounts (temporary, living specimens), fixed and stained (permanent, dead specimens, various stains highlight different structures - methylene blue for nuclei, iodine for starch), thin sections (embedding in paraffin or resin, cutting with microtome).

Use phase contrast microscopy: enhances contrast in unstained transparent specimens, converts phase shifts to amplitude changes making structures visible; useful for living cells, doesn't require fixing/staining.

Compare microscope types and applications: bright field (basic, stained specimens), dark field (specimen bright on dark background, unstained), fluorescence (fluorescent dyes or proteins emit light when excited, specific labeling - GFP to track proteins), electron microscopy (much higher resolution but can't view living, expensive, requires training).

sub_topics.name: Advanced Experimental Design
sub_topics.short_description: Design and conduct rigorous scientific investigations.

sub_topics.name: Developing Research Questions
sub_topics.short_description: Formulate testable hypotheses from observations.
example_tasks: Generate research questions from observations: identify gaps in knowledge, consider practical applications, use literature review to refine questions; good questions are: specific, testable, relevant, feasible with available resources and time; example progression: "How do plants grow?" (too broad) → "What affects plant growth rate?" (better) → "Does blue light increase lettuce growth rate compared to red light?" (specific and testable).

Formulate hypotheses: null hypothesis (no effect/difference), alternative hypothesis (specific predicted effect); hypotheses must be: falsifiable (possible to disprove), based on existing knowledge, specific about expected results; example: H₀ - light color has no effect on lettuce growth rate, H₁ - lettuce under blue light grows faster than under red light.

Design experiments to test hypotheses: identify variables (independent - manipulated, dependent - measured, controlled - kept constant), determine sample size (power analysis, balance between statistical power and resources), consider feasibility (time, equipment, safety, ethical approval if needed).

sub_topics.name: Data Collection and Statistical Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Collect data systematically and analyze appropriately.
example_tasks: Collect data systematically: use standardized protocols (ensures reproducibility), record all observations (even unexpected results), maintain detailed lab notebook (dated entries, protocols, observations, calculations, thoughts), use appropriate measurement tools (with adequate precision), replicate (multiple trials increase reliability).

Perform statistical analyses: descriptive statistics (mean, median, mode, range, standard deviation), inferential statistics - t-test (compare two groups), ANOVA (compare multiple groups), chi-square (categorical data), correlation/regression (relationships between variables); understand p-value (probability results due to chance, p<0.05 typically considered significant), distinguish correlation from causation.

Graph data effectively: choose appropriate graph type (scatter plot for correlations, bar graph for categories, line graph for time series), include error bars (standard deviation or standard error), label axes with units, descriptive title; graphs should be self-explanatory, support conclusions without requiring text explanation.

sub_topics.name: Scientific Communication
sub_topics.short_description: Present research findings in multiple formats.

sub_topics.name: Writing Formal Lab Reports
sub_topics.short_description: Communicate research in standard scientific format.
example_tasks: Write effective sections: Abstract (concise summary of entire study, ~250 words), Introduction (background, significance, hypothesis), Materials and Methods (detailed enough for replication, past tense), Results (present data objectively, figures and tables, no interpretation), Discussion (interpret results, compare to other studies, limitations, future directions, restate conclusions), References (properly cited).

Use scientific writing style: third person ("The plants were measured" not "I measured the plants"), past tense for completed actions, present tense for established facts, precise language avoiding ambiguity, define technical terms, avoid anthropomorphizing ("the enzyme facilitates" not "helps").

Cite sources properly: use consistent citation style (APA, MLA, CSE), cite all sources of information (journal articles, books, websites), avoid plagiarism (quote directly if using exact words, paraphrase and cite if using ideas), understand peer-reviewed vs. non-peer-reviewed sources (peer-reviewed more reliable).

sub_topics.name: Oral and Poster Presentations
sub_topics.short_description: Present research to audiences.
example_tasks: Prepare oral presentation: organize logically (introduction → methods → results → discussion), use visual aids (slides with graphs, images, minimal text), practice delivery (timing, clarity, maintain eye contact), prepare for questions; 10-15 minute presentation typical for student research.

Create research poster: standard format (Introduction, Methods, Results, Conclusions in columns), visual emphasis (large fonts, graphs and images prominent, minimal text), self-explanatory (viewer can understand without presenter), attractive layout (organized, balanced, not cluttered); be prepared to discuss in detail when presenting.

Answer questions effectively: listen carefully to question, take moment to think, admit if don't know answer (offer to investigate), use questions to clarify and expand on work, remain professional even with critical questions; defending research is normal part of science.
